summary:
A roadside improvised explosive device [IED] blast killed one soldier and wounded a second in Datta Khel, on the Afghanistan-Pakistan border.
The remotely triggered explosion targeted a convoy of security personnel in the North Waziristan agency. The IED blast also damaged the security vehicle.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. The government has a peace deal implemented with the main Taliban group in the area, under the control of Hafiz Gul Bahadur, that states neither side will attack the other. Splinter groups in the area, especially Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan [TTP] members who fled from South Waziristan are known to operate in the area, outside of this agreement.

No group claimed responsibility, and there had been no reported threats against the jirga prior to the attack.

FARC have an active presence in the area.

summary:
A roadside bomb in Raman district, Yala, wounded one soldier.
The remotely controlled device was prematurely triggered, exploding just before two motorbikes and a truck carrying eight soldiers passed along the road. The soldiers had been escorting agriculture officials when the blast occurred. The five kilogramme explosive left a meter-wide, 80cm deep crater in the world.
Police blamed southern separatist militants, though no claim of responsibility was made.

The defence volunteer guard was waiting outside his home in Ban Kuemeng for a lift to work, when two men on a motorbike pulled up, and the passenger shot the volunteer. The man later died in hospital, and the gunmen escaped.
No claim of responsibility was made, though southern separatist militants frequently later local representatives of the government.

Four soldiers had been provided security for teachers along the Pattani-Yala road in Ban Ton Phai area, when the roadside device exploded. Five kilogrammes of explosive had been concealed by a tree, and triggered by radio.
Police have blamed southern separatist militants for the attack, though no claim of responsibility has been made. Such attacks are frequent, especially against educational figures in the southern provinces of Thailand.

summary:
A bomb blast killed two children and wounded three other people in the Salarzai tehsil of the Bajaur Agency.
The device had been remotely detonated inside a crowded market shop and sparked a fire in its wake. Eyewitnesses claimed a man had left a plastic bag inside the shop before exiting with a remote in his hand. The attack occurred during rush hour in the market.
The targets of the blast was believed to be members of the pro-government peace committee, who had actively been purging the area of militants.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though one arrest was made.

summary:
A suicide car bomb blast in Quetta killed ten people and wounded at least 21 more, before a gunfight broke out following the explosion.
The strength of the blast in a residential neighbourhood was reported to be of a very large size, damaging several houses and at least eight vehicles in the vicinity. The explosion occurred outside the home of the son of former federal oil minister. A fire broke out in the wake of the detonation, and as police and media responded to the scene, gunmen opened fire.
No immediate claim of responsibility was made. Balochistan has seen an ongoing insurgency that has generated violence across the entirety of the region.

summary:
Suspected Maoist rebels killed seven people in Bihar state before dumping their bodies in a village in Banka district.
Approximately 100 Maoists had initially stormed village in Jamui district, attacking and killing three people instantly before abducting four more. The following day the bodies of the four abducted people were found riddled with bullets in a nearby village pond.
Jamui is considered a Maoist stronghold. The Maoists claim that those killed had been involved in criminal activities, including assaulting local women.

Al-Shabaab has frequently attacked military forces in Mogadishu since it was expelled from the city earlier in the year.

summary:
A Qassam rocket was fired into the western Negev. No casualties or damage resulted from the strike as the rocket did not appear to explode.
The rocket launch came in the wake of two IDF strike against militants in Gaza that killed one and injured 10. Earlier in the day, another rocket had been launched towards Israel, but fell short and exploded on the Palestinian side of the divide. Two rockets had also been fired on the 25 and 26 December into Israeli territory. No casualties or damage was reported from any of the strikes.
No responsibility was claimed. Israel has conducted several cross-border raids, after going on high alert on 08 December following fears that gunmen had crossed over into the south of the country.

summary:
A roadside landmine killed three soldiers and wounded three civilians in Bosaso, Puntland.
The remote control device was detonated as a Puntland security forces attempted to disarm the bomb. The explosion occurred close to the town's sea port, on a path leading to the presidential palace. Three members of the Puntland Intelligence Service [PIS] were killed in the blasts, and three civilians in the vicinity injured.
The blast comes in the wake of the discovery of another explosive device earlier in the day, on the main road to the city's airport. Both the Somali Prime Minister, and the Puntland President, were due in the city on an official visit.
No responsibility for the blast was claimed. The PIS had previously been targeted by Al-Shabaab in 2008 when a suicide bomb killed six. Last week the militants threatened attacks in the state, after the announcement that a UN-supported consultation conference would be held in the state's capital.

An improvised explosive device [IED] thrown into an Arabic school in Sapele in the Delta state wounded seven people.
The homemade bomb was thrown into the school from a moving vehicle. Six of the injured were children under the age of nine.
The attack comes in the wake of a series of attacks over the Christmas period that targeted churches in the country, leaving over 40 people dead. There are fears that this is the start of an escalation of sectarian violence between the Muslim and Christian populations.
Police believe a local vigilante group may be behind the attack, but no claim of responsibility was made.

summary:
A bomb exploded at the Equitalia tax collection office in Olbia, Sardinia, though no casualties were incurred.
The low-intensity bomb, thought to have been constructed of gelatin, caused minimal material damage to the front of the office. Neighbouring buildings remained intact in the mostly deserted Colca suburb where the office was located.The blast was the latest in a string of letter bombs that had been sent to the company's office in Rome earlier in the month.
No responsibility for the latest blast was claimed.

summary:
A suicide car bomb killed at least seven people outside the Ministry of the Interior in Baghdad. 27 other people were wounded in the blast.
The bomber rammen an explosive-filled car into a police checkpoint at the main road leading to the Ministry. Several cars in the vicinity were destroyed in the blast. At least 14 of the wounded were policeman.
The attacks comes four days after a bombing spree in the city killed over 70 people, and in the wake of an arrest-warrent issued for the Sunni vice-president. There are fears that sectarian violence will re-ignite across the country, after US troops finally left the country.

summary:
An improvised explosive device (IED) was recovered from a national highway near the Mindanao Textile Corporation compound in Datu Odin Sinsuat, Maguindanao.
The IED comprised two 81 mm mortars attached to a battery and timer device, and was concealed in a charcoal-filled sack. It had been unloaded from a jeep by unidentified men, who left it on the roadside before driving away. The site was located a kilometre from an army base. The military recovered the device, and safely detonated it at a nearby junk yard as it was too dangerous to defuse.
No group claimed responsibility for the attempt, but separatist militants have frequently carried out bomb attacks in the region. The explosives were reported to have been inside a box with "BIFF" marked on the front. The Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters are a splinter faction from the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), but a spokesman denied their involvement

summary:
Boko Haram carried out a bomb attack at a church in Madalla on Christmas Day, killing 35 people and wounding at least 52 more.
The blast occurred just outside St Theresa's Catholic Church near the capital city of Abuja, as the Christmas morning mass was ending. The victims were caught up in the blast as they exited the church and entered their cars. The roof of the church was destroyed, as well as several houses in the vicinity of the blast. Five cars were completely burnt out. The improvised explosive devices that caused the blast were thrown from a moving vehicle at the front of the church.
The previous year Boko Haram had carried out a wave of bombings on Christmas Eve that killed 32 people. In a statement claiming responsibility, Boko Haram stated that they would continue until their demands had been met. Their insurgency has been conducted as part of a campaign in order to implement Shariah law across the country. The shift from security personnel to religious targets has generated fears that the group is exploiting religious differences in the country.
source_urls: BBC News; AP; Reuters; AFP; Sydney Morning Herald; The News Tribune

summary:
A suicide car bomb attack on a Frontier Corps [FC] military base killed six people and wounded 19 more in Bannu, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
The suicide bomber drove his car into military building, and the resulting blast caused a section of the FC building to collapse, as well as a nearby officers' mess. The military checkpoint was completely destroyed, whilst several houses in the vicinity sustained damage due to the strength of the blast.Approximately 500kg of explosive were thought to have been used in the attack.
The six dead were Tochi Scouts, a wing of the FC who play an active role in combating militants in the area.
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants claimed responsibility, citing it revenge for the killing of a local commander in November. It was the second significant attack in the area, after TTP militants attacked another base in the Tank district.

summary:
A double suicide car bomb attack killed 44 people and wounded 166 in Damascus.The majority of casualties were civilians.
According to Syrian state media reports, one car tried to ram into the the State Security Directorate, whilst a second car laden with explosives detonated minutes lateroutside an intelligence building.The explosions occurred in the Qabound district in west Damascus, and the Jamarek area of Mezzeh district.
Within an hour of the blast, State TV reported that 'Al-Qaeda' was the principle suspect of the attack. One of the bombers was allegedly arrested shortly after the attack. President al-Assad later confirmed that the attacks were the work of Al-Qaeda.
The attack comes a day after Arab League observers arrived in the country to monitor the unrest. Opposition groups claimed the government carried out the attack itself.

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants attacked a Frontier Corps military post in the Tank district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, killing one soldier, wounding two and kidnapping 15 others.
The militants also set fire to the base, having initiated the attack with rockets and mortars. They captured several weapons in the attack.
The TTP claimed the attack was revenge for the death of a local commander, and announced the intention to execute the prisoners.
On 5 January. the bodies of the soldiers were left the town of Shiwa, in the Thal area of Hangu district, North Waziristan. The bodies bore the marks of torture as well as gunshot wounds.

summary:
Two roadside bombs killed at least seven people and injured 21 others in Umal, Baghdad. The bombs went off near a police patrol. Three police officers were among the dead.
The attack was one of 13 coordinated explosions that struck neighbourhoods across Baghdad during rush hour. At least 60 people were killed and over 200 others wounded. The bombings took place between approximately 0630hrs and 0830hrs. They targeted shops, markets, schools, hospitals and government buildings in Sunni, Shia and mixed sectarian neighbourhoods. The timing of the attack shows they were designed to inflict maximum levels of casualties and disruption.
The bombings occurred five days after US troops withdrew from Iraq and as the country faces a deepening  political crisis. On 19th December, the government issued an arrest warrant for the vice president on charges of terrorism. Tariq al-Hashemi denied the charges, and fled to the semi-autonomous Kurdish Region (KR). The allegations by the Shia prime minister against the Sunni vice president heightened sectarian tension in the country.
On 12th December the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) - the most active terrorist group in Iraq -  issued a communiqu threatening a new campaign of attacks. The last waves of coordinated attacks took place on 15th August during Ramadan and were claimed by the ISI; in that instance, the group also issued a statement threatening attacks during the Muslim holy month.
On 27 December, ISI issued a statement claiming responsibility. stating the attacks had been in support of Sunnis held in prison, and warning of further attacks against the Shiite government.

On 19th December, the government issued an arrest warrant for the vice president on charges of terrorism. Tariq al-Hashemi denied the charges, and fled to the semi-autonomous Kurdish Region (KR). The allegations by the Shia prime minister against the Sunni vice president heightened sectarian tension in the country.
On 12th December, the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) - the most active terrorist group in Iraq -  issued a communiqu threatening a new campaign of attacks. The last waves of coordinated attacks took place on 15th August during Ramadan and were claimed by the ISI; in that instance, the group also issued a statement threatening attacks during the Muslim holy month.
On 27 December, ISI issued a statement claiming responsibility. stating the attacks had been in support of Sunnis held in prison, and warning of further attacks against the Shiite government.

attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Two improvised explosive devices (IEDs) detonated consecutively in the Alawi district of Baghdad, causing at least three fatalities and 25 injuries.
The bombs targeted day labourers waiting near a major transportation terminal.
The attack was one of 13 coordinated explosions that struck neighbourhoods across Baghdad during rush hour. At least 60 people were killed and over 200 others wounded. The bombings began at approximately 0630hrs and targeted shops, markets, schools, hospitals and government buildings in Sunni, Shia and mixed sectarian neighbourhoods. The timing of the attack shows they were designed to inflict maximum levels of casualties and disruption.
The bombings occurred five days after US troops withdrew from Iraq and as the country faces a deepening  political crisis. On 19th December, the government issued an arrest warrant for the vice president on charges of terrorism. Tariq al-Hashemi denied the charges, and fled to the semi-autonomous Kurdish Region (KR). The allegations by the Shia prime minister against the Sunni vice president heightened sectarian tension in the country.
On 12th December, the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) - the most active terrorist group in Iraq -  issued a communiqu threatening a new campaign of attacks. The last waves of coordinated attacks took place on 15th August during Ramadan and were claimed by the ISI; in that instance, the group also issued a statement threatening attacks during the Muslim holy month.
On 27 December, ISI issued a statement claiming responsibility. stating the attacks had been in support of Sunnis held in prison, and warning of further attacks against the Shiite government.
source_urls: CanalSur; Wall Street Journal; Aswat al-Iraq

summary:
Suspected Al-Shabaab sympathisers mounted a twin grenade attack in the north eastern town of Garissa. The coordinated attacks injured four people and occurred less than three weeks after a previous grenade attack in the town.
The first incident took place outside a local hotel restaurant 4 kilometers from the town centre, when an unidentified man tried to throw a grenade into a packed dinning hall.  The grenade struck a wall and exploded when it hit the ground. The blast wounded four civilians.
At approximately the same time, a second individual threw a grenade into the staff canteen of a prison facility but the explosion caused no casualties.
In recent week, suspected Al-Shabaab sympathisers have conducteda number of targeted attacks against Kenyan security force personnel. On 16th October, Kenya began a military incursions into Al-Shabaab controlled southern Somalia.

summary:
Sixteen prisoners, including members of AQAP, broke free from prison in the southern Yemeni city of Aden.
Several prisoners broke out of the jail by digging a tunnel, though others appeared to have fought their way out. The AQAP prisoners involved had all been convicted on terrorism charges.
This was the second major prison escape involving AQAP since June, when militants broke free of the prison in Mukalla. The entrenched unrest in the country against President Saleh has seen a deteriorated security situation that has left swathes of the country under the control of Islamist militants, as well as numerous tribal factions.

summary:
A government official and five others were wounded in a roadside bomb as they participated in independence day celebrations in Wajir, northern Kenya.
The wounded official was in charge of the National Security Intelligence Service for the area, when the convoy he was travelling in was targeted. The vehicles had been leaving the local stadium where the independence day events had been  held, when a concealed device detonated causing minor injuries. Four civilians within the vicinity of the blast were also hurt.
One individual was arrested fleeing the scene.
The attack comes in the wake of two earlier incidents that also targeted security personnel in Mandera and Wajir. Since the incursion of Kenyan security personnel into Somalia in order to tackle the Al-Shabaab threat, there has been an escalation of incidents on Kenyan soil. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary:
A leading human rights activist died when armed gunmen shot him in the Gundhai area near Jamrod bazaar in Khyber Agency. Witnesses say that two gunmen rode up to him on a motorcycle, as he was on his way to a school, and opened fire on him.  He was taken to the Jamrod civil hospital but died from his wounds.
Zarteen Khan was the Khyber agency's Human rights commissioner for Pakistan.  His family said that he had received threats because of his opposition to Taliban activities in the tribal areas and for his support for women's rights.
The Abdullah Ezzam brigade, an Islamist militant group based in Pakistan and affiliated with al-Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack. Its former leader, Sheik Abdullah Ezzam was seen as a mentor to Osama bin Laden and was a significant figure in the Soviet war in Afghanistan in the 1980's.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a Shia Muslim shrine in Kabul near the presidential palace. The attack killed 54 people and wounded over 100 others. Hundreds of Shia pilgirms were crowded together when the attack occurred.
A near simultaneous attack happened in Mazar-i-Sharif, and another occurred in Kandahar.
The attacks coincided with the Shia commemoration of Ashura and came a day after Afghanistan's Western allies pledged long-term support in the country once their troops leave in 2014.
Over the past ten years attacks have been ethnically motivated but both attacks appear to be of a sectarian nature unprecedented in recent Afghan history.

summary:
Separatist militants blew up an oil installation in the Dibrugarh district of Assam, sparking a fire that raged over 100metres in height.
The banned United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) claimed responsibility for the attack at the oil collection station in Tipling, that belonged to Oil India Limited, an Indian oil exploration company. The fire was still blazing, though no casualties were thought to have occurred.
ULFA claimed the strike was part of their campaign against the government's exploitation of natural resources. However, a local police chief refuted the claim, saying a spark from two trucks colliding accidentally started the fire.

summary:
A bomb explosion at a market in Al Khalis, Diyala, killed at least 10 people and wounded 25 more.
The car bomb detonated at a popular vegetable market of the mainly Shi'a town. A three-metre diameter crater was left by the explosion, which also left at least ten vehicles charred in the vicinity. A young man was reported to have driven a Kia truck to the market and parked before leaving, ten minutes before the attack occurred.
The blast came as the US Vice-President Biden visited the country to mark the departure of US troops from the country. It highlights the fears of the ability for local forces to continue to provide security, even as the troops began their withdrawal.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Al Jazeera TV; AFP; AGI; Reuters

summary:

According to local police reports, the bomb was concealed on a rickshaw parked close to the gate. Media reports indicate that the explosion at around 1100hrs killed a rickshaw puller, who police suspect was transporting the bomb.
No group claimed responsibility but the authorities blamed Kangleipak Communist Party (KCP) - which seeks to form an independent communist state in Manipur - for the attack.
The explosion took place three days before Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh was due to visit the state.

summary:
A suicide car bomb exploded outside the Al-Hout prison in Taji. The attack killed 19people and wounding at least 15 others.
The blast occurred as prison employees were heading to work to start their shifts. The bomber rammed the car filled with explosives into the main gate of the prison. Amongst the wounded were security personnel, including guards, prison staff and police officers. It remained unclear whether the explosion was part of a prison escape plot.
No group claimed responsibility. The attack, the third significant attack in the week, continues to highlight the question of the ability of local security forces to adequately protect the country, especially in the lead up to the US withdrawal of forces at the end of 2011.
source_urls: BBC News; Al Jazeera; AP; New York Times;

summary:
Al-Shabaab militants stormed the offices of international aid agencies in coordinated raids in southern Somalia and forced the offices to close down. The raids caused no casualties.
Armoured vehicles surrounded the offices of agencies including UNICEF and the WHO, and gunmen forced staff to vacate the premises.
The raids occurred across several locations in the south of Somalia,and were executed in a planned and coordinated manner. Computers, telephones and equipment were seized form the offices.
Al-Shabaabsaid that many of the foreign agencies are working to prevent the establishment of Sharia law in the country.Southern Somalia continues to face an extreme famine situation

summary:

The authorities suspect the bomb was part of a coordinated attack. The second explosion, planned for Basilan island, failed after the authorities found and defused two bombs in Isabela City.

summary:
Two bomb attacks on Isabela City, Basilan were prevented after the police discovered and defused two separate bombs.
One device was recovered near a shop in Mabarakat village, the other from a motorbike in Barangay Aguada. The trigger, battery and shrapnel - nails - were found inside a blue plastic bag.
The attempted attempt was believed to be related to a hotel bomb attack in Zamboanga City that occurred at approximately the same time.
No group claimed responsibility for planting the devices.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed two foreign aid workers from ASCOM and injured another in the Ngozi area of northern Burundi.
A Croatian nun and Italian doctor working for the Italian NGO ASCOM were shot after gunmen cut the electricity supply to Kiremba hospital, and forced the local head of ASCOM to drive them to the a nearby convent. After demanding money from the nuns, they shot a Croatian nun dead, and forced the Italian doctor and an Italian nun to drive them them to Marangara, where they killed the man and wounded the nun.
It was the first targeting of foreign aid workers in the area since 2007. Two high school students aged 20 and 24 were later arrested and convicted of the attacks.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Armed militants attacked a natural gas pipeline in the El-Arish region of Sinai. The pipeline supplies natural gas to both Israel and Jordan.
Three bombs were placed at separate sections of the pipeline to the west of El Arish city. Twin blasts set the gas alight, whilst the third failed to detonate. The flames reached 20 metres in height. A security guard reported that eight masked militants forced him at gunpoint to watch as they laid the devce. He was released unharmed when the attackers fled the scene.
This was the ninth bombing on the pipeline since the Egyptian revolution in February, and the second of the month. El-Arish is the hub of gas exports to both Israel and Jordan, a deal unpopular with the wider public. Export was halted, as was the provision of local services in the wake of the blasts.
No group claimed responsibility.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Xinhua; CBS News; Kuwait News Agency;

attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

The tactics used during this incident is similar to recent Boko Haram attacks in Yobe.

summary:

The incidnet occurred on the same day a major oil and gas conference started in the city.
The incident was the second mass casualty attack in Basra in November. On 2nd November, three motorcycle bombs went off in the city. No group has claimed responsibility for either attack. However, multiple bombings and the targeting of first responders is a tactic commonly employed by the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).

summary:
Seven armed men kidnapped two French nationals from Hombori, northeast Mali.
The two geologists, working for a cement works company, were taken from their hotel. The attack appeared to bear the hallmarks of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM).
It brings the number of French hostages in the Sahel region to six, after four nationals were seized from Niger in 2010. AQIM kidnapped an Italian and two Spaniards from Algeria in October.
No group claimed the attack.
On 15 July 2013, it was confirmed that one of the hostages, Phillipe Verdon, had been killed after his body was found in Northern Mali. Al Qaeda's North African faction claimed responsibility, stating that they had killed Verdon for relatiation for French intervention in Mali.
An unofficial announcement was made in March that Verdon was dead, and in April the media arm of Al Qaeda confirmed this.
source_urls: Xinhua; AFP; BBC News; Expatica.com; News24; Washington Post; BBC

The second also detonated in a toilet, at the Pattani branch of CAT Telecom Plc.
The last device exploded at the compound of the Pattani Labour Development Centre in Rusamilae village.
All devices were homemade, and contained in metal boxes. They were remotely detonated. The explosions came during a night of nine bomb and shooting attacks across five districts in the province. No group claimed responsibility.

summary:
A suicide car bomb exploded after a van refused to stop at a police checkpoint in the south of Karachi at around 2200hrs. Police then pursued the vehicle and after an exchange of fire, the terrorists detonated their explosives in an the affluent Sea View neighbourhood near McDonalds Park. The explosion killed two of the pursuing policemen and the three terrorists.
Police discovered a suicide vest, six hand grenades, five Kalashnikovs, a burqa and women's clothing in the vehicle. The weapons cache suggests the militants were planning a sophisticated attack at another location in the city.
The attackers' intended target is not currently clear, but the incident occurred the night before the start of a three-day Sufi festival. Last year during the celebration, TTP terrorists conducted a double suicide attack outside the Abdullah Shah Ghazi shrine in the city, which killed seven people and injured over 65 others. 
No group claimed responsibility.

The police described the attack as a contract killing.  Ruslan Ahktakhanov was a professor at the Modern Humanitarian Academy and was a strong opponent of the Chechen separatist movement.
No group claimed the attack and the motive behind it was not clear.

summary:

The pipeline was initially excavated to a depth of two meters before the charges were remotely detonated. A smaller bomb was also remotely detonated at the pumping station that then ignited.

summary:
Gunmen killed a member of the transitional federal government of Somaliaoutside his home in Mogadishu.
Local witnesses blamed militants for the killing, and said two men armed with AK-47 rifles shot the parliamentarian in front of his house. Clan militiamen had previously occupied the house by force, until Al-Shabaab pulled out of the city, and the MP ordered security forces to evict the militia.
The killing came a day after an Al-Shabaab grenade attack killed at least two people in the city. Al-Shabaab had promised to increased attacks in the city, despite fighting continuing against Kenyan troops in the south of the country.

summary:
A large group of Taliban militants attacked an ISAF base in the Barmal District, Paktika Province, using small arms and rocket-propelled grenades.
The attack resulted in a clash between the Taliban and ISAF forces, who reported that significant casualties occurred among the insurgents. A spokesperson for the Paktika governor put the number of Taliban militants killed to about 50. No casualties were reported from the ISAF forces.
Paktika province lies on the border with the Pakistani tribal area of North Waziristan, where the Taliban and allied insurgents like the Haqqani network have safe havens from which they launch attacks into Afghanistan.

summary:

The TTP,who oppose non-Islamic education in the country,have destroyed at least 12 other schools in Mardan.

summary:
Militants detonated a bomb at a girls' school in Derai, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, causing material destruction. No casualties were incurred in the blast.
The school had recently been upgraded from a middle- to high-school for girls, and was the only high-school for girls in the area. 8-10kg of explosive material were set off by an outer wall in the middle of the night. Three of the five rooms were destroyed, and the remaining two badly damaged.
Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants have banned education for girls in the area, and have repeatedly targeted institutions and people who have defied them on this. Twelve schools have been destroyed in Mardan district alone.

summary:

According to local reports, suicide bombers driving a black SUV attempted to enter the base, but was prevented by security guards. The terrorist then detonated his explosives, which damaged several buildings in the military compound, and injured one soldier and six civilians.
A local policeman said that there were three other failed suicide attacks near to the base, but reportedly there were no casualties from these explosions.
No group has claimed responsibility for the incident, but the tactics and target choice strongly suggest that Boko Haram was responsible.

summary:
Boko Haram terrorists conducted a series of co-ordinated attacks in Damaturu. Yobe, throughout the evening.
In the first attack, a car bomb exploded outside a building which is used as a military office. The explosion injured an undisclosed number of soldiers.
An unknown number of terrorists then staged attacks across the city. They destroyed a First Bank PLC branch in the centre of the city and then attacked at least three police stations and two churches in different locations.
Terrorists then fired at police and military troops throughout the evening.
A Red Cross spokesman said that at least 63 people died and over 100 others were injured during the attacks.
A spokesman for Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the incidents, which are connected to the attacks earlier in the day in Maidiguri.
source_urls: BBC, New York Times, Washington Post, AP
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Boko Haram, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

Minutes later a car bomb exploded in a garage outside the base as Iraqi Security officials arrived at the scene of the first blast. The two explosions killed ten people and injured 25. Most of the casualties were members of the Awakening Council and security officers.
No group claimed responsibility, however the method and targets suggest Al-Qaeda in Iraq could be responsible.

summary:
Twin bomb exploded in the central commercial Karadah district of Baghdad and killed at least four people and wounded eight others.
An improvised explosive device struck a police patrol vehicle near the Lebanese Club in the Mesbah neighbourhood of outer Karrada. One police officer was killed, and four wounded.
The second explosion occurred in the Al-Wathiq Square in northern Karadah. Three civilians were killed and four more injured.
No group claimed responsibility.
Attacks have continued to occur across the country on an almost daily basis, maintaining concerns about local security provision in the face of US troop withdrawal at the end of 2011.

summary:
A suicide attack on a private logistics company close to the ISAF logistics office near Herat airport killed two Afghan guards and wounded four. The attack initiated with two car bomb explosions, before armed militants stormed the offices and a gunfight broke out.
The attack took place at the offices of Monaco-based international firm ES-KO, a contractor for Italian troop services. Two suicide car bombs exploded by gates number one and two of the office, and three militants were then shot in the firing. All five attackers were reported to have been wearing Afghan army uniforms in the attack.
No group claimed responsibility, but attacks on contractors working with ISAF forces are common in Afghanistan. Security control of the city was handed over to local forces in July 2011. Earlier in the week, a Taliban attack in Kandahar killed five, including UNHCR workers.

summary:
Militants remotely detonated a homemade device in the Ra-ngae district of Narathiwat province. The explosion killed six people and injured two.
The seven civilian occupants of a pick-up truck were returning from a hunt when the device exploded. Investigators reported that militants hidden in the trees opened fire with machine guns after the explosion. As a rescuer went to attend to the site, he was also injured when he stepped on a landmine.
Earlier in the day security forces had defused another homemade bomb hidden inside a PVC pipe, on a road used by teachers in the same district. The bomb had been discovered near the village entrance during a security search.
No group claimed responsibility, however Muslim separatist insurgents have been blamed for the escalation of violence in Narathiwat in recent months.

summary:
A bomb in a garbage container exploded outside of a regional government building in the western Kazakh city of Atyrau close to the Caspian Sea. No casualties were reported.
In a separate but possibly linked event about an hour later an explosion in a residential building occurred 400m away from the first explosion. The explosion was reportedly caused by a suicide bomber whose vest detonated prematurely.
The events are the first terrorism related incidents in the region as previous events have mostly been confined to the Aktobe region in central Kazakhstan.
A day later, the little-known group called the Kateeba Jund al Khilafah (the Brigade of the Soldiers of the Caliphate) claimed responsibility for the attacks. Earlier, the group released a videotape on 26th October in which its members threaten the government of Kazakhstan if it fails to retract a law banning women from wearing the veil.
source_urls: Ria Novosti,; The Long War Journal

summary:

The gunman reportedly opened fire from a bus stop outside the front of the embassy. He was shot and wounded by security personnel before being arrested. Initial reports suggested he was a jihadist.
Police continued to search the area for potential accomplices. The embassy had been closed briefly in March 2002 following a threat, but had not previously been attacked.

summary:
A car bomb explosion in the centre of Aden killed a senior police commander and wounded three others, including two children.
The device was remotely detonated in the Kour Maksar district, and an official reported that the attack bore the hallmarks of Al-Qaeda in the Arabain Peninsula (AQAP). Despite a government crackdown, the southern Yemen region has seen vigorous AQAP activity in the preceding nine months, and the car bomb is the latest in a series of attacks targeting high-level security personnel.
AQAP made no comment on the attack.

summary:
An improvised explosive device (IED) detonated outside a restaurant in downtown Cotabato City, wounding a policeman.
The device was found on Sinsuat Avenue, and police were dispatched to cordon off the area, when the IED unexpectedly detonated.
The explosion coincided with a visit by senior government officials to Zamboanga in the wake of a series of bomb attacks and clashes with rebels. The attack in Cotabatooccurred two days after another device explodedSangali, killing a person and wounding eight others.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Suspected Al-Shabaab terrorists bombed a Kenyan security vehicle on a road that leads to the Dadaab refugee complex in Kenya's North Eastern Province. The explosion wounded four security guards.
An eyewitness said the perpetrators were  monitoring the paramilitary General Service unit (GSU) vehicle as it headed towards the camp. The vehicle was in a convoy of four.Unconfirmed reports suggest it hit a landmine.
The country has been on high alert in the wake of threats made by Al-Shabaab, following Kenya's military incursion into Somalia to target the group 13 days ago. The incident is the fourth attack on Kenyan territory within a week.
Al-Shabaab made no comment on the attack.

summary:
Two consecutive blasts on the Pakistan side of Torkham border crossing destroyed four NATO armoured vehicles aboard two trailers. No casualties were incurred in the explosions.
The Afghanistan-bounded trailers were transporting armoured vehicles for ISAF forces and were parked in a carpark near the border. An explosive device within one of the containers detonated, which then set alight the vehicles. The Afghanistan-Pakistan highway was closed for an hour following the blasts.
No group claimed responsibility, but the Taliban frequently target logistics convoys carrying material for ISAF troops, in order to disrupt the international combat mission.

summary:
A Taliban attack lasting four hours on a civil-military housing base for a provincial reconstruction team (PRT) in Kandahar killed one and wounded eight other people.
The insurgents were armed with RPGs, automatic weapons and explosives, and initially opened fire from an empty building near to the compound. Two car bombs were also safely detonated during the course of the siege, without incurring any casualties. Senior officials including provincial leaders were at the base at the time of the attack for a meeting.
Four of the insurgents died in the attack, as did an Afghan national interpreter. One American civilian contractor, two Afghan security guards and five ISAF soldiers were among the wounded.
The Taliban claimed responsibility, adding that suicide attackers were taking part and the provincial governor was a target of the attack. They frequently target western forces in Afghanistan, and the attack comes a day after the Taliban destroyed a fuel truck in Bagram.
source_urls: IBN, The NewsTribe; AFP; WarBlog; BBC Monitoring; Afghan Islamic Press
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Omar Abdullah, the chief minister of Kashmir, announced the previous week that emergency laws imposed in 1990 allowing security forces to act with near-impunity were to be partially withdrawn as security improves. There were speculations that the sudden spike in attacks could be linked to this.

summary:

summary:
Six Ugandan peacekeepers died when a roadside bomb exploded in the Karaan district of Mogadishu. The incident followed an offensive on 8th October by government and AMISOM troops into areas of the capital controlled by Al-Shabaab.

Al-Shabaab continues to remain a significant threat to the Transitional Federal Government and African Union peacekeepers even though it vacated many parts of Mogadishu on 6th August.

summary:
At around 12:00, four Taliban militants attempted to assassinate the governor of Patakia province in Gardez city, east Afghanistan.
The first assailant detinated his VBIED and killed on civilian as the governor's motorcade passed by. Then the other three attackers opened fire but died in the ensuing gunfight. A conflicting account maintains that the militants tried to enter the Gardez town hall, and left the car just before it exploded, but that they were killed by security forces.
As soon as the attack happened, a Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for it, saying that "Self-sacrificing mojahedin have entered Gardez city and the fighting is continuing, but that I have no other details now."

summary:
Militants fired a RPG at a gas pipeline in Al-Hadhina, in the Shabwa governorate. The pipelinetransportsgas fromMarib to the port of Belhaf (Gulf of Aden).
The explosion occured at 12:30 and caused no casualties.
Yemen's natural gas exporter Yemen LNG said that it had had to halt production after the attack, but that 'the loss of production is expected to be limited as the LNG plant was due to shut down on Oct. 23 for annual maintenance'.
No one claimed responsibility for the attack. But both AQAP militants and anti-government tribes are potential suspects.
The attack came on the same day that a US strike killed AQAP's media chief in Shabwa, a week after killing Anwar al-Awlaki. A Yemeni official said the attack was likely in retaliation. But anti-government tribes have also attacked the pipelines. In March the Al-Shabwan tribe attacked the pipeline carrying oil from Marib to Ras Eisa.Seven people died in fighting during protests in Sanaa on the same day.

summary:
Gunmen kidnapped two female Spanish aid workers from the Dadaab refugee camp near Somalia's border. They shot the driver of the vehicle they were travelling in.
Local police officials said Al-Shabaab was responsible although there was no claim of responsibility from the Somalia-based Islamist militant group. Following this incident, the Kenyan authorities immediately closed the border with Somalia and launched a search operation.
On 1st October, the UK Foreign Officechanged its travel advice for Britons visiting Kenya. It warned against all but essential travel to coastal areas within 150km (93 miles) of the Somali border instead of the previous 60km limit. The warning followedan incident on 11th September, when gunmen killed a British tourist and abducted his wife in the resort of Kiwayu. Then, on 1st October, gunmen seized a French tourist from the island of Manda and took her as well to Somalia.

specific_target: Police station; police patrol; army patrol
summary:
A wave of car bombs exploded across Baghdad on 12th October. At least 28 people were killed and 59 injured as five blasts took place within minutes across the city.
The first explosion occurred in the centre of the city outside a police station in the Al-Alwiyah district of Karrada at 0820hrs. Terrorists rammed an explosive-laden car into the entrance of the station, killing 13 people, including four policeman and a civilian. Six people were also wounded.
Almost simultaneously, a second suicide bomber drove his car into a checkpoint of a police station in the mainly Shia, northwestern district of Al-Hurriyah. Nine people, including three policemen and three civilians were killed, and 10 people wounded.
A roadside bomb targeting an army convoy of the commander of 22 Brigade detonated in the same area. The explosion killed a civilian and wounded 10 soldiers and two civilians.
A car bomb parked outside a police station in the southwestern district of Ilaam caused the third explosion that left three civilians dead.
A roadside bomb also detonated in the western Shia Washash district, targeting a police patrol. Two policemen were killed and a further seven injured.
The attacks continue to highlight the concerns of local security provision, in the lead-up to the US withdrawal of forces by the end of the year. The explosion in Al-Hurriyah is notable given that it is the stronghold of the Shia cleric Muqtada al-Sadr. The area is surrounded by blast walls, and entrance is extremely restricted - there are only four access points and all are manned by the Iraqi army.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, however, a military spokesman for the city blamed the Islamic State of Iraq.
source_urls: ESISC; Xinhua; AP; Reuters; Al Jazeera; Dawn
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A group of unidentified militants abducted the 10-year-old daughter of the mayor of Fortul, a village in the north-eastern Colombia, close to the border with Venezuela. The girl was walking along a Fortul street with her mother in the early morning when a vehicle approached and men forced the two into the car. The group later abandoned the mother in the vehicle outside of the village.
No group claimed responsibility and no ransom demands were immediately made. FARC is known to operate in the areas, and has historically use kidnapping as a tactic to obtain funds, however on 13th October the group released a statement denying involvement. The ELN released a similar statement denying any involvement on 17 October. Colombian police have blamed the FARC due to recordings discovered in the investigation.
The girl was released on the evening of 17 october and picked up by the Red Cross close to the Venezuelan border about 30 miles away from where she was originally abducted.
perpetrators: Colombia:Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC):Far Left/Revolutionary

The attack on two containers at a container terminal on the route ended with a container loaded with military jeeps bound for US and NATO forces in Afghanistan erupting in flames. Local tribal police who responded to the scene exchange gunfire with the militants, forcing them to flee.
No responsibility was claimed, but military supplies are often the focus of Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) attacks, as a means of disrupting the ongoing ISAF campaign.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Associated Press of Pakistan
author: Unknown author

The authorities sent more security personnel to the area following the incident.

summary:
A car bomb explosion in Dagestan killed a policeman and seven civilians. The bomb wounded six other policemen.
The explosion in the village of Karamakhi occurred as the policemen attempted to check a suspicious car. The area had been cordoned off as police went to check the car. A second vehicle broke through the cordon as the explosion occurred, killing the three occupants of the car.
No group claimed responsibility. A wave of fatal attacks has swept the republic in recent weeks, including twin bomb blasts in the centre of the capital.

summary:
A suicide car bomb attack outside a bakery popular with policemen killed five people and injured 26 others in Lashkar Gah. The blast targeted a police truck that stopped at the bakery.
The bakery supplied food to the Afghan National Army, and was located near the police headquarters in the city. The dead included two policemen and three civilians, and six children were among the injured. The strength of the blast shattered windows of buildings and vehicles in the vicinity.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack. Lashkar Gah is one of several areas where security has been handed over from NATO to Afghan security forces. Suck attacks continue to highlight the uncertainty of national forces to provide adequate security in the country.

summary: Two White supremacists, identified as Holly Grisby and David Pedersen, killed four people in three US states on the West Coast, between 26 September and 5 October. The pair first killed two individuals in Everett, Washington, on 26 September. In the next days, the attackers killed a 19-year-old in Oregon and a 53-year old man in Northern California. According to US media outlets, both suspects were arrested near Yuba City, while they were on their way to Sacramento. At the time of writing, no group had claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Local officials reported that a group of Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) militants attacked a military outpost in the Pervari District at around 18:00hrs. The militants fired automatic weapons and rocket launchers at the post, and Turkish soldiers returned fire. Six soldiers were killed and 11 injured in the attack. Three of the assailants were also killed. The Turkish media reported that the militants planed mines along the road leading to the outpost to prevent assistance reaching the soldiers.
The PKK typically aims its attacks at Turkish government official and the military. The group is most active in Turkey's southwest, where this incident took place. PKK attacks increased in the aftermath of parliamentary elections in June 2011, in a bid to force the government to formalise greater social and political rights for the Kurdish minorityin a constitution that will be drafted by the new parliament.

summary:
Four consecutive bombings, including at least one car bomb, killed at least nine people and wounded 90 more outside a government office in Karbala. The first explosion took place at around 9:30, when militants detonated a car packed with explosives. A second explosion went off several minutes later. The second two explosions followed about 20 minutes later when security forces and medical personal arrived on the scene.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but it bears many of the hallmarks of the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI). The group often stages attacks, particularly car bombings, outside government buildings. The tactic of setting off a second set of explosions as security forces arrive is also a common ISI tactic.

A member of the group Jemaah Ansharut Tauhid (JAT) carried out a suicide bomb attack in the Church of Bethel Injil in Solo City, that killed two persons and injured 27 others.
The attack took place at around 10:55 inside the church in an apparent attempt to maximise casualties.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but police investigating the attack identified the bomber through DNA testing as Ahmad Yosepa Hayat, a known member of JAT. Hayat is known to have accompanied a suicide bomber to an attack on a police mosque in Cirebon and was wanted in connection with this attack by police.

summary:

The first car bomb exploded at 00:30 but caused no casualties. Policemen responding to the scene were then caught in a second blast that occurred 15 minutes later. The bombs were estimated to have the power equivalent of at least 35kg of TNT. Buildings in the immediate vicinity were damaged.
The attacks come just hours after an earlier blast in the city that killed at least four people. No group claimed responsibility, but the authorities have blamed the Imarat Kavkaz. A senior leader of the group waskilledin a counter-terrorism operation on 18 September.

summary:
Ten Taliban militants attacked the British and American embassies, NATO-ISAF headquarters and several government buildings in a complex and sophisticated attack in Kabul. The assailants were armed with automatic weapons, rocket-propelled grenades and suicide vests. At least four of the assailants detonated their vests during the attack, which lasted 20 hours and killed four policeman and two civilians.
The attack started at 13:30 inAbdul Haq Square, when gunmen dressed in burqas killed a police officer at a checkpoint. The terrorists then separated into teams and targeted four different locations.
Seven militants occupied and fired from a half-built downtown building that overlooked the US Embassy and several government buildings in Kabul's diplomatic district. According to reports the men had smuggled a large quantity of weapons into the building over the previous three days.US and Afghan helicopters fired on the building. It took 20 hours to kill the last gunman.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, but US officials believe the Taliban-affiliated Haqqani network was responsible.The Haqqanis are based in Pakistan's North Waziristan and have staged a series of deadly raids and suicide attacks against high profile and well-guarded targets in Afghanistan in recent years.

summary:
Shortly after midnight on 10 September, unidentified gunmen with suspected links to Al-Shabaab killed a British national and kidnapped another from a luxury beach cottage resort on the coast of Kenya, 45km from the Somali border.
The British couple were staying at the Kiwayu Safari Village when the attack took place. Local witnesses claim up to six militants entered the couples room - a hut on the shoreline- shortly after midnight. They shot and killed the British man and took his wife hostage. The militants fled the scene by boat and headed north towards Somalia. 
Kenyan police were placed on high alert and cordoned off the area, while a British investigation team arrived in the country to assist in the investigation. According to report the Ras Komboni militia, a Somali based militant group affiliated to Al-Shabaab, claimed responsibility for the high profile attack. The group claimed the kidnapping was in retaliation for US drone strikes and there is speculation it will use the victim as a bargaining asset to secure the release of fellow militants held by Somali Authorities.
A conflicting report in Reuters quotes a senior Al-Shabaab member denying the group's involvement in any kidnapping. But Al-Shabaab are suspected of bombing attacks in Mandera on the northern border with Somalia in June and July. 
No ransom demand has yet been issued.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Shabaab, perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
At approximately 10:17, a bomb exploded outside the main entrance to the Delhi High Court. The blast killed 10 people and wounded over 65 others. The incident occurred less than two months after a series of bombs in Mumbai killed 26 people.
The bomb was concealed in a briefcase outside Gate No.5 and created a 3-4 foot deep crater. Over 100 people were queuing close to the device, waiting to gain entry to the court. The explosion mirrored an outside Gate No. 7 of Delhi High Court onattack on 25 May.
The High Court is located in the heart of Delhiclose to India's Parliament and the Prime Minister's office. Both the capital and Mumbai were placed on high alert following the attack. Eye-witnesses claimed that the scanner and metal detector at Gate No. 5 were not working when the blast occurred.
Harakat-ul-Jihad Islami (HUJI) claimed responsibility for the attack, and send an email to media agencies which said:'We own the responsibility for today's blasts at Delhi high court. Our demand is that Mohammed Afzal Guru's death sentence should be repealed immediately else we would target major high courts and the Supreme Court of India.'
Indian officials said they had no prior intelligence about the attack.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Harakat-ul-Jihad-aI-Islami (HUJI), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A twin suicide attack at the residence of a military official in Quetta killed at least 24 people and wounded 82 others. At 08:58, the first suicide bomberdetonated an explosive laden vehicle near the residence of thecity's Frontier Corps chief, which wounded the official and killed his wife. Less than five minutes later, the second bomber, after throwing grenades at the police, entered the house and detonated his explosive vest. Police said the force of the explosions was so great windows of dozens of buildings shattered, and walls of the official's house and nearby offices fell down. The death toll is expected to rise.
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed the attack and said it targeted the city's Frontier Corps chief to avenge thekilling of five Chechens in May by Pakistani forces in Quetta's Khrotabad area.
The attack occurred two days after the Frontier Corps took part in an operation that caught three senior Al-Qaeda members in the city, includingYounis al-Mauritani who Pakistani army officials claim had plotted attacks against the United States, Europe and Australia.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Associated Press of Pakistan; Dawn.com; AP; Reuters; AFP; Pakistan Today
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

The children aged between 12 and 18 accidentally crossed from the Bajaur Agency border when militants took them hastage. A grand jerga (Council of Tribal Elders) convenec to secure the release of the children.
A local Urdu TV channel, GeoTV, reports that Tehrik-e-Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident.It is not the first mass kidnap of Pakistani boys from the tribal belt. In June 2009 students travelling in a convoy were kidnapped from North Waziristan, and released a few days later.
Eight of the youths had been released in the following weeks. The remaining 17 boys were unconditionally released 5 January 2012.

summary:
Security forces today thwarted a bomb attack against the Egyptian gas company Gasco in Al-Arish, the capital of North Sinai.
The pipeline, which supplies Egyptian gas to Israel, has been subject to five successful and two failed attacks since Mubarak left power. Egyptians have been holding anti-Israel protests in Cairo for two weeks, calling for the cancellation of the controversial Mubarak-era gas deal that supplied Israel at below market prices.
No group has ever claimed responsibility for the previous attacks against the pipeline, but most indications suggest jihadist groups comprising Egyptians and Palestinians conducted them. The groups are operating in North Sinai and may have been trained in Gaza. Israel suspects members of the same groups of having crossed into southern Israel to attack security forces in Eilat on 18th August.

summary:
A suicide car bomb blast at a police checkpoint in Paizo killed at least five people and injured thirty-five more, mostly civilians.
A car laden with heavy explosives detonated at the police station, after police officers requested the vehicle to halt at a checkpoint.  Security personnel opened fire when the driver refused to stop, and the driver detonated his explosives. Half of the police station was levelled to the ground. Shops and other buildings in the vicinity were damaged by the blast. A police cheif reported that the subsequent collapse of the buildings caused the fatalities.
The explosion came at the Eid al-Fitr festivities in the Muslim world drew to a close. It is the second attack during the period in the country - two days prior a suicide car bomb detonated in Quetta killing 11. Lakki Marwat district borders South Waziristan, a militant stronghold. No responsibility was claimed, but the Tehrik e-Taliban have frequently used car bombs targeting security personnel.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring; Geo News TV; AFP; Xinhua;

summary:
Three suicide bomber explosions killed six police officers and two civilians, and injured twenty-two more, in successive attacks in Grozny.
The first bomber is reported to have detonated his device at an identity checkpoint near the Parliament building. Two policemen were killed in the initial blast. Thirty minutes later two more explosions occurred at the same place after emergency services and police responded to the first explosion.
Security sources reported that one of the bombers had been the brother of the terrorist who attempted to kill Chechen President Kadyrov in June 2010. Kadyrov famously announced in 2009 that 'the nest of terrorism has been crushed' in Chechnya.
The attacks came as the celebrations for Eid al-Fitr began, marking the end of Ramadan.
No group claimed responsibility.

summary:
A Palestinian launched a knife attack on club goers in Tel Avivduring the early hours of Monday 29 August. Israeli authorities claim the attack was an act of terrorism. 
According to reports, a Palestinian man from the West Bank hijacked a taxi and injured several citizens and security personnel when he rammed the vehicle intoa police checkpoint at the entrance to Haoman 17, a popular nightclub in the Florentine area of the city. He then left the vehicle and stabbed several people near by with a knife. In total, the attack left eight injured.
Police arrested the perpetrator at the scene. Theyclaim the intended target was the 2,000 young people gathered in the club and that the man was acting out of nationalist motives. 
The unusual attack comes after heightened border tension between Israel and the Gaza Strip, where Isrealiauthoritieshave launched multiple airstrikes in retaliation for militant rocket attacks over the last two weeks.

After repeatedly ignoring warning shots, naval forces fired on the craft sinking it with its occupants on board.Divers are reportedly searching for the sunken boat to check its contents.
No group has claimed responsibility for the incident, which bears similarities in tactics to the October 2000 attack against the USS Cole in Aden harbour which killed 17 US sailors and wounded 40 others. Al-Qaeda claimed responsibility for that attack.
AQAP's take over of southern cities in May and subsequent activity along the Abyan coast has raised concerns in the international community of a growing threat of a maritime terrorist attack in the shipping lanes of the Gulf of Aden and Bab-el-Mandeb strait.

No group claimed responsibility, but the authorities suspect the Taliban was responsible.

On the same day a car bomb exploded outside a bank in Lashkar Gah, Helmand province, as workers were collecting salaries.  No group claimed responsibility, but the authorities suspect the Taliban was responsible.

summary:
On 27 August, the Taliban staged its latest cross-border raid into Pakistan, killing 25 Pakistani troops and 10 border police officers at seven paramilitary Frontier Corps check posts in Chitral, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.  The authorities said the coordinated attacks began in the village of Arandu. Several hundred militants then attacked more locations near the Afghan-Pakistan border.
The Pakistani military said the militants believed to have co-ordinated the raid had fled into Afghanistan following Pakistani military offensives.
In recent months the Taliban has launched a series of attacks against Pakistani military positions.  The cross-border incidents have raised tensions between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

summary:
Unidentified militants opened fire on two NATO oil tankers in the Mithri area of Bolan District in Balochistan. The two oil tankers were carrying fuel from Karachi to Kandahar when armed men on motorcycles fired on them on the National Highway near Mithri.
The tankers caught fire but caused no casualties.
Both the TTP and Baloch separatist groups regularly target and attack NATO tankers.

summary:
A car bomb explosion outside a branch of Bank of Kabul in Lashkar Gah, Helmand province, killed four civilians and wounded 20 other people, including 10 soldiers and six police officers. Terrorists detonated the bomb as soldiers and police officers lined up to collect their salaries.  The explosion took place approximately 50 meters from the office of the Provincial Governor.
No group claimed the attack. Less than three hours later, a car bomb exploded outside Kandahar's main hospital, and a suicide bomber detonated his explosive laden vehicle near a police compound in the city.
Officials suspect the Taliban was responsible for the series of attacks.

On 17 July, the Shia militia group linked to the Jaish al-Mahdi (JAM),Kataib Hizbolah, issued a communiquon its website warning Kuwait of potential reprisal attacks if it continued to construct the Mubarak port.
However, Iraqi officials claim the target was the former US prison camp Bucca and the rockets did not strike the border area. Neither source reported any casualties.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
On 26 August, Malay-Muslim separatist staged a multi phased attack on Thai security forces in Rosoe, Narathiwat. At around 07:30 village forces responded to reports that militants killed a rubber plantation owner inRueso. As they approached the scene a road side bomb struck their vehicle. The explosion killed five and injured another.
No group claimed responsibility. Security forces suspect that the National revolutionary Front -Cordinate carried out two attacks in the region earlier that day. A resurgentMalay-Muslim insurgency began in 2004 and latest statistic put the casualty figures at over 12,000.

Local police attributed the attack to the Runda Kampulan Kecil group, an elite unit of the National Revolutionary Front-Cordinate (BRN-C). The BRN-C is the most active Malay-Muslim insurgent group operating in the provinces of Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat.

Local sources report that the attack began at 16:00 and lasted for two hours.Authorities claim that retaliatory fire killed a NPA member and injured an unknown number.
The New People's Army was engaged in peace talks with the Filipino government but recently stepped up its operational tempo. The group continue to hold captive a town mayor kidnapped on 6 August from Surgiao del Sur. On 8 August NPA militants opened fire on a soldier in Albay.

summary:
Two suicide bombers attacked the Cherchell military academy, 100km west of Algiers, in an evening attack. At least 18 people were killed and dozens more were wounded.
The attack reportedly took place soon after iftar, when Muslims break their daily fast during the holy month of Ramadan. The attack began when a bomb exploded just outside the entrance of the academy. Soldiers reportedly rushed outside and when a crowd formed another suicide bomber, with explosives strapped to his body, drove his motorcycle at them.
On the 29 August AQIM claimed responsibility for the attacks. The attack occurred 12 days after an AQIM suicide car bombing of a police station in Tizi Ouzu wounded 29 people. AQIM has dramatically increased both the frequency and lethality of its attacks since the start of Ramadan.

summary:
Boko Haram staged its most elaborate attack in its operational history targeting the UN headquarters in Abujaon Friday 26 August.
At 11:00, a Boko Haram militant drove a car bomb into the UN building near Independence Avenue in the diplomatic quarter of the city.
The suicide bomber rammed the explosive-laden SUV through two security barriers and struck the reception area of the building. The attack caused 23 fatalities and wounded 82 people. Up to 400 UN staff (from UNDP, UNICEF and UN Population Fund) and other NGO workers were in the building at the time of the attack.
Boko Haram claimed responsibility for the bombing in a phone call to the BBC Hausa service five hours later. On 16 June it staged its first suicide attack when it targeted the national police headquarters, also in the capital. It attempted another on 15 August in Maiduguri, Borno State. Police thwarted the attack as the suicide bomber attempted to ram a vehicle into thepolice headquarters.
Nigerian secret police (SSS) have since revealed that two members of Boko Harma arrested in conjunction with the attacks had been detained the week prior to the attack at a military base. The SSS indicated that on 18 August they had received intelligence about a possible car bomb attack in Abuja. It calls into question anti-terrorism measures implemented in the city.
The SSS also confirmed a third suspect is sought, who may have ties to Somalia-based Al Shabaab.
source_urls: AP; ESISC; BBC News; Reuters Africa;
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Boko Haram, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

The minibus, identified with civilian license plates, was transporting military personnel of the Hakkari Mountain and Commando Brigade Command. The road was closed while a second possible improvised explosive device (IED) was searched for.
No group claimed responsibility, but the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) is suspected after an intensification of attacks on military targets in rcenet weeks. The Turkish Air Force replied by conducing an extensive air raid campaign against the group's positions in northern Iraq.

summary:
Two unidentified men detonated an improvised explosive device (IED) at an elementary school in Panabo City. The explosion caused no casualties but slightly damaged the building.
The IED exploded behind the school stage in the early hours of the morning. Witnesses reported two men running towards a banana plantation after laying the IED. Police and the army recovered 50m of electrical wire and four sharpened bamboo 'suyaks' (spikes) from the site of the explosion.
No group claimed responsibility, but the southern Philippines is home to separatist Islamist groups and IED attacks are not uncommon.

summary:
Twin grenade attacks in Kashmir killed two and injured thirteen people in the north Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.
The first grenade was thrown at Border Security Force (BSF) personnel at the Jhelum Market in Baramulla, 55km from Srinagar. The blast injured two civilians and two BSF officers. A civilian and an officer later died from their injuries.
Three hours later a second grenade was through at a Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) vehicle, but missed, detonating by the roadside in the Batamaloo area. Eleven people were injured in the second blast.
No responsibility was claimed.

summary:
An explosion at a hotel killed at least 12 people and wounded 17 in the Nowshera  district. Many of the injured were in a critical condition and the death toll was expected to rise.
A remotely-detonated bicycle bomb exploded in front of the Decent hotel, where several armed forces personnel from the nearby Risalpur garrison were breaking their Ramadan fast with Iftar dinner. Bomb Disposal personnel stated eight kilogrammes of explosive had been used, which destroyed the hotel front and damaged nearby shops.
No responsibility was claimed, but the Al Qaeda-affiliate Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan (TTP) have escalated their attacks in the wake of the death of Osama Bin Laden in May.

summary:

The raid comes immediately after insurgents targeted the local police station, thereby preventing police from responding to the bank robberies. It is not the first time two near-simultaneous attacks have been carried out.
Local authorities have attributed to the attacks to Boko Haram. This is significant both for being the first of this type of attack by the group, and also for demonstrating their reach outside of the limits of the Borno state.

summary:
Gaza-based militants fired 19 mortars and rockets into southern Israel on 24 August, according to the Israeli military.
The barrage wounded two people and Israel'sIron Dome anti-missile system reportedly shot down several of the long-range GRAD missiles fired at Beersheva and Ashkelon. Other rockets did penetrate into the cities.
The rocket-fire continues to threaten the truce agreed between Israel and Hamas at the start of the week, following the escalation of violence started by an attack that left eight Israelis dead near Eilat on 18 August.
Islamic Jihad claimed the latest round of rocket-fire, in retaliation for the killings of its leaders by Israeli missile fire the previous day.

summary:
In attack planned to coincide with the anniversary of Afghan independence from Britain, suspected Taliban suicide attackers stormed a British Council office in Kabul at dawn on 19 August. The attackers seized the building, killed at least nine and engaged in a six hour fire fight with British, New Zealand and Afghan forces. 
The elaboratefidayeen style attack took place in three phases. At approximately 05:30, a bomber detonated an explosive belt at a main intersection in west Kabul. Ten minutes later, a suicide bomber detonated a car bomb outside the front gate of the British Council. 
Local witnesses report up to nine attackers with RPGs, automatic weapons and heavy machine guns then stormed the entrance of the building. Police sources noted that the attackers had enough ammunition and supplies to last for days.
The ensuing fire fight, militants seized control of the building, killed at least five security guards and injured five others.Afghan police reinforcements, as well as British soldiers and New Zealand Special Forces arrived at the scene shortly after and cordoned off the area. In six hours of further fighting, which included further explosons, the attackers killed a three Afghan officers and a New Zealand soldier. All of the attackers either detonated suicide belts or died during the gun fight. 
Four of the councils employees were trapped in a safe room inside the building until Isaf forces secured the area. The British Foreign Office confirmed that all British nationals were eventually saved, but the final number of casualties remains unknown.
The attack coincided with AfghanIndependence Day, which celebrates Afghan succession from British rule in 1919. ATaliban spokesperson immediately claimed responsibility for the attack on the group's website, saying the it was a 'signal for the British and their allies on the Independence Day that invading forces are doomed to destruction'. 
However, the sophistication and pattern of the attack suggests the involvement of the Haqqani network. In recent months this insurgent faction has demonstrated its capability to strike the capital.
On 28 June, Haqqani linked militants launched a similar fidayeen style attack on the Inter-Continental Kabul hotel. Combining suicide bombs with heavy weaponry, it killed 21, injured almost as many, and held back Isaf forces for six hours.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

The attacks followed Israeli Defence Forces' (IDF) retaliatory strikes on targets in the Gaza Strip in the wake of a series of terrorist attacks in southern Israel earlier that day.

summary:
Gunmen conducted a series of consecutive attacks against passenger buses, private cars and the security forces on 18 August, 30km north of the southern city of Eilat. The first attack occured ar 12:00 when three men opened fire on Egged bus No. 392 traveling on Highway 12 between Eilat and Mitzpe Ramon. The terrorists were armed with assault rifles, roadside bombs and one wore a suicide vest. The attack wounded 10 passengers - both IDF soldiers and civilians.
Twenty minutes later, one of the militants opened fire on an empty bus as it drove past and then detonated an explosive vest which killed him and the bus driver. Another assailant then opened fire on two passing cars and killed five civilians. He then launched an RPG at an IDF helicopter overhead, but missed.
An IDF patrol car arrived at the scene and was struck by a roadside bomb. The two assailants still on the highway opened fire and killed one of the IDF soldiers. One of the assailants also fired an RPG at an IDF helicopter, but missed. Both were then killed in an exchange of crossfire.
Israeli police briefly crossed into Egyptian territory where they pursued and killed two militants on the Egyptian side of the border.The Israeli press reported that the IDF believes the assailants planned to kidnap an IDF soldier and civilian and hold them captive in the Gaza Strip.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Less than two hours after the attack, Breivikopened fire at a Labour Party youth conference in Oslo. summary:
A gunman opened fire on participants in a Labour Party youth conference on the island of Utya, Hole municipality, and killed 69 people and injured at least 110 others. The shooting came less than two hours after a major bombing outside government buildings in the Norwegian capital, and was part of a coordinated attack.
The gunman, Anders Behring Breivik, was dressed in a police uniform and travelled to the island on a ferry after conducting the bombing in Oslo. Witnesses said he approached the camp and asked participants to gather in a central location. He then opened fire, shooting indiscriminately into the crowd. He was carrying a handgun, automatic weapon and a shotgun. Victims began to run into surrounding woods and tried to swim away from the island.
Police officers were deployed to the island, but it remains unclear how the man was captured. Police later found undetonated explosives on the island. On the same day as the attack, Breivik distributed a manifesto called'2083: A European Declaration of Independence' which described his far-right militant ideology, encompassing Islamophobia and opposition to feminism.

A Moroccan security source said that the militants retreated to a nearby mountain range across the border.
A communique released by Morocco's Ministry of the Interior said the gunmen were dressed in Afghan garb, and were likely to be Islamists from Algeria. After learning of the raid, the soldiers sought to intercept the gunmen.
