summary:
At least 17 people died and at least 131 wounded in a series of three bomb attacks that occurred within 15 minutes of each other in Mumbai on 13th June.
The first explosion was at around 18:50hrs near the Mumbadevi temple, in the Zaveri Bazaar (Kalbadevi) area in the south of the city; another in in the upmarket Diamond Market area near the Royal Opera House in Girgaon Chowpatty, and another near Kabutar Khana in the Dadar West area of central Mumbai.  A fourth explosive device was reportedly found and disarmed in the Dadar West area. All three blasts struck busy commercial areas that were crowded because it was rush hour. The timings and location of the three blasts strongly suggests the bombings were intended to be mass-casualty attacks that would cause maximum disruption
No group has claimed the attack. Initial press reports that the attacks happened on the same day as the birthday of the sole surviving gunman from the 2008 Mumbai attack proved erroneous. Early reporting speculated that the Indian Mujahidin might be responsible, as the nature of the attacks are similar those carried out by IM in the past.

summary:
Suspected southern separatist rebels have injured ten people, including nine policemen, in two coordinated bomb attacks in the Raman district of Yala
The first explosion took place when a rubber farmer stepped on a mine at around 07:00, sustaining injuries to his leg. Then at around 09:00, a second explosion occurred as a bomb disposal unit of the Border Patrol Police inspected the scene of the first blast.
More than 4,500 people have been killed and about 9,000 hurt in the country's southern provinces of Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat since fresh violence erupted in January 2004. Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, the Malay separatist group National Revolution Front - Cordinate is known to operate in the area and is likely to be involved in the attack.

summary:
FARC rebels have attacked five towns in western Colombia. In total, four people have been killed, and many more have been injured.
When the assailants attacked Toribio, one of the main towns, the main square was packed with people attending the market when the rebels attacked. FARC members drove a small bus laden with explosives into the local police station. Two civilians and one policeman died in the incident.
FARC has repeatedly attacked the town of Toribio, which has 26,000 members, and there have been 13 attacks on the town in all. These have killed 41 people and injured hundreds.
There were also attacks on the towns of Corinto, Caldono, Jambalo and Santander.
According to Colombian president, Juan Manuel Santos, the attacks were an attempt to distract the security forces, who are closing in on their leaders. Last week, the Colombian military was reportedly only 12 hours away from capturing Alfonso Cano, the former FARC leader.

Tensions between Ankara and the restive Kurdish community have mounted in the wake of the 12 June elections after the authorities refused to release six Kurdish politicans elected to parliament.

The raid came shortly after Mauritanian army forces destroyed a terrorist camp belonging to AQIM in northern Mali in late June.
Both the Mali and Mauritanian governments have launched joint initiatives along the border to curb AQIM initiatives. The border between the two countries has been among the hardest hit by terrorist activity in the region.

summary:
On 3rd July, militants, allegedly linked to the killers of two policeman in Aktobe province on 30 June and a third on 2 July, opened fired on police in Kenkiyak before escaping. Police officers returned fire and reportedly killed a relation of one of the men who carried out the initial attack.
According to the Kazakhstan Times, police were reportedly alerted to the group after receiving reports that a man and two women were behaving suspiciously in Kenkiyak. The group threw a bag at the police when they arrived but it did not explode and caused no injuries. Police reportedly discovered two guns, 500 grams of black powder, religious pamphlets and $10,000 in Kazakh tenge after the assailants fled.
Kazakh's interior ministry has confirmed the initial attack, but said it is unclear whether the assailants are members of an Islamist terrorist group. The police has named six suspects and offered a $100,000 reward for information. But according to the Kazakhstan Times, police have not ruled out the involvement of religious extremists'.
The incidents come six weeks after Kazakhstan experienced its first terrorist attack in over a decade. On 17 May, the regional headquarters of the secret police in Aktobe was subject to the country's first-ever suicide bombing attack. A week later, a car bomb - which contained the equivalent power of 2kg of TNT - exploded in the capital, Astana, outside a detention centre run by the security services.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Militant groups operating in Pakistan's tribal areas frequently kidnap security officials, opposition groups and government employees. The kidnapping of foreign nationals is unusual but offers groups such as the Tehrik-e-Taliban a source of revenue through ransom.

summary:
On 30th June, gunmen shot and killed two police officers at a checkpoint in Aktobe province.
No group claimed the attack,which occurred six weeks after Kazakhstan experienced its first terrorist attack in over a decade. On 17 May, the regional headquarters of the secret police in Aktobe was subject to the country's first-ever suicide bombing attack. A week later, a car bomb - which contained the equivalent power of 2kg of TNT - exploded in the capital, Astana, outside a detention centre run by the security services.
Even before May's suicide attack, there were a series of indications that Kazakhstan was facing a much deeper Islamist threat than its government seemed willing to admit. In February, a man threw a bomb at Aktobe prison, where six prisoners are being held on suspicion of plotting a terrorist attack; in April four men were sentenced to jail for trying to recruit jihadists inside the facility, and just a week before the bombing, a court jailed six Islamists for desecrating a local graveyard.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack but pro-democracy campaigners and ethnic groups have increased the use of violence over the last year. The Karen National Liberation Army (KNLA/KNU) has been fighting for an independent Karen state for almost 20 years. It has launched six attacks already this year.

summary:
Three coordinated bombings killed 40 and wounded over 100 in southwest Baghdad on 23 June.
The first bombing took place at 19:00 in a market in the Shia neighbourhood of al-Shurta al-Rabaa. Three bombs, placed at the entrance, exit and centre of the market detonated simultaneously. The explosions killed 34 and injured 82.
Local sources report that the bombs were hidden in wooden carts and one of the bombs was placed next to a mosque. Police sources note that the bombs were likely targeting the Shia community as the explosions coincided with the market's busiest trading hours.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. But given the size, sophistication and coordinated targeting of Shia districts, it is highly likely that the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) carried out the attack. The ISI is committed the removal of US troops and the imposition of a sharia Islamic state. It remains the main security threat in Iraq and is responsible for an attack on a mosque in Tikrit on 3 June that killed 34.

summary:
Ten suspected members of Islamist sect Boko Haram simultaneously robbed a bank and attacked a police station in Kankara, Katsina state. The attacks killed seven people, including five policemen.
The militants, armed with home-made bombs and firearms, split into two groups. One robbed the bank while the other attacked the divisional police station and freed suspects held in cells. The attackers seized guns and ammunition from the police station.
This is the third time since February that the group has attacked these two targets simultaneously. Militants attack the targets at the same time to prevent police officers from stopping the banks being robbed. The tactic is proving highly successful and the group is stealing both money and weapons from the police in the assaults. In January, the Central Bank of Nigeria released a security alert which warned all bank chief executives that a terrorist group - meaning Boko Haram - was planning to attack banks to raise funds for its operations.
This was Boko Haram's first attack in Katsina state. The group recently threatened to conduct more widespread attacks in Nigeria, and carried out their first ever attack in Abuja last week. Nigerian officials are increasingly concerned about Boko Haram's growing capabilities.
targets: Financial Sector; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces

summary:

The group had said on 13 June that it was angered by Ringim's declaration that "the days of Boko Haram are numbered". Witnesses of the attack said the motorcade of a senior police officer had driven into the headquarters minutes before the blast.
This was the group's first ever suicide attack, which indicates that its capabilities have grown. On 13 June, the day before the attack, Boko Haram warned that some of its members had recently received training from Somalia's al-Shabaab. The statement also vowed to conduct "fiercer" attacks in a wider geographic area, including Abuja.

summary:
A mortar landed next to the National Police Training Centre in Wardak province. There are no reports of any injuries.
The attack happened as senior Afghan politicians including vice president Mohammed Karim Khalili, and NATO officials arrived at the centre to celebrate the opening of the centre. Members of the security services evacuated the officials by helicopter before they created a security zone around the area.
The training facility in Wardak will become the largest training centre in Afghanistan with over 3,000 recruits to be housed there. It is part of a programme which aims to increase the number of Afghan police to 134,000 by October 2011.
This attack is one of many to take place in Wardak provincesince the Taliban declared its spring offensive against NATO and Afghan forces.
source_urls: Associated Press; War Update,; Tolo News
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Taliban terrorists destroyed two NATO oil tankers after they fired at them on the Qumbrani bridge in the Bolan district of Balochistan. The suspects managed to escape on motorcycles.  There are no reports of any casualties.
NATO forces in Afghanistan rely on supply convoys that pass through Balochistan from Quetta city. Yet, these supply lines are frequently attacked by members of the Tehrik -e- Taliban Balochistan (TTB) and other armed groups.

summary:
Armed militants launched a series of coordinated attacks against the provincial council building in centralBaqubain an incident that resembles that which took place inSalaheddinon 29th March which left 58 people dead.Reports suggest that the casualty figures include eight people dead and 27 wounded.
Local authorities said the attack began when a suicide bomber blew himself up in front of a police checkpoint before a car bomb exploded at the parameter walls of the building. This allowed armed gunmen to storm the compound and engage in a fire fight with members of the Iraqi army. Two of the attackers managed to blow themselves up before the security services took control of the building.
The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A suicide bomber drove a vehicle into a checkpoint outside of a police compound in central Basra. The explosion killed five people and injured 15 others.
The bomber tried to drive into the grounds of the compound.  Unable to gain entry, the bomber blew up the car. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
Compared to many other parts of Iraq, there are very few terrorist attacks carried out in the oil rich city of Basra. On 06 March, the last major attack, seven people died and 18 people suffered injuries when a roadside bomb detonated next to a US military patrol.  The authorities believe that attacks may rise as the deadline for the withdrawal for US military troops comes in December.

summary:
A suicide bomber blew himself up outside of a bank in Islamabad. One other person died in the attack which injured nine others. The security services say that the bomber tried to gain entry into the Silkbank in the 1-8 district of the city but detonated his explosives when a security guard tried to stop him. It was the first such attack to be recorded in Islamabad since December 2009.
The Taliban did not claim responsibility for the attack and it remains unclear as to whether the bank was specifically targeted because of its indirect links to the Saudi Royal family or in retaliation for the US raid that killed Osama Bin Laden.

summary:
Two homemade bombs exploded at a food market in the Tak Bai district of Narathiwat province of southern Thailand. The explosions did not cause any injuries. The first bomb exploded in front of a market vendor's stall in Plak Chang village. The second bomb exploded 15 minutes later at another walkway to the market.
According to the authorities, both of the devices were timed to explode with a digital watch. The two explosions caused a hole around three feet deep and four feet in diametre, but did not inflict any casualties.
There were no injuries, as police had cordonned off the area before the incident after the military spotted three teenagers riding around the market suspiciously before the explosion. The teenagers sped away as they saw the soldiers.
Islamic separatist militants are likely suspects, and have been conducting terrorist attacks in the South of Thailand for several years.

summary:
A suspected anarchist was seriously injured when he attempted to detonate an improvised explosive devise (IED) outside a branch of Banco Santander in the centre of the capital of Santiago. Witnesses claimed the mans accomplices fled the scene on motorcycles.
The incident is similar to a number of recent incidents in Chile during previous years, where banks have been attacked because they are symbols of the global economy. However, commercial premises, residential areas and churches have also been targeted.
Similar attacks have frequently been claimed by anarchist groups, such as the Efrain Plaza Olmedo Explosives Band. Some of the anarchists, however, have been reported to be linked with the Mapuche Indians, Chiles main indigenous group, which are struggling to reclaim the ownership of their ancestral lands.

summary:

Yala is the stronghold of Muslim separatist groups operating in Thailand's south. The attack came during the run up to the contested Thai elections on 3 July.

summary:

At the time of the attack, the Tibesti Hotel housing rebel leaders.
Although no one claimed responsibility for the attack, Ghadhafi loyalists are likely to blame. It is also worth mentioning thatAl-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) is currently exploiting the poor security environment in Libya, and has reportedly pillaged large quantities of weapons.

summary:
Armed gunmen launched a three day assault on a military checkpoint in Shaltalo town, Upper Dir district. Approximately 200 militants crossed the border from Kunar province in Afghanistan to carry out the raid. The militants successfully destroyed the checkpoint and pushed Pakistani security forces south to the Nusrat Darra area.
The attack killed 26 security personnel and six civilians. Police sources reported that 45 militants were killed during the raid. A video tape recording emerged on the 18th of June which showed the execution of 16 police officers taken hostage.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack although the security sources suspected the Haqqani network, a faction of the Afghan Taliban, was relocating fighters from the North Waziristan tribal region.

summary:
Suspected FARC militaries abducted and killed two mayoral candidates in the municipality of Campamento, North-Western Antioquia department.
Guillermo Roldn, candidate for the centre-right Partido Conservador (Colombian Conservative Party) was reportedly abducted by armed men on Monday and killed hours later. Donay Correa, aspirant Mayor for the Unidad Nacional - a coalition formed to support the government of incumbent President Juan Manuel Santos - was killed in similar circumstances.
Authorities blamed the 36th front of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) for the abductions. Given the targets and tactics, FARC is the likely culprit.
Abductions and targeted killings of local politicians happen on a regular basis and are likely to continue towards the elections taking place in October.

summary:
Two African Union soldiers died when Al-Shabaab militants, including one suicide bomber, launched an assault on a military base in Mogadishu.  Two other militants died in the assault.
The attackers, disguised as Somali government soldiers, drove up to the checkpoint in a white Sedan, and engaged in a firefight with the African Union soldiers and a pro-government militia. Unable to gain access to the base, one of the attackers blew himself up after he sustained injuries in the gun fight.
The Al-Qaeda linked Al-Shabaab group are in control of many parts of Southern Somalia and are engaged in fierce fighting with the Somali Transitional Government and the African Union's AMISOM peacekeeping force in many parts of Mogadishu. On 10 June a spokesman for the terrorist group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
In one of two explosion during twin suicide attacks in Herat, a Taliban militant drove a car bomb into the Ministry of Transport in the centre of Herat City, western Afghanistan. Intelligence sources stated that the explosion killed five and injured at least 34 others.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack and for another on the Italian-led Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) base, which injured at least 15.
Herat City is generally considered one of the safest areas in Afghanistan and was due to be the first city handed over to Afghan control in July 2012. However, this attack comes after the Taliban announced a spring offensive against NATO and ANSF forces at the start of May.

The incident comes after a series of attacks on Pakistan security forces and foreign nationals in Pakistan. Including a major assault on a Pakistan Naval Base in Karachi and a double suicide attack in Peshawar which killed at least 80.

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident. Gardez frequently sees attacks on the construction industry, including 35 workers killed and 20 wounded in the same area on 19 May. The attacks are Taliban efforts to undermine the central Afghan government. This particular company was constructing the Gardez-Logar main road.

summary:

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack on the Italian-led Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) base, which houses both civilians and NATO personnel. Local news sources state that one Taliban attacker detonated a suicide bomb outside the entrance to the compound, allowing three other gunmen to open fire on NATO troops for at least an hour.
Herat City is generally considered one of the safest areas in Afghanistan and is due to be transferred to Afghan control in July 2012, however theTaliban announced a spring offensive against NATO and ANSF forces at the start of May.

Law enforcement discovered the explosive before anybody was injured. Bomb disposal experts later defused the device. A police spokesman later claimed that some bomb-making components were also discovered at another location of the city after the incident.
The motive for the attack remains unclear. Nigerias recent elections were marred by violence in parts of the country, including several bombing incidents.

summary:
At approximately 04:00, a car exploded near a security services building in the capital of Kazakhstan, Astana. The explosion killed two people. Although initial media reports stated that the incident was a suicide bombing, the country's interior ministry played down the link to terrorism. In a statement, the department of the interior said that two people died after a car blew up in a spontaneous explosion'.
The explosion coincides with the visit of the president of Belarus to the Kazakhstan capital and comes only a week after a suicide bombing outside the headquarters of the security services in the northwest city of Aktobe, which wounded three people.

summary:
A road side bomb exploded in the Sparwan area of Panjwai districtas a vehicle carrying construction workers passed by. The explosion killed 11 construction workers and injured 30 others.The men were all employees of the local Nisa Road Construction firm and were on their way to work when the incident happened.
No group claimed the attack, but the location and method of attack suggests the Taliban was responsible.
The Taliban frequently attack labourers working on government-run projects. On 19 May, the group targeted the headquarters of another local road construction company in Paktia province.  That attack killed 35 people dead and injured over 20 others.

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants set fire to nearly 40 houses in the village of Darra Adamkhel, and fired rockets and mortar shells at tribesmen they accused of supporting government security forces. The attack injured numerous people, including children.
Village elders say the local administration did not offer them sufficient support against the militants. They claim authorities ignored their requests for a greater Frontier Constabulary (FC) presence in the area.
The area is said to have become a stronghold of the TTP, led by Commander Tariq Afridi. According to sources, Taliban militants from Swat, Waziristan, and Orakzai are currently located there.

summary:
Unidentified assailants left an explosive device at the Alejandro Velasco Astete Airport (IATA) in Cuzco. The explosive consisted of a grenade and dynamite but law enforcement officials stated that the device was not capable of detonating because of its poor condition.
At 12:50, airport staff discovered the device in a black bag in a service toilet. Disposal experts removed the item and the airport was evacuated as a security precaution. The airport is used by thousands of tourists who visit the Inca city of Machu   Picchu.
The motive behind the incident remains unclear. A police source stated that the cause may have been to intimidate security forces in the wake of the presidential election, scheduled for 5 June.
source_urls: Reuters; EFE; Europe Press; La Rpublica

summary:

No further information regarding the incident was provided. A military sergeant only confirmed that the blast occurred in a rural area of the department.
According to a military chief, FARC has increased its use anti-personnel mines this year. The Colombian military actively deactivates militant minefields across the country.

summary:
A car bomb exploded near the headquarters of the Iraqi federal police in a square near a federal police building in west Baghdad's shia Amil district neighbourhood, in the Al-Rashid district.
The area saw the heaviest bombing with at least five consecutive attacks. The total casualty rate of the city's attacks on that morning were two people killed and 15 more wounded.
This attack was part of at least 16 seemingly coordinated attacks in the morning as people were going to work in Baghdad. The final death toll of the morning's attacks across the city was 13 killed, 74 injured.
No one immediately claimed responsibility.

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants blockaded around 200 people in the village of Las Mercedes in Choc Department. On 22 May, FARC also killed three civilians and a police officer in attacks along the nearby Atrato River.
The military was sent to the area after the attacks and FARC militants blockaded themselves in the town of Las Mercedes to evade security forces. The people of the town were prevented from leaving and boats were prohibited from passing through the area. According to some reports the people were initially withheld for defying a travel ban imposed on the area by FARC.
The Colombian military eventually freed the town from FARC control and condemned the group for using the people as human shields. No fatalities or injuries were reported. The 34th Front of FARC is responsible for the attack.

summary:
At 22:30 a group of ten to 15 Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants, armed with automatic weapons, suicide vests, rockets and grenades, managed to evade security and enter the Pakistan Naval Station in Mehran. They launched multiple explosives and opened fire on Pakistani military personnel in a fire fight that lasted 16 hours. Ten personnel were killed in the attack and another 15 injured. Two attackers were killed by the Pakistani military, while another blew himself up. Two other attackers escaped, but a number remained unaccounted for.
The intial target of the assault appeared to be three aircraft hangars inside the base. The militants destroyed at least two US-made P-3C Orion aircraft using rocket propelled grenades. Subsequently, the militants opened fire on security forces and workers. Pakistani marines staged a 16 hour operation to end the seige.Initial reports suggested the TTP was holding several people hostage, but local officials later denied these claims and noted all foreigners were recovered safely.
The TTP, the most active militant group in Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack and stated that it was in retaliation for the killing of Osama Bin Laden on 2 May. The attack follows a number of high profile attacks, including an attack on a US convoy in Peshawar on 20 May and a double suicide attack in Shabqadar, which killed 80, on 13 May.
area: Pakistani Naval Station Mehran, Karachi, Sindh

summary:
Four Taliban gunmen dressed as Afghan policemen stormed a police checkpoint in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, and occupied it. They were all wearing suicide vests. There were further militants outside the compound.
The raid took place at 04:30 when there were not a lot of guards on duty. The gunmen shot officers guarding the compound and occupied the second floor to fire on officers below from the building. One of the gunmen detonated his explosives vest.
US troops assisted the police in fighting the gunmen.
The gunmen also rigged their car with explosives outside the compound, but police and US troops conducted a controlled explosion.
In its claim of responsibility, the Taliban said they targeted the building because it overlooked  the local base for the Afghan police Quick Reaction Force.
The siege and ensuing fires continued for at least ten hours. The fighting killed three of the four attackers. At least two US soldiers were also injured.
author: Unknown author

The attack was timed to strike consulate employees as they arrived for work. It follows repeated warnings of attacks on American and Pakistani interests from the TTP after the death of Osama Bin Laden on 02 May. On the previous Friday, more than 80 were killed in twin suicide bombings in Pakistans northwest. This incident is the first attack on Americans since 2008.
Peshawar, the provincial capital of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, borders the tribal areas were groups such as TTP and Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ) are highly active. University Town is considered one main the most secure area in Peshawar.

summary:
In one of two attacks by Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) on NATO tankers, at 22:40 militants bombed two oil tankers parked on the roadside in the Torkham area of the Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). The fire from the explosion spread through the Torkham parking hub and destroyed at least 14 other tankers. No casualties were reported in the attack.
The FATA frequently suffer attacks from the TTP, the most active group in Pakistan. In a related incident one tanker was bombed ten minutes earlier in the nearby Landikotal area. Torkham is a major supply route for NATO forces in Afghanistan.
area: Torkham area, Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA)
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
In one of two attacks by Tehrik-i-Taliban on NATO tankers in North West Pakistan,at 22:20 a tanker parked on the roadside was bombed in the Landikotal area of the Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). The initial attack left no casualties, but a subsequent explosion killed 15 people as they attempted to salvage fuel from the damaged vehicle.
The FATA frequently suffer attacks from the TTP, the most active group in Pakistan. In a related incident 14 other tankers were torched ten minutes later in the nearby Torkham area, a major transport route for NATO forces in Afghanistan.

summary:
During morning rush hour traffic at 09:00 in Kirkuk, an explosive device attached to a car detonated in a parking lot in front of the police headquarters. The explosion was part of two other coordinated bomb attacks in the city. A local police source stated 25 were killed and 86 injured. Seventeen police officers were among the dead.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, but the incident followed the arrest of at least eight Al-Qaeda in Iraq militants on the 18 May; including the alleged military commander MikhlifMohammed Hussein al-Azzawi, and at least three other senior figures.

summary:

The attack came thirty minutes after two explosions outside the police headquarters that killed 17 officers and eight civilians.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, but the incident followed the arrest of at least eight Al-Qaeda in Iraq militants on the 18 May; including the alleged military commander MikhlifMohammed Hussein al-Azzawi, and three other senior figures.

summary:
In the second of three coordinated bomb attacks in Kirkuk, a large explosion outside the local police headquarters killed 25 people and injured 86 others. All of those killed are suspected to be police officers or fire fighters.
The attackers used a familiar tactic, detonating a small explosive device in a parking lot first which killed eight people. After police arrived at the scene a larger car bomb went off killing 17 officers and eight firefighters.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, but the incident followed the arrest of at least eight Al-Qaeda in Iraq militants on the 18 May; including the alleged military commander Mikhlif Mohammed Hussein al-Azzawi, and three other senior figures.

summary:
Taliban militants attacked a regional road construction company's headquarters in Paktia province. Gunmen killed 35 employees and wounded 20 others. Eight Taliban members are reported killed.
Provincial officials stated that 80 employees were at the site when it was attacked in the early morning. Fighting between the Taliban and company guards reportedly lasted for hours. The attackers destroyed twelve vehicles and some equipment before escaping with eight vehicles and a large number of weapons. Shortly after a Taliban spokesperson claimed responsibility for the attack.
This was dealiest attack since February when 42 people were killed in Jalabad. The Talibanoften targeted construction and development projects in order to derail the efforts of ISAF and ANSF to establish effect rule of law in rural Afghanistan.
At the beginning of May, the Taliban announced the start of their spring military campaign.

summary:

The incident comes shortly after the arrival of Joseph Yun, deputy US assistant secretary for East Asia and Pacific affairs arrived for talks.
The Karen National Union and its armed wing, the Karen National Liberation Army, is a ethnic separatist movement that has fought government forces since 1948.

On May 19, reports surfaced that the men were planning to attack tourism sites in Tunisia. According to newspaper Le Temps, a map of Tunisia was discovered amongst the terrorist's belongings marking planned attacks on tourism targets inBizerte, Tabarka and Hammamet.

summary:
More than 70 suspected Laskar-e-Islam (LeI) militants attacked a police checkpoint on the outskirts of Peshawar in a carefully planned pre-dawn assault that killed two police officers and injured five others.
The militants travelled from Bara, in neighbouring Khyber Agency, and retreated in the same direction. A smaller group of militants had already attacked the checkpoint at midnight, but police repelled the attack. When the militants returned with added force hours later, the exchange of fire lasted 2.5 hours. The suspected LeI attackers carried AK-47 rifles and rocket launchers.
Lasker-e-Islam is based in the Bara region of Khyber. The group is known primarily for conducting kidnappings for ransom and targeted killings. LeI is affiliated with the TTP, but it is unclear whether the group takes direct operational orders from TTP command.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Suspected Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) terrorists were arrested in Rimadah, near the border with Libya. One of the men threw an explosive at police officers during the arrest but the device failed to detonate.
The men were carrying an explosive belt, several other explosives, and small weapons. Tunisian authorities stated that the men were Libyan and Algerian nationals but were carrying Afghan papers.
After interrogating the men, Tunisian officials also discovered a weapons cache hidden in the mountains where they found automatic weapons, munitions, and explosives. Police also discovered that the men were connected to two other men arrested last week in Tunisia.
AQIM is believed to be exploiting the Libya conflict to acquire weapons and transport them across the region. Security officials have suspected that group members have been transferring weapons to a possible stronghold in Mali. Tunisia has tightened security along its border with Libya.

summary:
Two Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) suicide bombers staged a double attack on a Pakistani paramilitary force academy at the Frontier Constabulary in Shabqadar, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. The explosions have killed 80 people and injured 100 others.
Both terrorists were riding motorcycles. The first blew himself up next to a line of police recruits who were preparing to go on leave. The second attack occurred as emergency services arrived at the scene.
Shortly after the incident, a TTP spokesman claimed responsibility and warned that this was the first revenge for Osama's martyrdom'. He said that the group would conduct larger attacks in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
This morning's attack was the most deadly in Pakistan this year. The target selection is consistent with its attacks against military and police targets over the past twelve months. The TTP is most active around Peshawar, where it conducts attacks on a near daily basis.

Two police injuries have been reported and local police have requested reinforcements and possible air support. A local police commander claimed that Taliban militants from Pakistan and other foreign countries were also engaged in the assault.
This is the second large scale assault in Afghanistan since the death of Osama Bin Laden last week. Four days ago the Taliban staged a massive attack on Kandahar which killed at least three people.

summary:

summary:

The Taliban suicide bomber targeted NATO and ISAF officials as they returned from a meeting with local tribal leaders. The explosion initially killed three, but two more died of injuries shortly after. All of those killed were children. Seven others, including two Afghan National Police officers, were wounded. No NATO troops were killed. 
A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack. The incident comes after the Talibans announcement of a spring offensive against ISAF and ANSF forces on the 30 April, and three days of continuous fighting in the southern province of Kandahar.

summary:
The Taliban launched a series of coordinated attacks across Kandahar and killed at least two people and injured 29 more. At least six Taliban militants were reportedly also killed over the course of the day.
Militants reportedly attacked the governor's compound, the mayor's office, the Afghan spy agency, and several police stations with machine guns, rocket propelled grenades and hand grenades.
There were also six suicide bombings, two car bombings and two rickshaw bombings in the city.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, and stated that despite the timing -- less than a week after the US killed Al-Qaeda leader Osama Bin Laden in Pakistan -- the assault had been planned for weeks and did not come in retaliation for Bin Laden's death.
Fighting continued at the government buildings for several hours and US helicopters were reportedly seen above the city during the fighting.
A week prior to the attack, the Taliban announced that it planned to launch a 'spring offensive' against international forces and the Afghan government, and this assault appears to be have been the first major attack in the spring campaign.

summary:
On Friday morning at 06:30, militants belonging to Lashkar-i-Jhangvi fired on civilians taking part in morning exercise near the graveyard in Hazara Town, Quetta. At least six people were killed and 15 others wounded in the attack which lasted 20 minutes.
In the area adjacent to the Hazara Town graveyard, three rockets were fired from a distance before armed men in two pick-up trucks fired automatic weapons and threw hand grenades into the crowd. A Quetta police officer noted over 100 rounds of ammunition was fired into the crowd and confirmed the casualty numbers. He also insisted that the attack was carried out for sectarian reasons. A spokesman for the banned Lashkar-i-Jhangvi called a local news agency and claimed responsibility for the attack.
Lashkar-e-Jhangvi is particularly active in Pakistan and the attack came less than a week after US special forces killed Osama bin Laden, Al-Qaeda's founder, in an attack on a compound in Abbottabad in the north of the country.

summary:

The Maoists lured police officers to a remote and tactically advantageous location on the pretence that the group was holding a meeting with villagers in the area. The Maoists reportedly planted 50 IED's around the forested ambush site which clowed the arrival of police reinforcements.
Theincident was the most serious CPI-M attack in Jharkhand in two years.

The attack was the latest in a series of attacks against senior military and government figures and occurred just months before US forces completely withdraw from the city. The dead soldier was part of Iraqi president Jalal Talabani's private office in Sulaimaniyah, Iraqi Kurdistan's second-biggest city. The officer was a member of the president's tribe.
Gunmen in a Toyota Corolla reportedly drove up to a construction site that Talabani was visiting in south Kirkuk and got out of the vehicle before fleeing the scene. According to eyewitnesses, the gunmen threatened to kill all of the workers at the construction site, as well as Talabani's lone bodyguard, if they tried to help the security officer.

AQAP has conducted a series of attacks against the army since it reportedly took control of large swathes of Abyan province on 30 March. Local sources reported that days earlier the group looted an ammunition factory in the Abyan city of Jaar.

Initial police reports say today's bomb, which was hidden near a petrol pump and detonated remotely, contained three kilograms of explosives.
Police said that bomb was similar to Tuesday's twin bombing, and that the device had been concealed in a motorcycle.
On the 26 April,terrorists detonated a bomb near a Navy service bus in the city's Defence Housing Authority (DHA Phase II), and minutes later another against a Navy bus in the Baldia Town area of Karachi which killed two people. The two explosions resulted in around 60 injuries, most Navy officers, and four deaths.
The incidents were the first major attacks on the military in Karachi in seven years. The TTP claimed both attacks.

summary:
Unidentified assailants attacked a gas pipeline near the village of Sabil in the Arish region of northern Sinai. The explosion forced the authorities to cut gas supplies to neighbouring Israel and Jordan.
Officials described the attack as an act of sabotage, and said the explosion caused no injuries. The extent of the damage was not known.
The pipeline was previously attack on 5 February during large anti-government protest that forced Hosni Mubarak from power on 11 February. Gas supplies were disrupted to Israel and Jordan for 11 days. On the 27 March, militants planted an explosive device at a gas terminal in Sabil but it failed to detonate.

A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack, but this is yet to be confirmed by Afghan and ISAF authorities.

summary:
At around 07:35, terrorists detonated an explosive near a Pakistani Navy service bus in the Baldia Town area of Karachi. An explosive device was planted along the bus route and remotely detonated when the vehicle passed the area.
The explosion killed two people and wounded 19 others. The attack occurred almost simultaneously with another Navy bus explosion in the Defence Housing Authority- Phase II area of Karachi. The two explosions resulted in around 60 injuries, mostly Navy officers, and four deaths.
These incidents are the first major attacks on the military in Karachi in seven years. A Pakistani security source stated that the attacks were preceded by intelligence reports suggesting Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), a militant group linked affiliated with Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and Al-Qaeda, was planning attacks.
The LeJ is linked to the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) through a network known as the 'Punjabi Taliban'. The TTP claimed responsibility for the bombings and warned that further attacks were being planned. It is not known if TTP militants from the tribal areas, or Punjabi proxies such as the LeJ, carried out the attack.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Taliban militants orchestrated a mass prison brake that freed more than 470 inmates at the Sarposa prison in Kandahar province. The militants dug a tunnel over 300 metres long that started from a house close to the jail and ended in a cell housing political prisoners. The diggers breached the prison on Sunday at 23:00, and then spent four and half hours leading prisoners through the tunnel to the outside.
A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility and said the operation took five months to execute. He claimed that they had freed 541 prisoners, of which 100 were Taliban commanders.
The police started a search operation and managed to recapture 26 inmates.
The incident is the second time in three years that inmates have escaped from the prison. In 2008 a suicide bomber destroyed the front gates of the prison killing 15 guards and allowing 900 prisoners to escape.

On a statement released on 08 June, the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed responsibility for the attack.The ISI is trying toexploit sectarian rivalries in order to foment instability and often target what they consider to be apostate government employees or religious figures.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists planted an explosive device targeted at police on the Annadale Embankment in south Belfast. The device failed to detonate and there were no injuries as a result of the incident.
Police responded to an emergencycall from a man who claimed to have heard a women in distress in the area. When officers arrived they found the device attached to a gate leading to the Lagan River. A police spokesman said that the attack was a 'clear attempt to murder' and if the device had detonated it was capable of causing many fatalities.
No group claimed responsibility for the failed attack although the target and type of device suggest that dissident republicans such as Oglaigh na hEireaan (ONH) are to blame.
On 2 April, dissident republicans targeted and killed PSNI officer Ronan Kerr with a sticky bomb near the town of Omagh.  The seucrity services say they fear an increase in activity by these groups in the lead up to the visit by the Queen to the Republic of Ireland in May.

summary:
An explosion at the Oktyabrskaya subway station in the Belarusian capital of Minsk killed fifteen people and injured almost 150 others. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
There has been considerable political tension in Belarus since December, when police cracked down on demonstrators who opposed the results of the disputed presidential elections. The station is located within 100 meters of the Palace of the Republic and the home of President Alexander Lukashenko.
In a statement the President claimed the attack was an attempt to destabilise the country and said it was likely external forces were involved.
On 18 April 2011, an investigation official reported that two suspects arrested on suspicion for the attack were amateur chemists and electricians.

Militants detonated the first car as two policemen tried defuse the device. Fifteen minutes later the militants detonated the second car about 150 metres away, targeted at crowds gathered at the scene of the first explosion.
No group claimed the attack, but the use of a double car bomb, the second designed to target crowds gathered at the scene of the first incident, strongly suggests the involvement of the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).

summary:
French police detained two suspected ETA militants after a gunfight in the town of Croze in central France. One policeman was injured in the incident.
On Saturday the two militants failed to stop and opened fire at a checkpoint in Vallires, in the Creuze department. French police launched an investigation and tasked 300 police officers to track the two suspects. Officials finally caught up with the men in Croze on Sunday, and after a short exchange of gunfire and took them in to custody.
The incident comes after Spanish police managed to dismantle an ETA cell in Spain in early March. French and Spanish police have arrested nearly 30 suspected ETA members since the group announced a permanent ceasefire in January 2011.

summary:

Police received two bomb alerts shortly before 23:00 on Thursday. The van was found on Friday and Army bomb disposal experts carried out several controlled explosions to defuse the device. Police reported the bomb was 500lb, and could have caused significant damage and loss of life had it detonated.
No group claimed responsibility for the device. The incident happened less than a week after a bomb exploded under the car of a police officer, killing a PSNI constable in Omagh. Oglaigh nah Eireann (ONH) claimed responsibility for two bombs over the last weekend in March, and we suspect their involvement in the incident.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a bus as it travelled from Pagadian city to Zamboanga city. The attack killed three people and injured one other.
Gunmen boarded the bus posing as passengers in Tungawan town and opened fire on two bus marshals, killing one and wounding the other. An army Major on the bus drew his weapon but the gunmen killed both him and his wife. The militants then forced all of the passengers off the bus and set it alight.
No group claimed repsonsibility. The attack occurred in a Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) stronghold, however security forces did not comment on its involvement as the government and MILF are currently in peace negotiations.
Armed groups regularly target bus companies for extortion, and it is possible that a criminally motivated gang was behind the attack. Due to the frequency of similar attacks armed marshals now travel on the buses.

The actor,the son of a Jewish mother and Arab father starred in several critically acclaimed Israeli films including the 'Little Drummer Girl' in 1984. He recently ran a theatre company in Jenin, which sparked anger and demonstrations from some people who saw it as a challenge to their traditions.

specific_target: Islamic Action Front, Jordan's main opposition group
summary:
The Jordanian authorities arrested a man thought to be wearing an explosive belt after he attempted to enter offices of the Islamic Action Front (IAF) in Amman. Police arrived at the scene and arrested the would-be bomber after employees at the building reported a suspicious individual on the premises. However, bomb disposal officers subsequently found the explosive device to be a fake.
The IAF is the political wing of the Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan and has been behind a number of protests in recent months calling for political reform. IAF officials have said that the man had threatened to blow himself up because he believes the party is against the new government's reforms and hates King Abdullah.
The IAF has been behind several protests in Amman since January, but has refused to participate in the king's national dialogue on reform. Instead, it seeks more profound political change, including the dissolution of parliament and removing the king's power to appoint the prime minister.
author: Unknown author

summary:

The explosives detonated but caused no injury. On March 25, another man was killed by security forces after a similar suicide attempt. 
This incident followed reports that Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) militants had seized truck-loads of weapons from Muammar Gaddafis weapons arsenals in Libya. The militants were reportedly storing the cache in AQIM strongholds in Mali.

summary:

Local security sources reported that that the terrorist acted alone and it was likely he accidentally triggered the device. A gun was also seized from the scene.
No other details were reported about the incident and no group claimed responsibility.
The attack is the second of its kind in the same day. Earlier a suicide bomber attempted to attack a crowd of people fleeing the unrest in Libya near a border checkpoint in Eastern Algeria.
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) is the most active terrorist group in the country and suicide attacks have previously been a common tactic of the group.

Fierce fighting continues in Abidjan between troops loyal to Gbagbo and those of Alassane Quattara, who the international community believes won the 2010 presidential elections. Meanwhile, the UN and France forces continue to launch operations which are aimed at hindering the ability of Gbagbo's military to conduct attacks.

summary:

The authorities blamed Boko Haram, the most active Islamist group in the country for the attack. The group is active in the area and seeks to implement Sharia law across Nigeria.
Nigeria is roughly split along religious lines between a mainly Muslim north and Christian south. Since its Christmas Eve attack in Jos, Boko Haram has conducted a number of attacks outside its stronghold in the country's predominately Muslim north. The group regularly attacks the security force members.

summary:
A bomb exploded under a car belonging to a 25 year-old policeman in Omagh, County Tyrone, this afternoon. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.He is the second policeman to be killed in dissident republican attacks since the RUC formed out of the PSNI in 2001.
In March 2009, Northern Irish police shot a police officer dead as he answered a distress call in Craigavon, County Armagh. Dissident republican group, the Continuity IRA, claimed responsibility for the attack.
On Saturday morning, around 2,000 people competing in the Omagh Half Marathon passed the nearby entrance to the estate only a few hours before the explosion.
Since 2007, dissident Republicans have staged a number of bombings in Northern Ireland, including planting dozens of booby-trap bombs under the private cars of police officers.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident although we suspect the Continuity IRA was responsible.

summary: A suicide bomber killed a child and injured ten other people when he blew himself up, after he was identified and shot at in Darra Adam Khel, Kohat district, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa on 1st April. The authorities identified the would-be suicide bomber as he tried to enter a crowded market in Darra Adam Khel. Tribesmen tried to overpower him, but he blew himself up as we shot at, killing a 12 year-old boy and injuring ten people. No group claimed responsibility, and it is unclear which group he was part of.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected anarchists mailed a parcel bomb to the governor of maximum security Korydallos prison in western Athens. The bomb was detonated in a controlled explosion outside of the prison.
Currently nine members of the Greek anarchist group Revolutionary Nuclei of Fire are on trial in the prison for their suspected involvement in bombings and other offences. The same group claimed responsibility for parcel bombs last November that targeted embassies across Europe.
The package bore postage stamps from Florence, Italy. On March 31 two more similar bombs were sent to locations in Italy and Switzerland.
source_urls: New York Times; IANS; The Scotsman
author: Unknown author

summary:
Unidentified militants sent a letter bomb to the offices of Swissnuclear, a nuclear power lobby group based in Olten, Switzerland. The bomb detonated as the post was opened in the morning. The explosion caused superficial damage and hearing injuries to two of the companies employees.
The group and motive behind the attack remains unclear.
The debate around nuclear power has been heightened since the tsunami in Japan seriously damaged one of their nuclear facilities and caused a worldwide nuclear scare. Earlier in March, Switzerland suspended the approvals process of three new nuclear power stations in order to assess safety standards.
In April 2010, members of an Italian eco-terrorist group, Il Silvestre, were arrested plotting an attack on IBM Corporation research facility in Rueschlikon, Switzerland. The group is known to oppose nuclear power.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

source_urls: New York Times; Arab times; Associated Press (AP)

summary:
Unidentified militants exploded a bomb which targeted the leader of the Jamiat Ulema-i-Islam - Fazul (JUI-F) party in Charsadda, northwest Pakistan. The explosion killed at least 12 people and injured at least 15 others. Three policemen were among those killed, as well as women and children.
The bomb hit a police vehicle that was part of the security detail, however the target and his entourage were unharmed in the attack.
This was the second attack in two days targeted at the leader of JUI-F. On Tuesday a suicide bomber killed three and injured 18 in an attempt on his life in the nearby town of Swabi.
No group claimed responsibility, and the motive behind the attack on the target remains unclear.

summary:
Militants attacked a provincial council meetingin an attack thatleft 55 people dead and 95 injured. The attack began when acar bombhit the main entrance to the building, which distracted police. The militants, who wore military clothing, opened fire on the securityguards and then stormed the rest of the building.Theyexecutedthree councilmen and randomly shot at staffin the reception areabefore they then took 15 people hostage.
A four-hour standoff with the security services, including the US military,ensued before the militants blew themselves up.
Tikrit was once a strong hold of the insurgency which followed the American-led invasion in 2003. The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), a cover name for al-Qaeda in Iraq, claimed responsibility for the attack.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Terrorists launched a coordinated attack on the Salaheddin provincial council headquarters in Tikrit.
The terrorists, who wore Iraqi army uniforms, attacked the complex with a suicide car bomb and an assortment of assault rifles, grenades and suicide belts. Local media sources reported that the terrorists spent several hours attacking office workers in the complex. The attack killed at least 53 people and wounded a further 90. Dozens of hostages were reportedly taken hostage during the attack.   Security forces reported that no survivors were found following the attack.
The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI), a cover name for al-Qaeda in Iraq, claimed responsibility for the incident which bore striking similarities to an attack in November 2010 when al-Qaeda gunmen attacked a Catholic cathedral in Baghdad in which over 50 people were killed.
source_urls: Reuters; CNN; Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty

summary:

The 110lb device did not explode. A local security team defused the explosive shortly after its discovery. Police warned that if the device had exploded, it would most certainly have killed or seriously injured passers by.
ONH claimed responsibility for two bombing incidents in Northern Ireland over the weekend. On 28th March, police discovered an explosive device in a coffee jar in west Belfast.
area: Bishop Street Courthouse, Derry, County Derry, Northern Ireland
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Oglaigh na hEireann (ONH), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb threat forced the evacuation of the area surrounding the courthouse Derry/Londonderry.  The police described the bomb - 50kg of explosives contained in a beer keg - as potentially viable.  The evacuation took place after a coded message was received on Sunday evening which warned of the threat.
Dissident republicans from the Real IRA or Oglaigh na hEireann, who are opposed to the Good Friday agreement, are thought to be behind this latest incident however no group claimed responsibility.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified gunmen killed a soldier in Kizlyar, Dagestan. The gunmen opened fire on the soldier near to his house and killed the man instantly. No other injuries were reported.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. However, westronglysuspect the incident is linked to the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia, the most active separatist group in the republic. The group acts under theumbrellaof the Caucasus Emirate, and frequently attacks the security services.

summary:
Unidentified militants exploded a bomb next to a Syrian Orthodox church in Zahle's industrial district.
The explosion did not result in any casualties, but caused significant structural damage.   According to media accounts of the incident, 2 kgs of TNT explosives were placed on the churchs doorstep and detonated by a mobile phone. The explosion damaged the churchs door and church benches.
The attack occurred in the same town where seven Estonian tourists were kidnapped on Wednesday, and local security officials believe that the two incidents could be connected.
No group has claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen attacked a natural gas terminal in the town of El-Sabil, on the Sinai peninsula. The group of assailants attacked a security guard, before planting a bomb near the pipeline.
The device failed to explode, and after a thorough search of the area the flow resumed as normal. The pipeline supplies natural gas to Israel, Lebanon, Syria and Jordan.
The same pipeline was attacked in early February after unidentified assailants detonated explosives near El Arish. Business was disrupted for six weeks because of the damage caused by the explosion.

The explosion killed one passenger and injured at least 22 others. Terrorists hid the bomb in the luggagecompartmentof the bus, which had 40 passengers on board.
No group claimedresponsibilityfor the bus. Two days earlier, The Tarai Hanatanrik Mukti Party (TJMP) detonated an explosion on a bus in RautahatDistrictinjuring 13 people.

summary:
The Taliban claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing that killed 13 people and injured 50 others in the remote Bermel district of Paktika province. Those killed and injured included engineers, construction workers and security guards from a local construction company.
The securityservices believe that the assailants shot their way inside the main gates of the Abdol Zaher construction company, before they exploded their bomb.
In an email statement to the media, the Taliban said it carried out the attack. The Al Qaeda-linked Haqqani network, which is based in North Waziristan in Pakistan, is alsoparticularly active in Paktika.

summary:
A group of Taliban militants kidnapped 50 police officers in northeastern Afghanistan. The men, who were unarmed and on leave, were travelling in four vehicles in the Chapa Dara district. A Taliban spokesperson claimed that they had kidnapped the people.
Previously the Taliban has kidnapped large numbers of police and security officials and only released them after they pledged to stop working for the government.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated an explosive device on a gas pipeline in Sui town in the Dera Bugti area of Balochistan. No injuries were reported, however the explosion caused the gas supply to be suspended in many areas of Balochistan.
Police started an investigation and authorities started work to repair the damage.
No group claimed responsibility. There are a number of separatist groups who are active in area, such as the Balochistan Liberation Army (BLA) and theBalochistanRepublicArmy (BRA) who strive for more autonomy over the large quantity of natural resources in the area. They frequently disrupt gas and electricity supplies in the region and we suspect their involvement in this incident.

summary:
Suspected Boko Haram gunmen killed a local politician in Maiduguri, in the restive state of Borno. Four men on motorcycles armed with automatic weapons opened fire on a group of politicians after a political meeting. The victim, a youth leader for the All Nigerian Peoples Party (ANPP), died instantly.
The attack comes as Nigeria prepares itself for parliamentary elections on 2nd April. The presidential poll will take place one week later, along with state governors elections.
Boko Haram has launched a low intensity uprising across parts of Nigeria and is responsible for a series of targeted killings which have left dozens dead.

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants detonated explosives along a tract of pipeline near the town of Carraipa, in rural La Guajira Department. The attack affected around 25 metres of the 220 kilometre long pipeline and halted production for several days.
The Trans-Caribbean pipeline (or Antonio Ricaurte pipeline) belongs to Venezuelan state company PDVSA and only 88 kilometres of the line is on Colombian territory. Security officials believe the 59th Front of the FARC is responsible for the attack.
This is the first FARC attack against the Venezuelan owned pipeline. On February 23, suspected FARC militants sabotaged a railway line used to transport coal near Cerrejon in the same department.

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan militants attacked two passenger buses in Bagan. The buses were carrying mostly Shia passengers.The gunmen fired at the buses, killing  at least 13 people and kidnapped 33 others. According to local reports, the majority of victims were Shia.
The militants then escaped with the hostages in two cars.   The incident was the latest in a series of Taliban attacks against Shias. The TTP appears determined to end a peace deal between Taliban terrorists and Shia Muslims that was brokered by Pakistani security forces in February. Prior to this, the Shia had been involved in a long-campaign that aimed to keep the Taliban out of Bagan.
The following day, after a security-force raid in Bagan, 15 of the hostages were recovered.

summary:
At 15:00, unidentified terrorists detonated an explosive device near the central bus terminal in western Jerusalem. The device was planted near a telephone booth and the explosion damaged several cars and buses. The attack killed a person and injured 30 others, five seriously.
The entrance to the city has been closed and security forces are searching for more suspicious objects. This is the first major bombing attack in Jerusalem since 2004, when the city experienced its last suicide bus attack. The Islamic Jihad claimed the attack.
Tensions have been rising between Israelis and Palestinians in recent weeks. On March 12, five Israeli settlers, including three children, were killed in the Itamar settlement near Nablus. Rocket fire from the Gaza strip has also increased in recent weeks and IDF forces have retaliated with several deadly strikes on the area.

summary:
Islamic Jihad militants launched a two rockets from Gaza, which hit the cities of Be'er Sheeba and Ashdod, and injured one civilian.
On 23 February, militants fired two Grad rockets at the city, which marked the first time that a rocket had hit the city since the Gaza war ended in January 2009. These two attacks demonstrate that militants possess the capability to attack cities over 26 miles from Gaza.
While claiming responisbility,an Islamic Jihad spokesman vowed that the group's Al-Quds Brigades will fire rockets deeper into Israel, in a 'new phase' of resistance.

summary:
At around 1730hrs, unidentified assailants kidnapped seven Estonian cyclists from Zahl, in the Bekaa valley.    According to most reports, the Estonians cycled from Syria into Lebanon, and were taken when they entered the Zahl area. According to news sources, the kidnappers intercepted the group in a Mercedes and two white vans. Photographs have shown their cycles left abandoned on the side of the road.
While some media reports suggest that the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command (PFLP-GC) may have been involved in the kidnapping because of its presence in the area, responsibility for the kidnapping was later claimed by the previously unknown Salafi terrorist group Annahda Wal-Islah (Rebirth and Reform), which requested the payment of a ransom without specifying an amount.
The hostages were released on 14 July. It is yet unclear whether any ransom was paid prior to the release.
author: Unknown author

summary:

No group claimed responsibility.There are several terrorist separatist groups who are active around Quetta and we suspect one of these to be behind the attack.

No fatality or injury was reported. It is not known how much crude oil may have been spilled or whether the spill reached the river.
FARC militants sabotaged the Cao Limn-Coveas pipeline with explosives in the same department on February 25. Oil and gas infrastructure remains a target for militant violence across Colombia.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack. There are a number of separatist groups active in the region. given the location we suspect Geraken Mujahidin Islami Pattani (GMIP) to be involved.
Since the beginning of 2004, the separatist uprising in the former the former Sultanate left almost 4,500 people dead and the government decision to deploy over 60,000 members of the security forces to this rubber rich region of southern Thailand made little difference to quell the violence.

The kidnapping coincided with the arrival of the US Ambassador in nearby Zamboanga City, who came to look at US development programmes in the area.
US troops are present in several southern provinces to train local forces in counter-terrorism operations. Over the weekend three fishermen were kidnapped by suspected Abu Sayyef members in Sulu Province.

summary:
Militants fired an estimated 50 mortar shells from the Gaza strip into Israel. The attack injured two people and caused some damage to civilian buildings. This is the biggest attack from the Gaza strip on Israel for two years.
The Al Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamasclaimed responsibility for firing 33 of the mortar shells. This is the first attack on Israel they have claimed since January 2009.
The spokesman said the attack was in response to Israeli warplanes bombing a target specifically associated with Hamas earlier in the week, and broke the cycle of attack and counterattack between Israel and other militant groups in Gaza.
Israel responded to the attack by firing tank shells at several targets in Gaza. Palestinian officials said this response injured five people including three Hamas militants.

The incident comes one day after security forces discovered a large Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) weapons cache in the same area. A Colombian security official claimed that the weapons and uniforms found in the cache originated from Venezuela.

Suspetced Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) terrorists mailed a bomb to the home of an Indonesian rock musician in upscale Pondok Indah, south Jakarta. The homemade device, disguised as a book, was one of four similar bombs mailed across the capital this week. Security teams managed to defuse the device before any injury or damage was caused.
On Tuesday police discovered three other mail bombs had been delivered to three separate recipients in Jakarta: the founder of the Liberal Islam Network, the head of an anti-terrorism unit, and the chairman of a local youth organization.
Indonesian security officials blame JI for the bombs. The group is responsible for several high profile attacks in Indonesia including the 2002 Bali bombings and the 2009 Marriott and Ritz-Carlton hotel bombings.

A Taliban militant carried out a suicide attack on an Afghan National Army recruitment centre in Kunduz, northern Afghanistan. The explosion killed at least 36 people and injured 40 more.
The militant joined volunteers lined up to register at the centre and then detonated an explosive device. The explosion killed and injured new recruits, army officials and women and children in close proximity.
A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack.The same recruitment centre was attacked by the Taliban in December 2010 when four suicide bombers stormed the building and killed eight soldiers.The target was likely chosen to discourage Afghans from joining the Army at a time when NATO forces are preparing for a handover to Afghan forces in 2014.
The attack continues the trend from February which saw the lethality of Taliban suicide attacks on civilian targets increase.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
In an early morning attack, unidentified militants blew up a section of the 1,000 kilometre long pipeline linking Kirkuk and Ceyhan, on the Mediterranean. The pipeline transfers one quarter of the nations crude oil from Iraq's Kirkuk and Kurdish oil fields to the Turkish port.
The attack happened by the town of Al-Hadr, near Mosul, when gunmen placed explosive devises along the main pipeline conveying oil north from the Baiji refinery. Local sources reported a fire and an oil leak at the site, but no casualties.
The government-run North Oil Company stated that oil flow would be disrupted for four to five days while the damage was repaired. This incident follows two attacks on the Baiji refinery in the past fortnight.

summary:
Militants detonated a roadside bomb and killed five civilians travelling in a car near Selmana in the Djelfa province. The intended target of the attack was unclear.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but the device was likely planted by Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The group typically targets Algerian security forces through roadside bombings and ambushes at checkpoints. Most of its activity in Algeria is typically confined to the northern provinces.
Over the course of 2011, the group has been less active, possibly due to a major offensive by the Algerian army in the north of the country. This is the first major AQIM attack in northern Algeria in around five months.

summary:
At approximately 18:00, a suicide bomber in an explosive-laden vehicle attacked a NATO-led ISAF convoy as it was passing in Bati Kot district, Nangahar province. The bomber is believed to have detonated his explosives before reaching his target.
The military vehicle was damaged but no soldiers inside were injured; a passing civilian was harmed in the explosion. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
A security spokesman noted how the eastern province of Nangahar has witnessed a recent increase in insurgent militancy.

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants planted and detonated an explosive device near a school in Darra Adam Khel. The attack destroyed the building, a local media source reported. No casualties were caused by the blast.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however we strongly suspect the involvement of the TTP, a group which frequently targets schools in the region.

summary:
A passenger van carrying people from the Pir Kok gas field area to Dera Bugti drove over a land mine and caused it to detonate. The explosion killed four people and injured 18 others.
Law enforcement agencies started an investigation and cordoned off the area.
No group claimed responsibility, however both theBalochistan Liberation Army (BLA) and the Baloch Republican army (BRA) are active in the area. The tactic of laying land mines and improvised explosive devices is common throughout Balochistan, however they are usually targeted at security personnel or gas company assets.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) attacked a funeral in Adezai nearPeshawar city, the capital of Pakistans Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province. A suicide bomber detonated himself at the funeral of the wife of a local, pro-government tribal leader. The attack killed 37 people and wounded around 50 others.
The TTP was targeting members of an anti-Taliban militia group called Aman lashkar who is supporting the governments fight against the TTP in the area. A TTP spokesman today confirmed that the group was targeting all those who support U.S. and the Pakistan military.
After the attack local police also found a hand grenade at the scene which was later defused. This incident occurred just one day after a car bomb targeted the offices of the Inter-Services Intelligence agency in Faisalbad, Punjab province. The TTP also claimed responsibility for that attack.
source_urls: CNN; IANS; Geo News (BBC Mon); Xinhua
author: Unknown author

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated an improvised explosive device outside a shop on Lenin Street in Buynaksk, Dagestan. The explosion caused damage to the entrance of the shop, but no injuries were reported.
The device was the equivalent to 40g of TNT.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however the Dagestani Jaamat Sharia is most likely to be responsible.
The majority of attacks in the region are targeted towards law enforcement and security officials.

summary:

Police noticed the unidentified man at a secondary school and approached him to ask for identification. The militant brought out a hand grenade, but as attempted to throw it towards the police it detonated in his hand.
No details of the militants affiliation to any organisation were released. Given the location of the incident it is likely that he was connected to Caucasus Emirate.

summary:
Unidentified militants attempted to bomb Iraqs largest oil refinery in Baiji in the north of the country. Iraqi security forces foiled the plot before any damage was done to the facility which is capable of producing up to 310,000 barrels per day.
Security officials discovered the bomb inside a storage tank in the adjacent town and were able to defuse the explosive soon after. The town of Baiji was a former Al-Qaeda stronghold and insurgents are still known to operate in Sal ad Din province.
This bomb scare follows an attack on the refinery on February 26 2011 by the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI). Militants detonated several bombs which killed four workers and closed the facility for two working days.
author: Unknown author

summary: Suspected Sudan Liberation Army (SLA) rebels killed two soldiers when they ambushed a Sudanese army supply convoy as it headed to its base in Rokuro, Jebel Marra. The territory remains an insurgent stronghold for the rebels despite increasing Sudanese military presence.    The counter attack from the army killed 15 SLA militants. It is believed the rebels were from a faction of the SLA loyal to Abdel Wahed al-Nur.    The mostly non-Arab rebels have been waging a violent revolt against the state after accusing the government of starving the region of resources and genocide.

specific_target: Gas filling station and government offices
summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a vehicle laden with explosives at a gas station in Faisalabad. The explosion killed at least 20 people and injured more than 100 others.
Militants parked the car full of explosives at a filling station that provided natural gas for vehicles. The detonation of the device caused the gas tanks to catch fire creating a large explosion which destroyed the filling station and caused damage to the buildings nearby.
The target of the explosion is unclear, however there are several high profile government buildings in the surrounding area, including a regional office of the Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate.
Over recent years Pakistan's military has been a frequent target for  militants throughout the country, however this is the first attack on a  security institution in Faisalabad.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. There are a number of Islamic militant groups that operate throughout the country. Sipah-e-Sahaba and Lashkar-e-Toiba both operate in neighbouring districts and could have some involvement in the incident.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: An anarchist group in Chile claimed responsibility for a small explosion which took place in La Reina, a neighbourhood in the capital Santiago. The group Clandestine Anti-prison Section Xose Tarrio left several pamphlets at the scene after the morning attack. No injuries were reported although some damage was caused to nearby cars and houses. The home-made devise was made from a fire extinguisher and left between two cars in the residential area. Chile has experienced around 100 bombings since 2004 and most are caused by small, homemade explosive devises which have so far caused no fatalities. The perpetrators of most of these attacks are small anarchist groups sometimes with links to anti-government indigenous movements.
source_urls: ESISC; NOTIMEX; La Nacin- Chile; Latin American Herald Tribune
