summary:
Unidentified militants carried out two attacks in Sa Sakhon, injuring at least two civilians and five policemen.
The first attack occurred when militants reported to be riding on a motorcycle threw a hand grenade at a grocery shop injuring the owner and a policeman.
The militants then detonated an explosive device in a car targeted at soldiers of Narathiwat Task Force, as they rushed to the scene of the first attack. The car was parked under a recently built block of police flats and caused significant damage to the building as well as setting fire to 18 cars.
No group claimed responsibility. The New Pattani United Liberation Organisation (PULO) is highly active in the are and we strongly suspect this group to be involved in the attack. The PULO frequently targets police personnel in the region.

specific_target: Provincial Council Members, Religious Figures and Police
summary:
Taliban militants conducted a twin bomb attack in the eastern city of Jalalabad, Nangahar Province, which killed two people and injured at least a further 22. Local news sources reported that the first of the blasts took place at 11:00 near to the Iqbah mosque, and when police arrived at the scene a second device was detonated at 11:20.
Members of the police force made up the bulk of the casualties. It is believed that a meeting of provincial council members and religious scholars was taking place in the Mosque at the time of the explosions, which suggests that they may have been the initial target.
The attack followed operations of similar sophistication in the area over recent weeks. A bank in Jalalabad was the site of a major suicide operation which targeted both civilians and police officials and caused 38 deaths and a further 70 casualties. The city has seen an upsurge in terrorist violence since the turn of the year, with this latest incident the fifth bombing and third mass casualty attack.
source_urls: Tolo News, Afghan Islamic Press, Associated Foreign Press, Monsters and Critics, Associated Press of Canada
targets: Religious Institutions; Government/Political ; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces

summary:

A security official stated that the abducted men may have been transported to Bangladesh where the NLFT has several base camps.
The banned NLFT is a militant separatist group fighting for an independent Tripura homeland based on the Christian faith.

summary:
A small pipe bomb exploded in the Derech Hebron area of Jerusalem,and injured two men. The device was concealed in a garbage bag on a central traffic island and detonated when a sanitation worker collected the receptacle. The man lost his arm in the blast and another victim suffered minor injury.
No group claimed responsibility for the bomb, though local sources stated that based on the type of device police believed terrorists were responsible.
The incident represents the first terrorist attack in the capital in over a year, and came days after the Israeli military bombed an infiltration tunnel and two other sites in Gaza following militants' rocket attacks upon Western Negev early on Saturday.

summary:
Suspected Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) militants killed a senior military official in a targeted armed attack in the city of Sayun in Hadramaut governorate. The victim was shot in the head outside a restaurant by two assailants on a motorcycle and died at the scene, while his attackers fled.
AQAP did not claim responsibility for the attack, though based upon its targeted nature and location we strongly suspect the group's involvement.
The group has established a considerable presence in Marib, Abyan and Hadramaut. An incident occurred in every governorate on the same day.
The attacks came against a backdrop of mounting pressure on President Saleh's government, as the country's opposition movement vowed to increase the intensity of its protests.

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban - Pakistan (TTP) militants killed one tribesmen, injured seven and kidnapped two others when they launched an armed attack upon a checkpoint of the pro-government 'peace commitee' in Manzari China in Mohmand. The assailants attacked the post with rockets and automatic weapons. Tthe two sides reportedly exchanged fire for three hours.
Peace committees of pro-government tribesmen were established in Mohmand Agency to help security forces fight the Taliban and they have suffered deadly attacks at the hands of militants on a number of occasions previously.
In December last year, a Taliban suicide bomber hit the office of a local administrator in Mohmand and killed almost 60 people and wounded an additional 90. Prior to that, in July, over 50 people died in a similar attack in the same region. A number of local people have fled the Agency following large-scale government operations against the Taliban.

summary:
During Saturday night, suspected New People's Army (NPA) militants attacked and destroyed two buses on the Island province of Biliran. The attack killed two bus drivers who were asleep in the vehicles at the time.
The militants broke into the depot and poured petrol over the buses before lighting them. It is unknown whether they were aware of the two men asleep inside. Police started an investigation and arrested two suspects at a checkpoint.
A police spokesman suggested the arson was in connection with NPA extortion. It is thought that the group fund their activities by forcing rural businesses 'revolutionary taxes.'
Biliran had not been subject to insurgent attack before the incident. The NPA rejected peace negotiations with the government in Norway after the first round last month.

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) terrorists exploded a bomb at a mosque that is located in the compound of the shrine of a revered saint in Akbarpura village, Nowshera district. The explosion killed at least 11 people and injured 40 others occurred after afternoon prayers as people were eating lunch.
Militants had hidden a time-device bomb, which has set to explode after prayers had finished. The device, had been hidden in a shoe rack, contained over 2kgs of explosives and ball bearings.   No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. But both the Punjabi Taliban, a conglomeration of groups which includes Laskhar-e-Jhangvi and Lashkar-e-Toiba, and the TTP have recently conducted attacks against shrines and religious minorities in towns and cities across Pakistan.Based on the location of the attack, we suspect that the TTP was responsible.
This incident occurred as the Pakistani military is conducting an offensive directed against the TTP in neighbouring Mohmand province.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Local media reported that the bomb was thrown from a passing vehicle.
The explosion killed at least ten people and wounded 21 others.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Ethnic, cultural and religious tensions have recently spilled over in to violence in recent months, however terrorist groups could not be ruled out.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen ambushed a Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) patrol in the west side of Derry/Londonderry. The PSNI officers were investigating a suspected stolen car near to Saint Annes Primary School in Upper Nassau   street when the gunmen opened fire on them. No casualties were reported.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack however police sources reported that dissident Irish Republican Army terrorists were most likely involved.
A splinter group calling itself the Oglaigh nah Eireann (ONH) have openly rejected the ceasefire agreed in 2005 by mainstream IRA groups and throughout 2010 the ONH was involved in armed attacks and bombings of police and British army personnel. We suspect the group could have conducted this shooting.

Sahwa members are frequently targeted by Sunni militant factions linked to the Islamic State of Iraq. We suspect one such group of this attack.

summary:
At 19:30, unidentified assailants detonated an improvised explosive device in Antananarivo, Madagascar's capital city. The explosion hit the convoy of President Andry Rajoelina who was returning home from the presidential palace. No casualties were reported and no vehicles were damaged.
Police sources later said that the rudimentary bomb comprised of explosives, 150m of wire and a timer. Given that the device was detonated by a timer this suggests that the perpetrators were familiar with the presidents schedule.
 
President Rajoelina came to power in March 2009 after ousting the elected former president Marc Ravalomanana with the help of the Madagascan military. Opposition groups rejected a proposal from Southern African Development Community mediators that Rajoelina stay as head of a transitional administration until elections that should be held by November.
The timing of the bombing was significant. On the previous day 2 March, Rajoelina's transition authority had come to an agreement with other political players on a roadmap to end the two year old crisis. The attack may have been perpetrated by political actors opposed to the agreement.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and Lashkar-e-Islam militants are known to be active in the area, and either group could have been responsible for this attack.

Frankfurt Airport is the second largest airport in Europe. The US military has several bases around the city which it uses as a hub for operations primarily in Afghanistan and Iraq.

summary:
At 11:15 on Wednesday, Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan militants assassinated the Pakistani Minister for Minorities Shahbaz Bhatti, in Islamabad. Three or four gunmen riding in a car stopped Bhatti's vehicle when it left his home in the I-8 area of the city, and then shot him.
After the shooting, the minister was taken to a nearby hospital where he diedfrom his injuries. The TTP claimed immediate responsibility for the assassination stating that Bhatti was targeted because of his opposition to the nation's blasphemy laws. Bhatti, the only Christian in Pakistan's cabinet, was an outspoken critic of the law and hoped to amend it.
This incident follows the assassination of Governor Salman Taseer in January. The governor was another outspoken opponent of Pakistan's blasphemy laws. He was shot and killed by his disgruntled bodyguard who opposed the governor's stance on the law.

The group was on the second day of the CPI-M strike launched to protest the killing of CPI-M members by police forces the previous week.
The riot began when the group burned three jeeps belonging to the irrigation department and destroyed a nearby building. They also bulldozed a school and an inspection bungalow belonging to the department of water resources.

summary:
Unidentified attackers killed several members of one family in the town of Dabwak, near the city of Jos. The assailants killed up to six individuals when they attacked the property with automatic weapons and machetes.
The event happened in the Plateau State, where the county's Muslim majority north and Christian majority south meet. The area has witnessed years of ethnic tension and violence, especially in the city of Jos.
Boko Haram -- and Islamist militant group -- is active in the area and frequently conducts attacks. Based on the location of this incident, we suspect Boko Haram was responsible for this incident.

summary:

Security officials said that AQAP used a new tactic in this attack. The militants were dressed in Central security uniforms and approached the checkpoint on foot.
This attack is directly connected to another incident inthe nearby neighbourhood of Ja'ar that occurred on the same evening. AQAP militants attacked the military vehicle transporting the wounded to a nearby hospital.
AQAP frequently attack soldiers and security personnel in hit-and-run attacks.

summary:

Police officials are debating the involvement of Boko Haram. One official blamed the attack on armed robbers although another witness noted that nothing had been stolen from the house. Local media blamed Boko Haram.
If this attack is proved to be conducted by Boko Haram it would indicate the groups expansion out of its two main areas of operation: the Borno and Baluchi states. Two policemen were killed in Borno state by suspected Boko Haram members two days later.

The incident follows a series of similar events. The previous week saw missiles strike the cities of Be'er Sheva and Netivot for the first time in two years.

This is not the first attack on the paper, with a bombing of the publication's printers in 2001 and an assassination of one of their journalists in 1996.

summary:
A suspected militant attack on Iraq's biggest oil refinery, Baiji, killed two people and stopped oil production. The terrorists stormed the site in Salaheddin, north of Baghdad with firearms, before staging a bombing.
The attacks comes after anti-government protests in several of Iraq's major cities.
The bombing caused a fire which badly damaged the installation. The refinery is one of three major installations in Iraq, with the others in Baghdad and Basra in the south. It processes around 150,000 barrels of oil per day. Officials claim that fixing it will take a very long time, since the damage was severe.
Militants linked to the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) are the most likely suspect, since it is active in the area, and used to control the refinery, using the proceeds of it to fund major attacks.

There has been a recent increase in incidents targeting the security forces, as Afghan security forces prepare to take over their security responsibilities from US-led forces. Some participants identified the terrorist and then fled the scene, therefore avoiding even great casualty figures.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists planted an improvised explosive device (IED) under a gas pipeline in Sochi's Adlerskiy district. After security forces discovered the device bomb disposal experts defused it.
The IED was found on the Gazprom-owned Maykop-Samurskaya-Sochi trunk gas pipeline close to Sochi, the site of the 2014 Winter Olympic Games. The IED comprised of a cylinder filled with 110 grams of triacetopne triperoxide and a rudimentary igniting fuse.
No group admitted to planting the device. The discovery came in the same week that militants killed three Muscovite tourists as they travelled to a ski resort in Kabardin-Balkaria, and bombed a cable car at another ski resort the next day.
The weeks' attacks appear to be part of a concerted campaign to deter foreign investment in the five new North Caucasus ski resorts that President Medvedev announced at the World Economic Forum in January. Two days before his speech, which encouraged private investment in Russia's winter sport tourism industry, a suicide bomber attacked tourists and international travelers at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport.

The pipeline was not transporting crude oil at the time and exports were not affected. The pipeline, the longest in Colombia, is operated by Ecopetrol and Occidental Petroleum.
Oil and gas infrastructure remain common terrorist targets in Colombia, despite a significant decrease in violence.

This incident came two days after a mortar bomb exploded at the Mandera District Hospital and a day after eight people were severely injured when they were hit by stray bullets in the Bulawayo area of the city.
The Kenyan government expanded its security presence in the city in response to the growing threat to the local people.

summary:

The attack, which involved over two dozen assailants armed with automatic weapons and rockets, killed five people, including two guards. Police officials said the militants planted timed explosive devices under a dozen tankers, and in total damaged 15 vehicles.
According to reports, police later found four grenades and bombs at the terminal and defused them.
The trucks were transporting fuel to NATO forces in Afghanistan. A police official stated that the militants fled shortly after the attack. No group claimed responsibility although Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan has claimed similar attacks in the past.
Militants in the region frequently target supply trucks in an effort to destabilize US and NATO efforts. The attack follows a series of similar incidents along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border this year.

summary:
Al-Shabaab militants seriously injured eight people in Bulawayo, an area of Mandera town in north-east Kenya. The victims were hit by stray bullets from across the border in Somalia, where militants had been fighting Transitional Federal Government (TFG) forces with automatic weapons and mortars since the previous evening.
Local news sources reported that TFG troops also repulsed an attempted incursion by Al-Shabaab militants in Bulawayo soon after the incident.
Mandera lies on the three-nation border between Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia. The Kenyan government moved quickly to deploy additional security personnel to the region in response to the escalation of the conflict in neighbouring Somalia.
Many fled southwards from Mandera, fearful of their safety in light of the close proximity of intense fighting. Schools, government offices and hospitals closed due to the frequency of stray fire.

TTP members have destroyed hundreds of schools in the Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa area over the past three years. The schools' province borders the Mohmand tribal region where military operations are currently ongoing against the TTP.

Chaman is a major crossing point for NATO supplies which travel from Pakistans main port city of Karachi to NATO troops in Afghanistan. Terrorists affiliated to Al-Qaeda-linked groups often target NATO convoys bound for Afghanistan.
Though no group claimed responsibility for the attack, given the tactics and target we suspect the Tehrik-e-Taliban-Pakistan of involvement.

summary:
Suspected terrorists fired two Grad rockets at the Israeli city of Beer Sheva. At least one rocket hit a residential area and damaged a house. No casualties were reported.The attack was the first time since the Gaza War in 2009 that a rocket had hit the city.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack but small terrorist groups operating without the sanction of Hamas, the ruling authority in Gaza could have beeninvolved.
Throughout 2010 Hamas has struggledto prevent smaller Gaza-based terrorist factions from firingrockets into Israel. The Army of Islam has fired numerous into Israel over recent months, and in retaliation Israeli security forces assassinated senior leader of the group in August and November 2010.
The group subsequently released a threat in Hebrew to avenge the killings of its leaders.

summary:

Police officials stated that damage was limited and that the incident did not disrupt business. It was the second time in less than a year that militants had left a bomb on the railway line.
No group claimed the attack, but similar incidents in the past have been attributed to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (ELN).

The militants withdrew after soldiers returned fire on their positions.No group claimed responsibility.
Since 2004 there has been a revival of militant activity in the three southern provinces of Yala, Pattani, and Narathiwat. Over recent months seperatist Islamist insurgents have increased the frequnecy of their attacks on both civilan targets and the security forces. The militants aim to drive the Buddhist population out of the three provinces, which is the only Muslim majority region in Thailand.

Over recent days, clashes between Transitional Federal Government (TFG) forces and Al-Shabaab have intensified in neighbouring Somalia and Mandera, which is close to the border lines of both Ethiopia and Somalia, has been hit with stray bullets.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Both the Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) and the Tehrik-e-Taliban - Pakistan (TTP) are known to be active in Quetta.
The incident came the day after militants targeted a police patrol with a roadside bomb in the city. Attacks upon security personnel have become more frequent in Quetta over recent months, with this operation the the third in 8 days in which they have been targeted.

summary:

ATMM claimed that they targeted the official because of his involvement in financial irregularities.
In response to the murder, government employees shut all offices in Bara on 23 February and all employees of the Land Revenue Ministry halted work for two hours in protest.
ATMM is a communist group which seeks an independent state for the Madhesi people of the Terai region. The organisation evolved out of the Janatanrik Terai Mukti-Morcha Goit (JTMM-G), which formed after separation from the Communist Party of Nepal - Maoist (CPN-M). The ATMM conducts only sporadic attacks.

Security forces responded by firing heavy artillery on suspected terrorist hideouts in the area. Unconfirmed reports claimed that eight terrorists were killed in the artillery barrage.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack however given the location and type of attack, Al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups were suspected of involvement. The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan and Lashkar-e-Islam are both active the neighbouring Kurram Agency.

Militants used bombs and rocket launchers to attack the post and stole riffles. The attack casued damage to two vehicles.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated multiple explosive devices at the headquarters of the governorship candidate for the Labour party in Bayelsa State. The explosion caused damage to the building but no injuries were reported.
The attack occurred two months before nationwide and state elections. Poll-related violence is expected to increase in the run-up to the elections. The labour Party campaign offices were attacked in January, following the state governorship primaries.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:

It is likely that the owner of the car was the direct target of the attack: militants factions across Iraq frequently target members of the Awakening Councils, who are credited in part with turning the tide of the Sunni insurgency.

summary:
Militants attached to the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) organisation shot and killed a man in Jhargram in the West Midnapore area of West Bengal for allegedly spying for local police.
Maoist posters were found near to the body which stated that the deceased was a corrupt CPI-M worker who had worked as an informer for the police.
Local security sources stated that the CPI-M is active in three regions of West Bengal; West Midnapore, Purulia and Bankura. Attacks have increased in Jhargram in February, with this incident the third armed assault recorded.

summary:
An armed attack by suspected Islamist separatists, in the Khasavyurt region of Dagestan republic, killed two women and injured a five-year old girl. The assailants opened fire on the women, both of whom were fortune tellers who local sources reported had previously been threatened by militants, because of their 'heretic' activities.
One of the perpetrators was believed to have been killed later in the evening by security officials.
No official claim of responsibility was lodged for the attack, however given its location and target, we strongly suspect the involvement of the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia.
Militants attached to the organisation have previously conducted attacks aimed at targets deemed 'un-Islamic' such as shops which sell pork and alcohol.

summary:

No group claimed responsibility for the attack but based on its location and the chosen target we strongly suspect the involvement of the Yarmuk Jamaat, a militant group affiliated with the Caucasus Emirate.
The incident took place the day after unidentified gunmen conducted an armed attack aimed at tourists travelling to the region's main ski resort.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Russian bomb disposal experts successfully defused three explosive devices equivalent in power to 70kg of TNT close to the Novy Povorot hotel near to Mount Elbus in Kabardino-Balkaria. The explosives were concealed within a VAZ-2110 silver car located in a car-park.
A spokesman for the Republic's law-enforcement agencies said that 'if the bombs had detonated, according to specialists' estimates, it would have been impossible to avoid a considerable number of victims and considerable destruction'. A counter-terrorism regime was subsequently imposed in the Elbrus area and part of Baksan district at 10:00 the following day.
No group claimed responsibility for planting the devices, however it is highly probable that militants affiliated with the Caucasus Emirate were responsible.
The incidents have further undermined Russia's $15 billion proposal to build five ski-resorts in the insurgency hit North Caucasus.
source_urls: Reuters, Associated Press, RIA Novosti, Business Week
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Yarmuk Jamaat, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected militants linked to the Caucasus Emirate ambushed a mini-van as it transported Russian tourists to Baksan ski-resort in the Zakuyovo area of Kabardino-Balkaria.
The assailants approached the vehicle in a black car with no number plates and after forcing it from the road, demanded to see the passengers passports. After the production of the documents they opened fire upon the vehicle with automatic weapons. Two men and a woman were killed whilst two others were injured.
The Caucasus Emirate claimed the attack and stated upon its website that the tourists were targeted because 'they came into the zone of war'.
The Baksan ski-resort is located near to Mount Elbrus, the centrepiece of Russia's recently announced $15 billion chain of resorts across the North Caucasus. It is most likely that this attack is part of a campaign to discredit the Kremlin's plans and dissuade tourists from venturing into the region.
source_urls: Reuters, Associated Foreign Press, The Moscow Times
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Caucasus Emirate, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

Police killed three assailants and arrested a man who blew his arm off after attempting to throw an improvised explosive device at the police station.
The Bauchi police commissioner said the militants aimed to rob the bank, and attacked the police station to create a distraction / prevent police officers from stopping the robbery.
The militants reportedly failed in their attempt to steal any money.
The attack came one month after the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) released a security alert which warned all bank chief executives that a terrorist group was planning to attack banks to raise funds for their operations.

summary:
Unidentified militants attacked an electricity tower in the Ghaffar Goht area of Nasirabad in a bomb attack. The assailants attached explosives to two 220kv electricity towers, with bomb disposal experts defusing the second device, equivalent in power to 15kg of TNT, prior to its detonation. There were no reports of casualties or fatalities.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Local organisations such as the Baloch Republican Army (BRA) and the Balochistan Liberationa Army (BLA) are known to conduct sabotage attacks upon infrastructure throughout the region.
The BRA and BLA are separatist groups which seek greater autonomy from Islamabad and, amongst other demands, a more considerable share of revenue generated from the region's abundant oil and gas supplies. They have conducted a spate of pipeline attacks in recent weeks.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Militants suspected of affiliation with either the Balochistan Liberation Army (BLA) or the Baloch Republican Army (BRA) conducted a bomb attack upon a gas pipeline in the Dera Murad Jamali district of Nasirabad.
Assailants placed a home-made explosive device upon the 18-inch diameter pipeline, which supplied gas to nine of Balochistan's districts, before they detonated it remotely. Officials from the Sui Southern Gas Company confirmed the attack but said it caused no casualties.
The attack was timed to coincide with the restoration of supply to Balochistan after militant operations the previous week had targeted infrastructure elsewhere.
The BLA and BRA are separatist groups seeking autonomy from the Pakistani government in Islamabad and greater share of revenue generated from Balochistan'ssupply of oil and gas. The organisations have initiated a sustained campaign of sabotage attacks upon the region's pipelines.
area: Dera Murad Jamali, Nasirabad,  Balochistan Province
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Balochistan Republic Army, perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

Two improvised explosive devices were detonated and though no casualties were reported, train services were suspended immediately as bomb disposal experts scoured the area for further bombs.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. However, the Baloch Republican Army bombed another area of track elsewhere in the region three days earlier, and we feel their involvement highly probable.
area: Odero Laal Railway Station, Matiari, Sindh Province
author: Unknown author

summary:

The suicide bomber approached a police station in the village, and when stopped by one of the guards, detonated the device. The assailant, identified as Mariya Khorosheva, was wanted in connection with the explosion in a Moscow hotel room on 31 December 2010.
No group claimed the attack. Gubden is known to have links to an insurgency aimed at building an Islamic state across Russia's Northern Caucasus which includes Dagestan and several other provinces.

No group claimed responsibility, but attacks aimed at police and security personnel is common in the North Caucasus republics of Dagestan, Chechnya and Ingushetia.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary: Insurgents detonated a car bomb in Yala, southern Thailand, and injured 18 people. The explosives were hidden in a fire extinguisher, and planted in a pick-up truck parked outside a grocery shop near Siam City Bank. The militants detonated the bomb with remote control as a military patrol passed by.  The ensuing fire took several hours to be extinguished.  Yala is part of the region near the Malaysian border that has been under emergency rule since 2005. Violence in the south escalated in the preceding months; several people were shot and killed a few days earlier in neighbouring Pattani province.

summary:
A teenage suicide bomber detonated his explosive vest amongst soldiers during their morning exercise routine atthePakistani training camp in Mardan. The powerful explosion killed 27 soldiers and wounded 40 others.
The suicide bomber was a teenage boy dressed in a school uniform which matched that of the civilian school near the military compound. Authorities suspect that a thick layer of clothing helped the bomber enter the facility undetected despite a heavy security presence.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has claimed the attack. The TTP has a long history of recruiting teenagers to carry out suicide attacks against specific targets in the region.
In 2009, the Pakistani army rescued several teenagers from TTP training camps,where it was thought they were being indoctrinated and trained to become suicide bombers.
Despite increased offensives against the TTP and other militants in the region, the Pakistani security forces have been relatively unsuccessful in preventing mass-casualty attacks in the area.
source_urls: Dawn; AFP; Los Angeles Times; The Nation
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) terrorists shot dead three people suspected of spying on the TTP. Three bodies were found in the Esuri area of Mir Ali tehsil, 35km east of Miramshah. Two of the victims were confirmed to be khasadars (tribal policemen).

The TTP often murders suspects accused of spying in a bid to foment terror amongst the civilian population.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a string of low-intensity bombs near police and security targets in the high security People's Colony area of Gujranwala, though no casualties were reported.
Two of the devices were planted outside the city's Central Investigation Centre. The third blast took place outside the offices of the Superintendent of Police (Special Branch) and the fourth explosion occurred in a police rest house near the office of the city police chief.
One local report stated that a fifth bomb planted outside the Central Investigation Centre was defused.
No group claimed responsibility for the devices, with the location of their placement raising significant concerns of a breach in internal security and the worries regarding the apparent ease with which militants were able to penetrate a secure zone.
This incident took place ten days after the disappearance in Punjab of 140 suspected terrorists. Attacks only occur sporadically in the region; the last recorded incident of terrorist violence was an assassination attempt which took place on 9 December 2010.
source_urls: Express Tribune, The Nation, Dawn, Xinhua, APP

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a bomb planted in a donkey cart at a cattle market in the northwestern town of Charsadda. The blast killed one person and wounded five others, with the deceased identified as the owner of the cart.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) operates in the town and could have been responsible.
Terrorist violence is fairly uncommon in Charsadda, with this incident the first recorded bomb attack since 10 November 2009 and only the seventh operation in the last two years. The most recent prior to this was a targeted armed assault aimed at police officers on 13 December 2010.

summary:
Shia Houthis fired three mortar shells into the non-residental Othman market area in the south of Sa'dah, in an attack which killed three people and wounded one other. Local security sources stated that the shells were aimed at a local chieftain, who is the most prominent anti-rebel leader in the region.
A spokesman for the Houthis denied their involvement, though given the location of the attack we strongly suspect they were responsible.
Othman market is controlled by a pro-government tribe of the General People's Congress (GPC) parliamentary member Othman Mujally, who had resisted rebel demands to place the area under their control.
Disputes between the Houthis and the pro-government tribe escalated in January, and lead to fierce clashes between the two groups.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) detonated two explosions causing damage to the Trans-Andean pipeline in the southwestern Narino Department. No injuries were reported.
The first explosion occurred near to the Guarchavez municipality, while the second took place in the Purres sector.
No group claimed the attack, however we strongly suspect FARC was responsible. The area along the Ecuadorian border is a well known stronghold for the group and FARC militants have sabotaged the Trans-Andean pipeline in previous attacks, most recently August 2010.
The attack supports claims that oil and power lines have become FARC targets to create chaos and deter potential investors bringing security forces into the region.

The married couple were travelling by motorbike to a rubber plantation in Baro. Two men also on motorbike followed the couple and the pillion passenger opened fire on them using a 9mm pistol. The militants fled following the attack.
Due to the number of groups operating in the ongoing Islamist insurgency in the south, it is hard to determine exactly which group was responsible. Armed attacks, especially against Buddhists, are common in the region.

Balkh province is on of Afghanistan's more peaceful provinces where such Taliban attacks are rare.

No group claimed responsibility, however based upon the location and intended target we suspect Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan of involvement. This is the third incident in two weeks where police have been targeted in Peshawar, taking the casualty total to 16 for the three attacks.

summary:

Security personnel used robots to defuse the bombs after the residents from homes nearby, were evacuated.
No group claimed responsibility for planting the devices, but we suspect the most active group in the Republic, the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia, was involved.

summary:
Taliban militants shot the acting head of Bak District in Khost Province while he was on his way to work. Mohammed died instantly. No other injuries were reported in the attack.
The militants carried out the shooting from a car and drove away. The Taliban reported after the incident that they killed the acting head because of his support to the government and NATO-led forces in Afghanistan.
This is the fifth incident of the year in Khost province, but the first targeted political assassination.

summary:
A Taliban suicide bomber killed one person and injured a further five when he detonated his explosives vest inside a customs house filled with US and Afghan troops in the city of Kandahar. Local security sources stated that the deceased was an Afghan interpreter who had been working with American forces and NATO announced that amongst the casualties were two International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) soldiers.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the operation and Kandahar is known as a key base of the southern insurgency. Despite the US and NATO having claimed significant gains, attacks still occur regularly in the south's largest city. On 4 February Taliban militants launched a suicide operation which targeted the provincial Chief of Police and six days earlier the Deputy Governor was killed in a suicide attack.
Of the eight terrorist assaults which have taken place in Kandahar since the turn of the year, 50% targeted police facilities or personnel. This attack represented the first of 2011 aimed at military forces in the province.

The attacks came on the day the CPI-M called a shutdown in many states to protest the rising prices of essential commodities and corruption of the country. The CPI-M often target railways as a means of further disrupting daily life in the areas in which the group is active.

summary:
A suspected member of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) detonated an explosives belt when Mauritanian security forces surrounded him in the southern region of Brakna. Another militant was arrested at the scene but no other casualties or fatalities were reported.
The pair were discovered after local people alerted the security forcesto their whereabouts. The Senegalese authorities had increased security along their border to prevent the terrorists from leaving Mauritania.
Local news sources reported that the two men were among those who had entered the country from Mali the previous week, and sought to conduct terror attacks in Nouakchott. A large scale operation in the capital was narrowly averted by security forces on 2 February.
AQIM continues to operate in Algeria but is also taking advantage of the vast and lawless desert regions of Mauritania, Mali and Niger. Despite efforts to crackdown on militant activity the group acquires large amounts of funding in 2011 through the kidnap and ransom of foreigners.

summary:
Early this morning, unidentified saboteurs attacked a gas pipeline in Al-Arish in the northern Sinai Peninsula. The Egyptian authorities have said the explosion was a terrorist attack.
Egyptian state media reported that gas supplies to Israel and Jordan were cut due to the explosion.
The explosion came as large anti-government rallies are threatening to topple the Egyptian governnment. We suspect that Egptian officials might have been quick to blame the attack on terrorist factions in a bid to demonstrate that chaos would ensue if the government fell. However, if this was a terrorist incident, it is most likely the work of Bedouin tribes in the Sinai, who have made threats against oil and gas interests in the region in the past.

summary:

No group claimed responsibility for the operation, which as with the bulk of attacks by Iraq's insurgents, appears to have been an effort to undermine confidence in the ability of the provincial government and security personnel to protect the local people.
This was only the second attack of 2011 in Ramadi; the other incident was a targeted bomb operation on 17 January aimed at the governor of the province.

summary:
Six armed men, riding in a pick-up truck, opened fire on Buddhists in Khok Krabue village in Pattani's Panare district. The assailants killed five people and injured four others in the attack.
The attack occurred shortly after the village defence volunteers had finished their nightly shift, and before the afternoon guards had begun their duties. Armed with machine guns and pistols, two of the assailants leftthe vehicle and fired at passer-by and villagers. The other four men fired from the vehicle, which fled following the attack.
Due to the number of groups operating in the ongoing Islamist insurgency in southern Thailand, it is difficult to determine which group was responsible. The militants' goals are the complete Islamization of southern Thailand, and the eradication of Buddhistsand their temples. Such attacks are aimed at driving Buddhists in near-by villagers out ofNarathiwat, Yala and Pattani.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated an improvised explosive device outside the Baba Haider Sayeen shrine near Minar-e-Pakistan in Lahore. The explosion occurred as large numbers of worshippers paid their respects to the Sufi saint at the shrine. The attack outside the shrine's main entrance killed three people and injured at least 22 others.
No group claimed the attack,and accounts differ as to whether the device was timed, or thrown from a truck. What is clear, is that the attack was timed to maximise the number of casualties, and was aimed at worshippers outside the shrine who were sharing food.
Based on the target and location of the attack, we suspect Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ) was responsible. LeJ is aPunjabi-based terrorist group that has carried out numerous sectarian attacks on religious minorities in Pakistan.On 28 May, LeJ gunmen killed 93 worshippers at two Ahmadi mosques in Lahore in coordinated attacks using automatic weapons, grenades and suicide vests. The attacks took place during Friday prayers in a bid to maximise casualties. The sectarian attack was the most lethal to date against Ahmadis in Pakistan.

summary:
At approximately 03:00, Mauritanian security forces prevented a large-scale suicide attack in Nouakchott by firing a shell at an explosive-laden Toyota Land Cruiser approximately eight miles outside the city. The resulting blast killed three suspected Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) militants, and injured eight Mauritanian soldiers.
 
Security personnel were aware that a three vehicle convoy had entered the country from  Mali on 28 February, and began pursuit on 1 February. The army captured one of the vehicles in the town of R'kiz and arrested its driver, a suspected AQIM member. During interrogation the assailant reportedly revealed that the convoy planned to conduct a major attack in Nouakchott.
After receipt of this information security forces were subsequently able to track the vehicles, and prevent the suspected suicide attack. The third vehicle was later found abandoned. It was not clear if it was carrying explosives.
AQIM claimed responsibility for the attempted attack in a telephone call to an Islamist website and stated that the intended target was the Mauritanian president, whose government has actively pursued militants affiliated with the organisation.
This attempted assault was similar in nature to a foiled suicide operation on 25 August 2010, when AQIM militants attempted to drive an explosives-laden vehicle into an army barracks in the eastern town of Nema, near the Malian border. Security forces prevented that attack in the same way; by firing at the vehicle before it reached its destination.
AQIM funds its activities through the kidnapping and ransom of foreigners. The abduction of two French nationals in Niamey, Niger's capital, on 7 January was the latest example of a trend which has rendered the stretch of Saharan desert spanning Mauritania, Mali and Niger an effective no-go area.

Amongst those killed was the head of the local Jafferabad station. Local news sources reported that the initial death toll was believed to be five, but one of those thought to be dead, subsequently reported for work. 
No group claimed responsibility for the assault.
Both the Balochistan Liberation Army (BLA) and Baloch Republican Army (BRA) regularly conduct attack in Pakistan's largest province. The groups seek greater political autonomy from Islamabad and an increased share of the profits from the region's substantial natural resources. The Taliban is also known to conduct attacks in the province.

summary:
Suspected Taliban militants detonated an explosive device in a busy market near to a police station in Peshawar, in an attack which killed nine people and wounded at least 20 others. The timed bomb, equivalent to between 40-45kg of TNT in power, had been planted in a parked car. The blast resulted in considerable material damage to other vehicles and nearby buildings.
Local security sources confirmed that the intended target was the police station, but stated that a combination of the time bound nature of the device and congestion in the area, resulted in the vehicle being abandoned on the approach to the facility. As a result, all of the dead or injured were civilians.
No official claim of responsibility was recorded, however based upon the location and the intended target we strongly suspect Tehrik-e-Taliban - Pakistan (TTP) of involvement. The group conducted a suicide attack aimed at police in Peshawar earlier in the week which caused five fatalities, and law enforcement officials, along with security personnel, are frequently targeted by the organisation.
The city is located near the restive tribal border regions of Pakistan, and despite claims by senior security personnel in December 2010 that authorities had 'broken the back' of the local insurgency attacks continue to take place regularly.
source_urls: Reuters, Associated Foreign Press, IANS, Associated Press
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Civilians/General Public

summary:
Suspected Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants detonated an explosive device on a bridge near the town of Anori in Antioquia department. No casualties or fatalities were reported.
The precise location of the device was not known, with local news sources uncertain whether it had been attached to a truck which was crossing the bridge or if it was inadvertently triggered by the vehicle as it passed.
The 'La Union' bridge is located on the main road which links the towns of Anori and Guadalupe. Local security officials confirmed that they had suspected FARC was planning an attack on a bridge, but were unaware of the exact location.
The incident appeared to be timed to cause maximum disruption, as it took place taking when approximately 5,500 displacedcivilianswho had left their homes following FARC threats, began to return.
Some local sources suggested the attack may have been a response to a recent security operation in the region in which a large number of explosives, landmines and semi-automatic weapons were seized. The bomb assault represented the second use of such weaponry by FARC since the turn of the year.
perpetrators: Colombia:Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC):Far Left/Revolutionary

No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however given the identity of the victims we strongly suspect Islamist separatist insurgents to have been the perpetrators.Three main insurgent groups operate in Thailand's three southernmost provinces, the Barisan Revolusi Nasional Coordinate (BRN-C), the New Pattani United Liberation Organisation (PULO), and Gerakan Mujahideen Islam Pattani (GMIP).
However, given the geographical spread of these organisations it is difficult to pinpoint exactly which was responsible for this incident.

summary:
Suspected Boko Haram militants assassinated a Deputy Superintendent of police and also killed his daughter in an armed attack in Maiduguri, the capital of Borno State. The official, who was in Maiduguri to offer his condolences to the family of a man killed in the state's continuing violence, was trailed by assailants on motorcycle to a fuel station before they opened fire on him and his daughter.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. However its clear similarities to previous operations by the Islamist group Boko Haram, suggests that the perpetrators may have been affiliated with the organisation.
Maiduguri is known as a Boko Haram stronghold and this incident represented the fifth recorded case of terrorist violence in the province since the turn of the year. The ANPP gubernatorial candidate and the brother of the current incumbent were both killed in an armed attack on 29 January.
The Borno State Governor subsequently stated that the attack was beyond the capability of Boko Haram and likely undertaken by assassins hired by political opponents, however given that the incident, like this one, bore all the hallmarks of previous assaults by the militant organisation, it is probable that this statement emerged from political considerations.

The exact location of the incident was not recorded, and whilst there was only one fatality, an unconfirmed number of the victim's bodyguards also suffered casualties. The deceased was the brother of a police commander responsible for a local security station.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, which was the ninth operation to target law enforcement personnel or facilities since the turn of the year, and the second incident overall in Baghlan province. Almost 80% of assaults aimed at police in January incorporated the use of explosives, with this incident one of only two in which firearms were the weaponry of choice, an clear indication that a specific target had been identified.

In December, Boko Haram's leader Shekau announced that the group would increase its attacks on 'non-Muslim' targets in Nigeria.In the days following his declaration, militants attacked churches in the country's north and the authorities reportedly uncovered a large strike on a Christian target being prepared for New Year's Eve.

summary:
Unidentified militants launched dual bomb attacks upon a Mobikom-Kavkaz cellular base station and a transformer station at the same facility in the Levashinskiy District of Dagestan. The blast from the device placed under the base station caused a hole with diameter of 157cm and a depth of 35cm, and it along with the transformer station which powered it, was completely destroyed. Whilst the attack caused no casualties or fatalities, damage has been estimated at 4 million roubles.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though given its location we deem it highly probable that Dagestani Jamaat Sharia was involved.
Operations which target business occur relatively frequently in Dagestan, with this incident the fourth such attack of its kind in the republic since the turn of the year. At least one of these can be seen to have had sectarian motivations, though in this case it would appear that outright sabotage was the intended, and achieved, goal. Following this incident, assaults targeting business in Dagestan in January can be seen to have increased by 100% when compared to the same month in 2010.

summary:
An anarchist group detonated a small explosive device in a four-star hotel in Davos, 1.5 Km from where the World Economic Forum was being held. The explosion took place in an underground storage area of the Posthotel Morosani at approximately 09:00. It caused no casualties and little damage to the hotel.
Shortly before the attack, a forum member with the name 'Revolutionary Perspective' claimed responsibility for the attack on an Italian activist Web site. The posting said, 'we have attacked the Hotels Morosani with pyrotechnics and sugar'. The claim of responsibility was also sent to a Swissnewspaper.
Swiss bankers and the Swiss government were using the hotelduringtheconference.

summary:
Bomb disposal experts are examining a car which is believed to contain a large bomb on Antrim Road in north Belfast. Over 100 homes and business in the nearby areawere evacuated and the road was closed at 16:00 on Tuesday, when the first reports of a separate explosive device, which was successfully defused, were received.
A series of phone calls were received by police providing contradictory details of where the device was located. The dissident republican group glaigh na hireann (ONH), which local news sources have reported is responsible for the device, has a history of purposefully misdirecting the security forces in an attempt to maximise casualties.
Police officials regard ONH as the most capable, active and dangerous of the dissident republican groups in Northern Ireland. ONH conducted at least five known attacks in 2010.
We will update when we receive further information.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a roadside bomb next to a truck in the southern Thai province of Yala, in an attack which killed nine people and wounded two others. The explosive device was detonated remotely by mobile phone as the vehicle, in which Buddhist rubber plant workers were passengers, passed. All of the victims were believed to be Buddhists.
No group claimed responsibility. However, given the target we believe that it is highly likely that Islamic separatists insurgents were the perpetrators.
In the three southern provinces of Yala, Narathiwat and Pattani, one of the key sources of income is the rubber trade. Rubber plantations are mostly owned by the regions Buddhists who employ predominantly Buddhist staff, which breeds resentment amongst the Malay Muslim population.
These provinces were annexed by Thailand from neighbouring Malaysia in 1902 and the bulk of the population is of Malay extraction, with the Thai speaking Buddhists a minority. Bomb attacks remain relatively uncommon in Yala, though this incident took place just shortly a week after a bomb attack on another of the province's rubber plants in Talor Halor.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated his explosives belt during the Shia Chehlum procession of Hazrat Imam Hussain near Bhati Gate in Lahore, in an attack which resulted in the death of 13 people and injury to at least 50 others. The perpetrator of the attack was believed to be a 13-year old boy who who triggered his suicide vest when police tried to check him at a security cordon.
Given the clear sectarian motivations behind the attack, we suspect the involvement of an organisation affiliated with Tehrik-e-Taliban - Pakistan (TTP). The group views Shia Muslims as apostates and utilises such operations to try to undermine the Pakistani government and provoke chaos within the country.
Lahore was the site of major suicide attacks aimed at Shia targets in September 2010, which left 28 people dead and more than 170 injured. Chehlum represents the end of the 40 day religious mourning period for Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Muhammad.

summary:
A suicide attack killed 35 people and wounded 168 more in the baggage area of the international arrivals hall at Domodedovo Airport in Moscow. Amongst those killed or injured were known to be British, French, German, Slovakian, Italian, Serbian, Tajik, Uzbek and Kyrgyz citizens.
Preliminary reports said that the device, equivalent to 7kg of TNT, caused the explosion. Screws and other shrapnel were found at the scene, which suggests that the bomber intended to cause as many casualties as possible. It is believed that the assailant was able, as a result of the laxity of security at the airport, to walk directly into the arrivals hall with a bomb carried within a suitcase.
Security was heightened at the city's Vnukovo and Sheremetyevo airports in response to the attack, and the baggage of all passengers, whether they arrived by ground transport or the Aeroexpress train, was inspected. Russian President Dmitry Medvedev subsequently pledged 3 million roubles to the families of each person killed, launched an investigation into the incident and requested that interior ministers draft plans for a radical revision of transport security within the country.
No terrorist organisation claimed the attack.
The last major terrorist operation in the Russian capital took place on 29 March 2010, when a female suicide bomber detonated her explosives upon a metro train at the Park Kultury underground station. Fifteen people were killed and 34 injured as a result. It is believed that the perpetrators of that incident were militants linked to the Caucasus Emirate, a group which is known to have conducted operations outside of the North Caucasus region, including the November 2009 bomb attack on the Nevsky Express.
Though widely regarded as Moscow's most modern airport, there had been previous criticisms of Domodedovo's security infrastructure and procedures. In 2004, two suicide bombers boarded planes having illegally purchased tickets from airport personnel, and subsequently detonated their explosives in mid-air, killing the 90 passengers aboard the two flights in the process. In this case, entrance to the arrivals hall was easily secured, as an adequate control system was lacking, with neither people nor luggage subjected to procedural scans which are the norm in airports in the USA and Great Britain.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a car bomb in Karbala in a targeted attack on Shia pilgrims, which killed six people and injured 13 others. The device was planted in a car park on the outskirts of the city where observers of an event to mark the end of Arbaeen had parked their vehicles. A second bomb was found nearby and dismantled prior to detonation. The devices had been planted despite the presence of a security cordon of 120,000 police and security officials.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though given the nature of the target and the overt sectarian motive, the perpetrators were likely to be have been Sunni extremists affiliated with Al-Qaeda, most probably members of the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI). These groups view Shias as apostates.
The attack came after a triple suicide bombing on two roads leading to Karbala days earlier killed at least 50 people and injured 150 others.
Arbaeen marks the end of the 40-day mourning period for Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Muhammad and an integral figure in the Shia interpretation of Islam. The Arbaeen pilgrimage attracts hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of Shia Muslims from Iraq, neighbouring Iran and other Shia communities around the world, which provides a high numbr of potential targets for Iraqi extremist groups.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Gerakan Mujahideen Islami Pattani (GMIP) gunmen killed one man and wounded another in an armed attack near to the village of Mo Mawi in Yarang district. The assailants, who rode in a pick-up truck, opened fire with Ak-47 rifles on the victims as they travelled along the Bannang Sata - Yala road in a similar vehicle.
Though no group claimed responsibility for the attack, its location would suggest the involvement of the GMIP. The exact motive for the assault could not be determined though Malay-Muslim groups which operate in Narathiwat, Yala and Pattani are known to target Buddhist plantation workers and security forces predominantly.
The incident occurred three days after a para-military ranger was assassinated in Pattani in a similar attack.

summary:
New People's Army (NPA) militants killed five police officers in an armed ambush in the Iluru village of Rizal. The incident occurred when a law enforcement vehicle drove over a mine, believed to have been planted by the NPA, and then a group of approximately 30 militants opened fire at the car with semi automatic weapons.
This was the first attack to cause multiple casualties since the agreement of a resumption in formal peace talks between the government and the NPA on 18 January. The leftist group, which is believed to retain about 4700 fighters, has been waging a four decade long campaign in rural areas. Despite official hopes for a resolution of the conflict by 2014, regional experts suggest that the major ideological differences which exist between the two parties are likely to prevent a permanent peace.
There had been three other armed assaults in the Philippines since the turn of the year prior to this incident, though this was the first use of landmines.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated an 81 mm mortar bomb placed under a seat on a passenger bus in the Philippine capital of Manila, in an attack which killed five peopleand injured a further 13. The blast, which took place whilst the bus was in the Makati business district, was triggered remotely through the use of a mobile phone. Local security sources stated that the shell had been placed in the centre of the vehicle in a bid to maximise casualties.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack though radical Islamist groups such as Abu Sayyaf, as well as the leftist guerrilla organisation the New People's Army (NPA), have conducted terrorist operations in the country previously. Security officials noted the parallels between this incident and the attack conducted by Abu Sayyaf on 14 February 2005, which occurred on the same road in Manila and also involved the use of a remote controlled device planted on a bus. In addition, such devices have been used in attacks on the southern island of Mindanao where the group maintains a strong operational presence.
The timing, power and location of the explosion suggest that this attack, whilst clearly intended to maim or kill the passengers, was also aimed at destabilising the capital city's central business hub.
The incident occurred upon the same day that suspected NPA militants conducted an armed ambush attack upon government security forces.
In November the US, Australia, Canada and New Zealand stated in travel advisories that Manila was a possible target for a terrorist attack. However, incidents such as this one are rare in the capital, with the last recorded assault a bomb operation conducted by Abu Sayyaf in November 2009, which caused no casualties. The bulk of the country's terrorist attacks occur in the south, particularly in Mindanao, known as a stronghold for the Al-Qaeda linked group.
source_urls: BBC, Associated Press, Asia Sentinel, Bloomberg, Philippine Inquirer, Reuters
author: Unknown author

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated an improvised explosive device (IED) which they had planted on the outer wall of a state-run girls' school in the Landi Kotal area of Khyber Agency, in an assault which severely damaged the building but did not cause any casualties. The IED was triggered by remote control.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. It would appear, given the time at which the bomb was detonated, that the operation was not intended to cause any casualties.
This incident occurred less than a week after an attack upon a school in Peshawar, which resulted in 15 casualties and two fatalities, and was the fifth assault to target educational institutions since the beginning of 2011. The last recorded attack of this kind in Landi Kotal took place on 14 December 2010 in a Lashkar-e-Islam (LI) stronghold.

summary:
Unidentified militants launched an explosives-based sabotage attack upon a gas pipeline in the Paish Bogi area of Dera Bugti district in Balochistan. Security officials said that the assault, which destroyed a pipeline that supplied gas to a purification plant, would not affect supplies to the province, particularly the capital Quetta.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, which took place in a region that has suffered from an insurgency waged by ethnic Baloch tribes seeking greater political rights and access to profits from natural resources, and also operations by Taliban militants.
Sabotage assaults on infrastructure, such as gas pipelines however, have become the trademark of the Balochistan Republican Army, a separatist group which had conducted three similar operations prior to this incident during the month of January.

No group claimed responsibility for what would appear to have been a religiously motivated attack, though given the location we suspect the involvement of Tehrik-e-Taliban - Pakistan (TTP).
The last armed assault in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa prior to this incident took place on 14 January and, as in this case, the assailants targeted the victims whilst they were in a private residence. We have recorded three attacks of this kind since the turn of the year in the area, which have resulted in a total of 9 fatalities and three casualties.

Eyewitness accounts stated that three men on a motorcycle stopped outside a tea-stall ostensibly to ask a group of men for directions, and when the group stepped closer a second group arrived on another motorcycle with their faces covered. The masked men then opened fire on the group with semi-automatic weapons and single barrelled rifles.
The Jangalmahal area used to be a Maoist stronghold and this attack demonstrates the faction's desire to win back control of a district now controlled by the Marxist wing of the Communist party.

summary:
Tajik security forces averted two explosions outside the Sughd police directorate and the State Committee for National Security (SCNS) office in the provincial capital of Khujand. Two vehicles, loaded with timed explosives had been planted outside the two buildings.
The first of these, abandoned outside the police directorate, contained an improvised explosive device (IED) with power equivalent to 6kg of TNT, which was defused by bomb disposal experts.
Security personnel were unable to open the doors of the vehicle left outside the SCNS office and made the decision to dispose of the car in the nearby Syrdarya River, thus neutralising the explosive device which it contained.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) was said to have conducted a similar operation which targeted another Khujand police station on 3 September 2010, in which two people were killed and 25 injured.
Tajikistan does not suffer from frequent terrorist violence, with only six recorded attacks during 2010. Nonetheless, as a result of those operations, most of which could be traced to the IMU, 28 people were killed and 72 injured.

The attack coincided with a presentation about the type of weapons being used by terrorist groups in the country, which was about to start.

summary:

The first incident occured on the northern side of the city at approximately 15:00. The second explosion took place approximately 20 minutes later 15 Km south of the city. Both attacks reportedly took place close to checkpoints to the city. Early reports suggest that both suicide bombers were among the Shia procession when they detonated their explosives.
Earlier in the day, a suicide bomber killed three people after detonating his explosive-laden vehicle at the police headquarters in Diyala province. At least three four other suicide attacks against sectarian targets and the security forces earlier in the week preceded these incidents.
Due to the attacks' sectarian nature we suspect they were carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks.

summary:
At approximately 10:00 a suicide bomber in an explosive-laden ambulance attacked an Iraqi police training centre. The blast killed 15 people and injured 70 more. Local sources reported that nearby buildings including the Al-Batool women and children's hospital.
Reports suggested that the prior to the attack the FPS received a call from an individual purporting to be from the provincial health department that said an ambulance would shortly be arriving. If confirmed, this is why the ambulance managed to get as close as it.
Approximately 90 minutes after the attack, a suicide bomber in an explosive-laden vehicle attacked a crowd of Shias 15 km from the city. This attack killed 2 people.

summary:
Armed militants killed four soldiers in an audacious raid on a military base in Narathiwat's Rangae district.Military officials said that up to 40 gunmen attacked the camp in Maruebotok Village.
Although reports suggested that the camp knew about the impending attack, following a tip-off, the militants still managed to steal 50 rifles and over 5,000 bullets.
The raid was well planned, sophisticated and lasted approximately 30 minutes. Reports suggested that 10 militants distracted the soldiers by attacking the front outpost. A group of at least 20 gunmen then made their way to the armoury. After an exchange of fire, the insurgents escaped with M16 assault rifles, Uzi sub-machine guns and an M60 7.62mm portable machine gun. The number of wounded insurgents remains unknown.
To prevent reinforcements from arriving at the camp, the militants reportedly put  spikes and fallen trees on the main road.
No group claimed the attack.

Police belived that the casualty numbers would have been much higher, if the bomb had detonated half-an-hour later. Many of thechildren that would have been at the scene at the time of the explosion, were yet to arrive at school.
No group claimed responsibility, but based on previous attacks of this nature Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is the most likely culprit.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated explosive devices outside two bars 100m apart in central Ajaccio in a twin bomb attack. Local sources reported that three suffered minor injuries, but the two bars, located beneath a block of apartments in the Cannes neighbourhood of the city, were completely destroyed. Significant collateral damage was also caused to the residential buildings from the devices, which contained 5 and 10 kilograms of explosives, and were detonated within minutes of each other.
No group claimed responsibility though the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) is known to have conducted bomb attacks upon holiday complexes and similar 'soft targets' in the past.
This was the first bomb attack in the capital of Corsica since the failed attempt on an Electricite de France (EDF) building on 15 September 2010, and terrorist incidents, particularly of this magnitude, are very rare in Ajaccio. The FLNC continues to wage its struggle for greater autonomy for Corsica from mainland France through sporadic low-level attacks.

There were no reported casualties as a result of the blast though material damage was caused to the building as the bomb had been planted within a drainpipe. Fragments of two bolts and two metal tubes were discovered at the scene.
Whilst no group claimed responsibility for the attack, the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia is suspected of involvement.
Prior to this incident there had been two attacks on businesses in Dagestan over the last month, on 2 January and 20 December, both of which bore the hallmarks of the terrorist organisation. The bulk of the assaults which take place in the Republic are aimed at law enforcement officials and institutions.

summary:
An unidentified suicide bomber detonated an explosive vest at a police recruitment centre in Tikrit, in an attack which killed 50 people and wounded over 100 more. More than 300 people had lined up outside the building with their documents in the hope of securing a job, and local security sources confirmed that the majority of those killed were police recruits. The death toll was the highest from a single attack since the seizure of a Baghdad church in October 2010.
The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed responsibility for the attack.
Tikrit is the hometown of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein and predominantly Sunni. Salah al-Din province as a whole continues to suffer regular attacks by Sunni insurgents opposed to the predominantly Shia government in Baghdad.
This was the eleventh assault aimed at police targets since the turn of the year in Iraq, and the seventh to utilise explosives. The last attack on police in Tikrit was on 8 January.

Following the attack the militants pasted posters in the area demanding that the company stop using machines and to increase the workers' pay. The Maoists are trying to attract the support of labourers in the area to further disrupt construction work.
The Maoists also cut trees near the Gajalbadi village to block the road from Ganjam district to the neighbouring district of Kandhmal.

At 04:00 suspected members of the National Liberation Front of Corsica (FLNC) launched a bomb attack upon a villa which was under construction in Sartene. There were no casualties in the operation as the building was unoccupied, however it did catch fire before it was later extinguished by firefighters.
The FLNC conducted a similar attack in Sartene on 25 March 2010 in which it detonated bombs outside three homes that were part of a housing development. This incident occurred approximately three weeks after militants detonated two bombs in a holiday complex in Castellare Di Casinca.
Terrorist attacks do not occur with any great frequency in Corsica, though the organisation continues to rail against a perceived foreign occupation by mainland France and holiday homes are often posited as an extension of this external control.

summary:
At 03:30 a bomb exploded outside an office linked to Derry/Londonderry's term as UK City of Culture on Custom House Street. The blast caused minor damage to the building's front door and no casualties were reported.
Dissident republicans were believed to have planted the device. The city's mayor said the incident represented an assault on the people of Londonderry and added that it was 'actually a sectarian attack'.
Londonderry's victory in the July 2009 campaign for nomination as the UK's City of Culture in 2013 had been heralded as demonstrative of the city's progress since the height of the Troubles and welcomed by both unionists and nationalists.

summary:

The incident comes days before the Croatian president, Ivo Josipovic, is set to visit Germany.
There has been a spate of parcel bomb attacks across europe in recent months. In November 2010, the Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei sent parcel bombs to embassies across Athens and the leaders of France, Riome and Germany. In December 2010, the Informal Federation of Anarchy claimed responsibility for sending parcel bombs to the Swiss and Chilean Embassies in Rome.

The former official escaped uninjured.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though the involvement of Islamist separatists is likely.
The incident did not represent the first time that Shogenov had been targeted. He survived a bomb assault at a Nalchik race course in May 2010 in which one person was killed and 20 others were injured.
The security situation in Kabardino-Balkaria worsened considerably during 2010, with a significant increase in the number of terrorist attacks when compared with 2009. We recorded only two incidents in the whole of that year, whilst 2010 saw over 39.

summary:
An unidentified terrorist targeted the Governor of Anbar Province in a suicide attack in the region's capital Ramadi. The official was uninjured after the assailant drove an explosives laden vehicle into his convoy. The blast killed one of his bodyguards and wounded at least five people.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack. The governor of Anbar has frequently been targeted over recent years, and had survived numerous other assaults prior to this incident. His headquarters were hit three times during 2010 and he had lost a hand in a suicide attack in December 2009.
Overall there has been a marked decrease in violence in Anbar since it was a stronghold of the Sunni insurgency between 2003 and 2006. Nonetheless, two major bomb attacks took place in Ramadi in December 2010 in which over 70 people were injured and 16 people killed, and the province does still suffer from relatively regular terrorist operations. A week prior to this incident a Chief of Police known to have launched an intense counter terrorism programme against the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) was killed in a roadside bomb assault.

summary:
Armed Yemeni tribesmen attempted to kidnap four Czech tourists in the Al-Haima Al-Kharijia district, in an attack which resulted in injury to two soldiers and a child. The group were being escorted by security personnel when the assailants opened fire in an effort to take the European travellers, who were not hurt in the attack, hostage. Armed forces were able to fend off the assault and force the tribesmen to retreat in their damaged vehicle.
Kidnapping is often utilised by tribesmen in the lawless areas of Yemen in an effort to force the government to meet their demands, which are often focused on the release of individuals from a given tribal group that have been detained by the government on charges of affiliation with Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).
The Yemeni government faces a triadic threat from AQAP, a southern separatist insurgency and Shia militancy.

summary:
Two people were wounded when their motorcycle triggered a bomb believed to have been planted by southern insurgents at a plantation in Talor Halor, in the Raman District of Yala.
The blast left a crater 40 cm wide and 30 cm deep and pieces of a PVC pipe and six spent AK-47 rifle shells were found scattered at the scene. Local security sources reported that the bomb weighed about 6kg and was planted the preceding evening. A dog which had been poisoned was also found nearby. 
None of Thailand's separatist groups claimed responsibility for the device. It is thought that this incident was part of an ongoing campaign by these organisations to intimidate local people, that a pet was poisoned, further indicates this.
Bomb attacks are rare in Yala, with this incident only the third of its kind in the area since the beginning of October. Armed assaults are more common however, with a number recorded in most months of 2010.
