summary:
Less than an hour before the start of the Martin Luther King Day parade route in downtown Spokane, Washington, three city employees discovered a backpack which contained an improvised explosive device (IED) and two t-shirts. The authorities re-routed the march and bomb disposal experts defused the bomb with a robot.
At least 1,500 people would have walked past the device during the parade, meaning that the attack could have caused hundreds of casualties.
The FBI said that given the timing and placing of the 'viable device', political motivations were behind the attempted attack. The FBI was investigating the incident as a foiled act of 'domestic terrorism'.

summary:
Suspected Taliban militants killed a driver and set fire to a vehicle laden with furniture destined for the education department in the Posht Rod district of Farah province. The truck was part of a convoy, and the assailants stopped the vehicles and opened fire before they set one of them alight. The other driver managed to escape the attack.
The drivers had been requested to transport the goods without a police escort in an attempt to prevent insurgent assaults. In the previous week two truckloads of tables and chairs had been successfully delivered to a school in the same district.
The Taliban did not officially claim responsibility for the attack, though is known to oppose the teaching of girls and what it sees as 'western education'.
The security situation in Farah is relatively stable overall, only five attacks occurred prior to this incident over the previous four months in the province, though two of these were armed assaults.

summary:
Suspected Pakistani Taliban militants detonated a remote controlled bomb attached to a passenger bus in Kohat, in an attack which killed 17 people and injured at least 11 others. Two exploded gas cylinders were found in the wreckage of the bus and local security sources stated that the explosive device had been placed near to these in order to cause the blast.
There was no official claim of responsibility and the exact motives behind the attack were not established. However, local news sources stated that the assault may have had sectarian motivations and been aimed at passengers from Pakistan's Shia minority.
This was the deadliest attack to take place in Kohat since 8 December, when militants launched a bomb assault which killed 17 and injured a further 25. Though such incidents do not occur frequently in the town, they tend to cause large numbers of casualties.

summary:
An improvised explosive device constructed of gas cylinders was detonated in front of a branch of Proton Bank in the Vyronas area of Athens. The blast caused material damage to the building and caused a fire, though no casualties were reported. Fire service personnel subsequently quelled the blaze.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however Greek police had issued a statement the preceding day which warned of assaults by the anarchist group Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei.
Four members of the group were arrested on 13 January and amongst their possession was a laptop upon which a draft statement of responsibility for an unspecified attack scheduled to take place before the trial of other members on 17 January.
Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei members were responsible for the parcel bomb attacks upon embassies in the capital on 2 November and were purported to have provided the inspiration for the similar assaults on diplomatic offices in Rome in the month which followed.

No group claimed responsibility for the assault, though we strongly suspect the involvement of the anarchist group, the Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei. Further details regarding why this company was targeted were unavailable.
Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei had conducted a bomb assault on 30 December that they stated was undertaken in solidarity with the members of the group due to stand trial on 17 January, and it is likely that this incident had similar motivations. 
This was the third incident of its kind in Athens on 16 January, and the first recorded example of a construction company having been targeted. The majority of recorded terrorist attacks in Greece have been aimed at businesses.

summary:
Far left militants launched a bomb attack on a police station in the town of Horqueta in Concepcion department and injured four officers. The device was planted outside the building in a backpack and detonated as police responded to an emergency call. Nearby homes also suffered material damage. 
A group which referred to itself as the Paraguayan People's Army (EPP) claimed responsibility for the attack, and declared that the assault was undertaken in revenge for the death of two members of the organisation in a previous exchange of fire with police, and added that the police should 'forget the word mercy'.
Many members of the organisation are believed to be located in Horqueta. Local security sources stated that the group was also behind a previous bomb attack earlier in the week and had, in the past, been blamed for high profile abductions dating back to 1997.
The EPP is believed to have received training from the Colombian insurgent group the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and to consist of approximately 100 members. Paraguayan President, Fernando Lugo, had dispatched additional troops and police to the regions bordering Brazil and Bolivia in an effort to detain the militants last year, though the mission was ultimately a failure.

summary:
A series of coordinated attacks against different mosques in Baghdad killed two civilians and injured 11 other people. Iraq's Interior Ministry said suspected Al-Qaeda members conducted the attacks, which targeted an interfaith group that was trying to quell recent attacks against Christians in Iraq.
The media released very little information about the attacks. Local sources said that one of the explosions took place outside a mosque where the interfaith group was meeting.
Another blast occurred outside Sheikh Abdul-Qader al-Gailany's Mosque in Central Baghdad, and claimed the life of a civilian and wounded five other people. The explosion damaged several civilian cars in the area.
A further explosion took place outside Al-Assaf Mosque in Baghdad's Aamdhamiya district, and wounded three civilians and damaged shops and cars. Finally militants detonated an explosive device near Ziwiya Mosque, which killed one civilian and injured three others.
No group claimed responsibility, but the coordinated nature of the attack suggests it was conducted by the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).

Local news sources reported that the assailants threw two grenades at the building, only one of which detonated, and caused damage to the property but no casualties.
The perpetrators of the attack and their motivations could not be established, however some security sources conjectured that the incident may have been related to Hezbollah's resignation from government and the subsequent political crisis. The head of the Free Patriotic Movement, Michael Aoun, is considered an ally of the Shia organisation.
The assault came hours after the leader of Hezbollah declared that the resignation of his party's ministers would not precipitate a civil war within the country.

Although a lull in violence has been reported in Darfur, aid groups are often targeted by attacks or kidnappings. Most of the workers get released negotiations or tribal mediation. Currently, no group claimed responsibility for the abduction.

summary:
An unidentified suicide bomber detonated his explosive-belt near to the Afghan parliament on Darul Aman Road in Kabul, in an attack which caused damage to nearby cars and buildings and killed two people. At least 36 others were wounded. Security sources stated that the assailant approached the scene on a motorcycle and targeted a minibus on which intelligence personnel were travelling to work.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
This incident represented the third bomb attack of 2011 in Kabul but the first suicide operation.Two suicide attacks had taken place earlier in the week in Spin Boldak.
Major assaults in the Afghan capital had been relatively rare over the preceding year; the last recorded mass casualty attack took place on 25 August 2010 and this was one of only five such incidents over the full calendar year. The installation of a 'ring of steel' in the city in preparation for the September parliamentary election had served as an effective preventative measure.
area: Alaudin Road Crossing, Darul Aman Road, Kabul
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomber in an explosives-laden car drove into the heavily fortified Merian police station in Bannu at high speed. The subsequent blast killed 17 and wounded a further 20 people. Local security sources reported that the assailant struck an outer wall of the police compound, which is located in a densely populated area of the district, and that parts of the station along with a mosque inside the facility suffered heavy damage. Some people were buried underneath rubble and amongst those confirmed dead were a number of members of a federal paramilitary police force and civilians praying at the mosque.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed the attack, which came after they had threatened in December to launch assaults that targeted police officials involved in counter-terrorism operations.The group said that it was a response to US drone strikes in the tribal areas of the country, which have killed hundreds of militants but also resulted in civilian fatalities. 2009 and 2010 saw a 300% increase in the number of these operations in Pakistan when compared with George W. Bush's second term in office, and the attack took place on the same day that it was announced that 3 people had been killed in neighbouring North Waziristan.
This incident was striking in that it took place merely hours after US Vice President Joe Biden had given a speech in Islamabad. Biden had attempted to quash what he called 'anti-American misperceptions' centred around Washington's motives for its actions in Pakistan. Behind the scenes American officials were reported to have asked Islamabad to step up its military campaign in the tribal areas of the north-west.
Bannu is located near to North Waziristan, one of the troubled Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA). The agency has been the target of a number of US drone strikes but is also the only one of these areas in which the Pakistani military has not, so far, conducted counter-terrorism operations. North Waziristan, especially, serves as a safe-haven for Taliban and Al-Qaeda operatives, and the suicide attack seemed precisely timed to provide a warning to the government not to extend the scope of its mission in the tribal borderlands, and an effort to further undermine the already uneasy relationship between the US and Pakistan.
area: Merian Police Station, Bannu District, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the placement of the device.
Mines are used commonly by the group to target security officials, though this was the first report of their use, and the second attack overall, in Konar since the turn of the year. The province suffers from terrorist attacks only sporadically, and the incidents that do occur rarely involve the use of mines.

This was the second mine explosion of the day in Afghanistan and came a day after two civilians were killed in a blast from a device of this kind in Farah Province. The last recorded landmine attack in Ghazni took place on 16 December and targeted construction workers, three of which were injured.

Two remote controlled explosive devices placed at the roadside were detonated in quick succession. Local security sources said that battery cells had been found at the site of the blast.
The TTP and affiliated groups such as Lashkar-e-Islam (LeI) are known to have conducted numerous attacks on schools, particularly in the nearby tribal areas.
The incident came two days after a remote controlled bomb attack outside a school in the Banaras Abad area of Peshawar, in which two female students were killed. This was the fourth bomb attack aimed at an educational institution since the start of 2011 in the areas bordering Afghanistan.

summary:
A mine attack launched by suspected Maoist militants injured three state agriculture department officials in a 4x4 vehicle near Odiapentha village in Koraput. Local news sources reported that officials were on the way to Narayanpatna when the blast was triggered. The driver of the vehicle suffered severe injury.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack but the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) is known to operate in Orissa and had previously targeted government officials.
Bomb attacks occur sporadically in the state, with mines last utilised on 10 February 2010. The most recent recorded incident in Koraput was an armed attack on 9 December.

Local news sources reported that the victim sustained bullet injuries to the head and was taken to hospital. 
The incident was only the 10th example of terrorist violence in Gadchiroli since May 2009, half of which were aimed at law enforcement personnel and all bar one involved the use of firearms.

Nigerian security forces prevented a bomb attack upon the Plateau State House of Assembly in Jos. They accosted a man within the complex who, amongst other possessions, carried a small tin suspected to contain an explosive device. Local police promised a thorough investigation into the incident.
No group claimed responsibility for the attempted attack.
The incident came against a backdrop of ongoing sectarian violence between Christians and Muslims in Plateau State. Jos, the capital, suffered several bomb attacks carried out by the jihadist group Boko Haram on Christmas Eve which served to further inflame tension in the restive province.

summary:
Bomb disposal experts defused an improvised explosive device (IED) found in an apartment in the capital of Dagestan, Makhachkala. The bomb was said to have power equivalent to 2kg of TNT.
No group claimed responsibility for the device, though given its location the involvement of the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia is likely.
This incident came after a bomb attack upon a supermarket in Khasavyurt on 2 January that used an improvised explosive device (IED). Similar devices were used in two separate attacks in Dagestan in December of last year.

summary:
A roadside bomb exploded on 10 January, in Anbar province, killing the Chief of Police and wounding four of his bodyguards. The explosion killed Colonel Mohammed Faisal al-Gu'ood and destroyed his convoy.
Iraqi security forces cordoned off the area and imposed curfew while policemen and soldiers were deployed in the area to look for assailants.
Col. Gu'ood was in the post since 2008 and was well known for hunting down Al-Qaeda militants in the area. We suspect it was a reprisal attack carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq (ISI).

summary:
Unknown gunmen killed a civilian in the Al-Jazair area of Mosul. In what appears to have been a targeted attack, the man, reportedly a Shia of Shabak ethnicity, was shot as he left work at a hospital in the city. 
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, which represented a further operation aimed at minorities in Iraq.
Ninewa is home to both Sunni Arab and Kurdish communities as well as Assyrian, Shabak, Turkmen and Yazidi minorities, and continues to suffer from terrorist violence. Since 1 October, Mosul, the capital of the province, had seen 68 attacks, the bulk of which were aimed at either security or police personnel.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen murdered a Shabak civilian in the Adan neighbourhood of Mosul. Local security sources stated that the assailants killed the victim, a doctor, with Kalashnikov rifles as he worked at his clinic.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) are active in Mosul, with a senior police officer killed on 29 December by members after he initiated aggressive raids against the organisation.
This attack was the second of the day aimed on Shabak civilians in Mosul, an area where violence has decreased over recent years but terrorist incidents still occur regularly.
The Shabak people are an Indo-European ethnic and religious minority group. They, along with fellow minorities the Yazidis and Assyrians had previously been targeted by militants in Ninewa Province.

No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. The Hamas is said to have started appealing to militant groups in Gaza to stop firing rockets in fear of anIsraelioffensive on Palestine.

The police immediately cordoned off the area without providing further details.

summary:
One Yemeni soldier was killed and two others were injured in an exchange of fire with suspected separatist militants in the Al-Milah area of Lahj province. Local news sources stated that the casualties were suffered as the army combed the area and added that one militant had been wounded.
The incident came two days after separatists launched an armed attack against a military checkpoint in Al-Milah and killed six people.
Yemen continues to struggle with the triple threat posed by the activities of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), a violent secessionist insurgency and the country's Shia rebels.

summary:
Militants shot dead a paramilitary ranger in Sungaipadi district in Narathiwat on 10 January. The ranger, a member of the 45th Rangers Regiment, was travelling on motorcycle from his home to his post when he was followed by six militants on three motorcycles. Pillion riders then opened fire with automatic weapons and killed the man instantly.
We suspect the New Pattani United Liberation Organisation (PULO) was responsible for the attack. The group is known to be active in the area, and regularly launches attacks on policemen while riding motorcycles.

summary:
Unidentified militants killed a man in Narathiwat Province in an armed attack. Local sources stated that the assailants opened fire and then escaped on motorcycles.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though Thailand's three main separatist groups are known to have a strong presence in Narathiwat. A motive could not be established.
This was the third terrorist operation of 2011 in Narathiwat and came on the same day that militants killed a paramilitary ranger in a similar assault.

summary:
Suspected Al-Shabaab militants killed one civilian and wounded three others in a grenade attack aimed at Somali government forces in the Wadajir district of Mogadishu. Transitional Federal Government (TFG) soldiers were targeted as they travelled through a market in the area.
Local news sources reported that the market was particularly busy when the blast took place as minibuses arrived carrying the narcotic plant Khat. Security forces subsequently detained a minibus from which the grenade was purportedly launched.
Whilst no group claimed responsibility for the attack, it is highly likely that this incident was the latest example of ongoing conflict between the government and Al-Shabaab.
The group targeted security personnel in Mogadishu on 63 occasions during 2010 and this incident followed an armed attack in the Somali capital on 5 January and a grenade attack the day before.

summary:
One unidentified militant was killed and another injured when a mine detonated in the Spin Masjid area of Khost city. The device exploded prematurely as the men attempted to plant it in a canal.
No group claimed responsibility, however the intended target was likely to have been the local police force, which is known to conduct stop searches in the area. No law enforcement officials were present when the mine was detonated.
Taliban involvement is likely given their acknowledged presence in Khost and their previous use of mines in attacks on security personnel. Foreign forces were targeted with a mine in the Mandozai district on 6 January.

summary:
Unidentified militants shot at and set fire to a NATO oil tanker in the town of Khuzdar in Balochistan. The vehicle was destined for Afghanistan. No casualties or fatalities were reported.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however Taliban involvement is highly probable given their history of similar assaults upon NATO supply vehicles.
The last recorded armed attack upon a NATO container in Balochistan took place on 30 December in Bolan, when the cargo was destroyed and the driver of the vehicle killed. It was the third such incident to take place in the province over that month.

The Taliban have claimed responsibility for the attack.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and Lashkar-e-Islam (LeI) have both previously targeted schools in the Khyber Agency.
The incident represented the sixth bomb attack aimed at educational figures or institutions since the start of December 2010.

summary:
Suspected Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) terrorists ambushed a vehicle belonging to the Yemeni state electricity company in the southern province of Abyan.
Several terrorists on motorcycle attacked the vehicles with automatic weapons. Three state employees and a soldier were killed in the attack and three more were wounded. 
The vehicle had been transporting ten million Yemen Rials (approximately US $47,000) to deposit in Zinjibar, the provinces capital. The media firm Xinhua reported that an un-official government sources claimed that Al-Qaeda was behind the attack and that it has succedded in stealing the money. This claim was denied by official government sources. 
Abyan was subjected to several attacks against government institutions in the first few weeks of January 2011. The authorities continue to deal with a potent campaign conducted by AQAP as well as a continuing insurgency prosecuted by separatists in Yemens southern region.

summary:
An explosion ripped through the Prem Tinsulanonda School causing severe property damage to the front and interiors of the school. There were no reported casualties. The United Front for Democracy against Dictatorship (UDD) is believed to be responsible for the attack.
The school was established and funded by Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda's foundation. The Gen. is believed to be responsible for the 2006 military coup that ousted then-premier, Thaksin Shinawatra, who is strongly supported by the UDD. The attack came a day before the UDD's rally commemorating the death of anti-governmentprotestersin Bangkok last year.
The UDD attacked the school, using grenades, twice last year on 20 March and 13 October.

summary:
Children in Kerave Village, Nerul found an unexploded grenade. The device was located in a chocolate box, with the discovery reported to police who subsequently inspected the device alongside the bomb detection and disposal squad. Officials issued a general alert which advised the public to be wary of unusual objects in public places and to report them immediately to the authorities.
No group claimed responsibility for the device.
The last successful attack to take place near to the major city of Mumbai was in Pune on 13 February 2010.

summary:
Maoist militants detonated explosives at a cabin signal point of Bondamunda railway station in Orissa and took 12 people hostage. Local news sources reported that the explosion took place at 02:00 and between 50 and 60 armed assailants attached to the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) then abducted rail employees, who were later released.
Train services between Chakradharpur and Rourkela and between Rourkela and Hatia were disrupted for more than eight hours as a result of the attack.
Posters which stated opposition to the central government's anti-Maoist 'Operation Green Hunt', criticised harassment of the innocent tribal populace and demanded the release of Dr. Binayak Sen, a human rights activist that had criticised the governments anti-Maoist operations and was arrested in 2007, were left at the scene.
More than half of Orissa's 30 districts have suffered from Maoist violence, with Sundergarh, Kandhamal and Rayagada considered strongholds. 2010 saw 30 terrorist incidents take place in the state.

summary:
Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghred (AQIM) gunmen kidnapped two French nationals in Niamey, the Niger capital.
The victims were at a bar in the Plateau district of Niamey when they were kidnapped. Media sources reported that two gunmen walked in to the bar and forced them to leave at gunpoint. After several hours, French and Niger troops successfully located the hostages close to the Mali border. There were two skirmishes between the troops and the militants and, following the second fire fight, the bodies of the hostages were recovered. They had been executed by the militants.
This is the first time that hostages have been taken from an African capital. AQIM which has Niger has in recent months become a kidnapping location of choice for AQIM however the group has traditionally conducted such operations in remote locations of the country.

summary:
Local media sources reported that unidentified gunmen ambushed a NATO oil tanker in the Sore Kamar area of Jamrud tehsil, Khyber Agency. The attack occurred on the Pakistan-Afghan Highway.
The gunmen reportedly used a grenade and automatics weapons in their attack which damaged the tanker causing the loss if its cargo.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack however given the location and style of attack we suspect militant groups affiliated to the Pakistani Taliban to be involved.

summary:
Unidentified militants opened fire on a gathering at the country home of Timi Alaibe, a former presidential advisor on Niger Delta affairs and current candidate for the Bayelsa governorship, in an attack which killed four and wounded at least six others. The assailants, armed with semi automatic weapons and cutlasses, stormed the grounds on a white bus and took aim at the crowd after they overpowered security operatives.
Supporters had gathered in their thousands at the house in Opokuma to welcome Alaibe, who was not hurt in the attack, home after he had conducted monitoring of a gubernatorial election re-run in Asaba.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack though Alaibe's previous government involvement may have provided its motivation. He had been integral in the implementation of a government-sponsored amnesty programme in 2009 which offered development of the delta region in exchange for the surrender of arms. This began to unravel in late 2010 after the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND), the region's main militant group, launched a new wave of attacks. Other militants who had been refused a role in the amnesty programme were also reported to have established militia groups.
Militants had launched an earlier armed attack on Alaibe's country home in November 2010, a rally for another governorship candidate suffered a similar assault in December, as did another for former military head of state Gen. Muhammadu Buhari. A spokesman for Alaibe however, posited that the attack was the work of political opponents within the current Bayelsa government.
source_urls: The Nation, Vanguard, Nigerian Tribune, Next
author: Unknown author

summary:
Iraqi Army soldiers foiled an attempt to attack the Chaldean Orthodox church in Mosul. Security forces seized six improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and two explosive belts near the church.Mosul has the highest proportion of Christians in Iraq.
We suspect the attack was planned for the Orthodox Christmas evening mass. Coptic churches across Europe, the Middle East and Canada were put on alert ahead of the Coptic Orthodox Christmas.
On 1 January, a suicide bomber detonated a bomb outside the Al-Qidissayn church in Alexandria, as Coptic Christians held mass to celebrate the start of the New Year. The attack killed 21 people and injured 97 others.

summary:

The attack came three days after the end of a 19 day ceasefire agreed upon by the government and the militants.
The NPA is the armed wing of the Communist Party of Philippines and has been active for the last four decades. It is believed to be active in over 60 provinces across the country.

It was difficult to say if the three explosions were connected.

summary:
Al-Shabaab militants launched a hit and run attack on a military basenear Shaqaalaha Road in Mogadishuwhich houses Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and African Union Mission in Somali (AMISOM) forces. The assault was not reported to have caused any direct casualties but prompted an intense exchange of fire that resulted in injuries to six civilians. 
The two sides both utilised heavy mortars, some of which landed in residential areas a considerable distance from the initial site of the conflict. The six casualties occurred at Bakaaraha Market and Suuq Bacaad.
The incident came two weeks after Al-Shabaab fired mortar shells at the presidential palace in Mogadishu. Clashes between government forces and the Islamist group continue to cause considerable civilian casualties, particularly around Bakaaraha Market, the country's largest open air bazaar.

summary:
Early reports suggest that a terrorist attack occurred at the French Embassy in Mali at 18:00. CNN reported that a Tunisian man threw a grenade into the embassy compound, while other sources suggest that a Tunisian man - with Al-Qaeda links - exploded a gas cylinder outside the embassy. One security guard was reportedly wounded in the attack.
Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) is active in Mali, but has conducted very few operations in the country aside from kidnapping hostages. In July 2010, French-backed Mauritanian troops failed to free a French hostage being held by AQIM in Mali. The military raid killed 12 AQIM members. AQIM said it would avenge the deaths of its members, and in August an AQIM suicide bomber attempted to attack a military base in Mauritania close to the Mali border.

summary:
A security guard assassinated the Punjab Governor Salman Taseer at the Kohsar market in Islamabad. Police reported that one of Tasser's own guards shot the official as he left a restaurant. The guard said that he had been planning the attack for four days after learning of the official's opposition to the blasphemy law.
Taseer was an outspoken critic of religious extremists and of the current blasphemy laws, which are often misused to discriminate against non-Muslims. He had described the laws as disgraceful' after the sentencing to death of a Christian woman.
Mr Taseer was a senior member of the ruling Pakistan People's Party (PPP). His death is the most high-profile political assassination  in Pakistan since the death of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto in December 2007.
Police arrested the suspected assassin following the attack.

summary:
Unidentified persons set fire to the Independent National Electoral Commission's (INEC) building razing it to the ground in Ughelli on 4 January. The incident occurred two days before Nigeria's state elections.
A group called the Delta Democratic Militia claimed responsibility for the attack on the INEC building to send a warning against electoral malpractice in the state.
Several groups across Nigeria have been protesting against the polling over INEC's insistence on using the old voters register. The country has witnessed a series of violent attacks over recent weeks including bomb blasts in the capital city of Abuja and the central city, Jos.

summary:
Unidentified militants launched a grenade attack against a four policeman on patrol in Ordzhonikidzevskaya's main square, but there were no reported casualties. Two grenades were thrown, though only one exploded. The officers had been tasked with the maintenance of order iand had been stationed in front of the town's New-Year tree, which suffered damage. 
The assailants were reported to have fled the scene in a silver Lada car.
Whilst no group claimed responsibility for the attack, we strongly suspect the involvement of Ingush Jamaat Sharia given the location and nature of the incident.
This was the second assault in three days in Ordzhonikidzevskaya to involve the use of grenades. Explosive projectiles and bombs are the most commonly utilised forms of weaponry in Ingushetia.

summary:

Local security sources stated that the blast occurred when a shell, that had been placed at the location, exploded. There was some disagreement between sources about the exact nature of the explosive device.
A spokesman for the province's police force stated that the bomb targeted security forces. The shop is known to supply meat to the Afghan army.
This was the first bomb attack of 2011 in Herat, though two incidents of this nature took place in the city in December 2010. Explosives-based operations were the most common type of terrorist incident in the province in 2010, with eighteen of the twenty nine reported attacks incorporating them.

summary:
A senior vice president of the Awami National Party's (ANP) Al-Falah Ward and another man were killed when unidentified militants opened fire upon a business in the Pathan Goth area of Karachi. A further man was injured. Local news sources stated that two men, who rode pillion on motorcycles, fired a number of rounds from a 9mm pistol before they fled.
The ANP member, Aziz Khan, was shot in the head, chest and shoulder.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though an ANP spokesman stated that Khan had been killed purely because of his political affiliation.
Targeted attacks of this nature have taken place in the past in Karachi, with representatives of the two major parties - the Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM) and the ANP - often blaming the other when one of their members was killed.

summary:
Unidentified militants killed a senior worker of the Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM) in an armed attack in the Nazimabad area of Karachi. The deceased was hit by three bullets fired from close range from a 9mm pistol by an assailant who rode pillion on a motorcycle. No other casualties or fatalities were reported.
The incident was followed by riots and arson attacks in a number of areas of the city, with an increased police presence subsequently transferred.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, though it is likely that the assailants had political motivations. This was the second operation of its kind to take place on 3 January in Karachi.
Politically motivated targeted killings occur regularly in Karachi; a recent Pakistani Human Rights Commission report stated that the total number of deaths from such incidents had more than doubled in 2010 compared to the preceding year. It also noted that members of the MQM, which split from the ruling Pakistan People's Party led government on 2 January, are targeted most frequently.

In Ingushetia the number of attacks aimed at religious figures or institutions in 2010 was double the figure of 2009. Furthermore, in total there were 67 recorded incidents in the republic during 2010 as opposed to 47 in 2009.
More broadly, the North Caucasus region continues to be plagued by an Islamist insurgency, with almost daily violence recorded in November and December 2010. We suspect that Ingush Jamaat Sharia, which is linked to the Caucasus Emirate, conducted the attack.

The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has increased its offensive against police and military officials.

summary:
A mine explosion in southern Afghanistan killed an ISAF soldier on 2 January. The ISAF forces refused to disclose the exact location or the nationality of the dead soldier.
The death of this soldier brings the count to three soldiers who have lost their lives within the first two days of the year.

summary:
Unknown gunmen fired at two Internal Troops servicemen deployed at Zavodskoy dsitrict in the Chechen capital of Groznyy, wounding them on 1 January. The servicemen were rushed to a nearby hospital.
Investigators found 14 cartridge cases fired from the automatic weapons. Investigations, into the shooting, are still on.

summary:
A group of unidentified gunmen shot and killed an Iraqi police officer and his driver in central Baghdad on 1 January. The gunmen used silencer weapons to launch the attack. The police officer was in his vehicle on the highway near the Iraqi Finance Ministry when the incident occurred.
While no group has claimed responsibility for the attack, it could have been carried out by members of the former Baathist party or other local insurgent groups.

summary:
Two mortar shells narrowly missed two Iraqi military camps in Al Fallujah on 1 January. One mortar shell fell on the headquarter of an emergency battalion while the other landed on a police centre. There were no reported casualties.
The incident is evidence of local terrorist groups launching their attacks on security bodies in the region.

summary:
A bomb explosion in Narathiwat, early on 1 January, claimed the lives of two bomb-squad policemen and wounded nine others, including five officials. The handmade bomb exploded on a road in a business area just as the two bomb squad officers were checking the basket they were seen in. A mobile phone device was used to detonate the bombs.
Narathiwat has become a hotbed for terrorist activity since the rise of southern Islamic extremism.

summary:
A grenade explosion in Burundi's Bujumbura on 1 January, killed three people and wounded three others. The grenade was planted between metal scrap lying on the roadside in a bid to cause maximum damage.
Security was immediately beefed up around the capital city. However, two more grenade explosions in central Burundi, in Gitenga, and the northeastern province of Kirundo, wounding five people.
Al-Shabaab had threated to launch attacks against Burundi for deploying its soldiers in Somalia through African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM). The group is also known to have launched a grenade attack on a bus in Kenya that killed three people and injured 39 others. However, given the scale of the attack, it is less likely that the Al-Shabaab were involved.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
At approximately 00:20 on 1 January, a suicide bomber detonated an explosive device outside the Al-Qidissayn church in Alexandria. The bomber timed the attack to kill Coptic Christian as they left midnight mass. The blast killed 21 people and injured 97 more, including 18 Muslims.
Initial reports called the attack a car bombing, but investigating authorities later concluded that a suicide bomber standing among the crowd was responsible. Officials believe he had planned to detonate his explosives inside the church.
The explosive device was reportedly homemade, and contained screws and ball bearings to maximise casualties. It reportedly had the equivalent explosive capacity of 10-15kg of TNT.
No group claimed responsibility for the bombing, and the attack marked a significant escalation in the violent tensions seen between Copts and Islamist extremists over the past year.
Initial speculation in the media suggested that the Al-Qaeda franchise Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) might have had a hand in the attack. This was largely due to threats made by the group dating back to 31 October when it warned the Coptic authorities in Egypt to release two female converts it believes are being held by the church, or it would respond with suicide vests'.
On 31 October, the ISI killed 52 Iraqi Christians and injured 67 others in an attack on a Baghdad church, which it said, was a response to the alleged kidnapping. However, the ISI did not claim responsibility for the Alexandria attack, which decreased the likelihood of its involvement.
The Egyptian government subsequently blamed the attack on the Palestinian group the Army of Islam, which it stated had 'relied on an Egyptian element' in its planning, a fact supposedly admitted by the accomplice during questioning by authorities. The man was one of five Egyptians detained in connection with the attack. Army of Islam, believed to view Al-Qaeda leaders as spiritual mentors, denied the charges, though praised those responsible.
The explosion sparked unrest amongst the Christian community leading protesters to attack a mosque and burn cars. Riot police were called in to break up a small riot between members of the two communities following the attack.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Mortar shells landed on a school building damaging property on 1 January in Khyber Agency. There were no reported casualties, however, the school's windowpanes, doors and cupboards were destroyed. The private school's laboratory was also wrecked.
Last year, mortar shells had damaged two classrooms in the same school. The school did not receive any compensation for the damage.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) are known to have destroyed schools in the area as a protest against westernised education.

summary:
Unidentified militants killed two members of the Pro-Talks Faction of the National Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDFB-PTF) and a civilian, and injured a further three people, in an armed attack in the village of Mukuldang in Kokrajhar District. Local security sources stated that the men entered the village before shooting indiscriminately into a gathering.
No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however the NDFB-PTF suggested that the Bodo Liberation Tigers were the perpetrators.
The incident represented the first armed attack to have taken place in Assam in almost two months, after the NDFB undertook six assaults of this nature on 8 and 9 November. The Anti-Talks faction of the NDFB is by far the most violent of the separatist groups which operate in Assam, with the Bodo Liberation Tigers a legitimate part of the Bodoland Territorial Council (BTC) after their surrender in 2003.

summary:
Two separate landmine explosions killed two civilians, including a girl, on 1 January in Kurram Agency and Mohmand Agency respectively.
Unidentified person planted a land mine bomb that exploded injuring a girl. The girl was rushed to a nearby hospital where she succumbed to her injuries.
An explosion in Mohmand district killed a truck driver as he was passing through Olaishah village when the incident occurred.

summary:
Suspected Boko Haram militants set alight part of the Victory Christ Church in Maiduguri. As the building was empty when the attack took place there were no casualties or fatalities.
No official claim of responsibility for the assault was made, however we believe that Boko Haram, the group which perpetrated the Christmas Eve attacks upon churches in the city, to have undertaken the operation.
This incident was one of a number of attacks to have taken place in Maiduguri since 24 December, all of which were intended to foment sectarian violence and instability ahead of the Nigerian elections.
